text: 12oz bottle. Midnight black, frothy light tan head. Toasty malt, bready nose. Flavors are roasted malt, caramel sweetness, nuts, pleasant bittering hops. Delicious, balanced roasted finish. Very tasty.

Draft at Cornerstone. Pours pitch black with tan head into a pint glass. Aroma is roasted malts, light coffee, and light licorice. Flavor includes dark chocolate, dark fruits, and some coffee. Ends with a robust bitter/roasty finish. Would buy this again!
Pours cola brown with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of toffee, biscuit, and chocolate. Toffee and chocolate sweetness with some bread. Creamy body with solid lacing. Very nice beer.

355 ml bottle. BBE 09.07.2017
Rated on 20170519.
Pours clear dark mahogany color with a large off-white head. Malty and nutty aroma with hints of cocoa, mild hops. Flavor has caramel and nutty dry malts, mild orange notes, subtle resin and some chocolaty bitterness at the end. A bit mellow, easy to drink though.
4324

(New Belgium 1554 Black Lager) Bottle 355ml at home, served into a small tulip. ABV 5.6%
Dark brown colour on the body, clear, tall and thick light beige head on top.
Aroma of caramel, toasted malts, some toffee.
Taste follows, caramel, toasted malts, coffee grounds, toffee.
Medium thin body.
Good.
on tap black pour very thin tan head aroma was slight roasted malt taste was smooth if not slightly watery

Draft. Pours dark brown-black with light beige head. Light bread malt aroma. Bread malt with some caramel notes and a subtle touch of chocolate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt. Sweet malty flavour, nutty chocolate, smoky porter.

Aroma is roasty, chocolate, earthy hop, bready, slight coffee, pretty nice. Appearance is dark brown reddish, light brown head, mostly clear from what I can see. Taste is roasted malt, slight cocoa, bready, earthy hop, coffee, Im a fan. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light carbonation, nice bready roasty aftertaste. Overall, very very good.
Very nice porter like beverage. Chocolate malt to keep the sweetness in check but not overwhelm it. Good malty texture. Aroma is pretty muted. Good beer, easy to drink. Not a light affair however.
Nice smooth black lager. Slightly smoky, light hops, smooth finish. March madness 2017.

5/II/17 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ train station Brugge, post-Brugs Bierfestival - BB: V/6/16 (2017-158) Thanks to bartlebier for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark brown beer, small creamy beige head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving some lacing in the glass. Aroma: very malty, grains, hay, cow fodder, caramel, bit sweet, malty. MF: lively carbon, medium body. Taste: malty, grains, bit sourish, malty, caramel, bit greenish, hoppy touch. Aftertaste: bitter, grains, malty, bit sourish, lemony touch, some cardboard. Decent one!

Dark brown color. Big , tan head . Aroma of malt , bread and roasted caramel. Moderate sweetness in rich malty taste. Gentle, roasted bitterness at the end. I'd say it is a Dunkel , not a Shwarzbier . Anyway it's great ,classy beer .

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thank you Bartlebier! 355 ml. bottle split post Bruges Beer Festival 2017 @ train station. BBF 5 JUN 2016. Black, creamy tanned head. Nose is thick soy sauce & grains, mocha, herbal coffee grounds. Taste is lightly metallic upfront, herbal, thick very sweet soy sauce, worth, grains, bit umami. Body is thick, soy sauce. Bit too thick with heavy soy sauce character, almost faint soy sauce but still pretty decent especially considering the age of this.
Pours rather clear dark brown. Small white headm smell is bit sweet. Taste is rather bitter , aromatic dark malts. Rather sweet. Ok. Bit weak though.

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown with slight reddish tint, large foamy beige head, roasted malt aroma, medium carbonation, slightly sweet roasted malt taste, smooth medium thick body, abrupt finish with creamy aftertaste. Very tasty and smooth.

355ml bottle [Thanks and a heartly "sapere aude!" to the Old Belgian philosophe des lumières Pierre Bartle (pron. Bayle) for this 1554 (Renaissance?) brew!]. Opaque, darkest brown colour with ruby glimmer and small to average, thick, foamy, fairly lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Chocolately, dark malty aroma, hints of treacle and pumpernickel, a nuttily touch. Taste is mildly roasty dark malty, minimally ashy, some cola and treacle sweetness in the middle part, again more roasty, minimally ashy and mineral finish, chocolately interludes throughout; full body, slightly viscous texture.
roasted malt, chocolate. Full-bodied, tad sweet. for some reason i wasnt a huge fan on this, and i dont remember why, will have to try this again in the future

Bottle. Pours a clear mahogany with a medium, short lived, beige head with lace. Roasted malt aroma with dark chocolate. Sweet flavor of roasted malt and dark chocolate with a dry, coffee finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Smooth and very drinkable. Suprised me how good it was.

Filled into a well-used New Belgium globe glass. Appropriate. Possessed of a black body with a tan head that dissipates promptly. A whiff of black licorice and blackened toast. Malty taste followed up by raisins and dates. Something earthy at the finish. I like stouts considerably, this is along that line. Not at the top.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a dark brown to almost black with a medium sized tan head. The aroma has a great malt smell. The flavor is malt, with some coffee, chocolate and bread. This is an outstanding beer.

2015 BJCP Category: 8B Schwarzbier
AROMA: Lightly sweet nose of dark toasted malt, some red fruit, and a hint of iced coffee. Very faint herbal hops. 10/12APPEARANCE: Deep ruby red or mahogany. Dark but clear with bright ruby highlights. Large, tan froth. Plenty of lacing. 3/3FLAVOR: Moderately strong malty presence and sweetness throughout. Bready but also toast/roast flavor (not burnt, however). A mild milk chocolate flavor emerges as it departs, leaving a slightly bitter aftertaste. Red fruits linger as a background note. Clean fermentation. 18/20MOUTHFEEL: Medium body and carbonation. Texture is soft and smooth. Not refreshing per se but comfortable in the mouth. Aftertaste is fairly clean with slight bittersweet chocolate aftertaste (not astringent). 5/5OVERALL IMPRESSION: Pretty much a perfect beer for the style, albeit slightly Americanized. 10/10TOTAL SCORE: 46/50
Dark, almost opaque black with a cream colored head. Chocolaty aroma. Sweet flavor, a bit of smokiness. Smooth, creamy.

355 ml bottle. Black body but with brown highlights at the edges. Sudsy off-white head that subsides to a thin cap. Raisins, brown sugar, plum and a little chocolate on the nose. Soft fruit at first in the mouth before some cinnamon and coffee come through. Fairly clean finish with a slightly sweet aftertaste. Balanced and easy drinking.
@Whats brewing 10/16 - blind tasting round side by side with Black Lion of Löwenbrauerei Bräunlingen. Fruity, slight caramel-toffee. A lot of residual sweetness in taste. Smooth.

12oz bottles catered by JoeinDahlem, blind tasted against Bräunlinger Black Lion Schwarzbier during and post Whats Brewing 1516-2016. Especially in comparison with the Brasilian-inspired roast and chocolate malt forward Schwarzbier: Not really a Black Lager, maybe loosely inspired by late 19c Belgian brewers copying German/Bohemian recipes...? - Autumnal aromas, marmite on brown bread conjure up fallen foliage, some roasted chestnut sweetness announcing itself...more of that in taste, especially both the gentle sweetness and pronounced nutty bitterness of roasted unripe chestnut, late astringent nutty "sourness" and all. Coca Cola running in between somewhere...none of that expected fig jam or date paste though. A US cover of an extinct Belgian brewerys Dunkel idea of a Schwarzbier?
From a bottle. Roasted and chocolate malts. Pour is black with very small white/tan head.

Pours almost black, small head.
Nose shows cocoa, bready and toasty notes, some light fruity notes too.
Flavours include bready and toasty notes, nutty malt, some soft sweetness.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a nonic pint glass. The appearance shows a light tan creamy head. The color is dark brown. The aroma is caramel and figs. On the taste I get caramel, figs and chocolate. A delicious dark beer with friendly composition and a nice alternative in dark beer for novices and the seasoned.
Sample at SBWF 2016. Dark malty smell with chocolate. Similar taste. Deep malty flavour. Clean.
Bottle - dark pour with a red tinge in the light. Aroma is fruity, roast malt and chocolate. Sligyt sweetness up front mild malty finish.

Wound up with a few of these and was not excited about drinking them. I remember 1554 from earlier days as a bit bland. Drank a couple and realized how wrong I was. There is a naughty bit of residual sweetness here that really accentuates the chocolate in the malt, but thankfully it finishes just dry and bitter enough to want more gulps.Looking forward to getting to know it better.
Really, really nice beer. Balanced, not too hoppy but a really nice bold flavor.

On tap at St. Augustines during New Belgium 25th anniversary celebration. Pours a dark reddish copper with a white head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate. Taste roasted malt, dark fruits notes. Roasted malt, bready notes aftertaste. Very pleasant. Full-bodied, but easy drinkable.

One of my favorite beers of all time. I think that beers are largely unbalanced. This on the other hand is a perfectly balanced beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a very dark ruby red color, but not opaque. Nice two finger beige head. Okay retention, great lacing.Aroma is roasted malt. Light coffee, medium chocolate. Maybe a touch of licorice.Taste is malty, chocolatey, creamy. No noticeable hops, barely bitter. Maybe a touch of caramel.Mouthfeel is medium light. Clean, not bitter. Super easy to drink. A little creamy. Sessioinable and easy to drink. Smooth and mellow.Overall, this is delicious. A delight to drink. A good special occasion, or anytime beer. I would recommend this, and I will buy this again.
Deep dark color, little carb levels. Smooth malty taste, lasting palate. Good...

Bottle pour. Appearance is dark brown/mahogany with 1/2 finger-width light brown head with poor retention to ring. Aroma is toffee, light fruit. Taste is roasted malt with toffee, mild dark fruits, European hops. Palate is medium bodied with thin, creamy texture, average carbonation with fruity, toffee more sweet than bitter finish. Overall, a dark beer with a pretty light palate that still packs a decent amount of flavor.
12oz bottle - Pours rich dark brown with some red, white sudsy head. Coffee, chocolate, dark sweet fruit, roasted malt. Mild drinkable flavors of the same.

Decent flavor and feel for the style. Appears heavier on the malt than actually is. Flavors of mild chocolate, light hops, with a yeasty finish. Balance is ok, but borderline macrobrew feel. Something along the lines of a black and tan.

Draft. Pitch black with tan head. Aroma of aroma is roasted malts, light coffee, and light liqorice. Taste is similar with light roasted malts, chocolate, light roasted coffee and light liqorice as well as a soft bitterness in the finish. Medium mouthfeel, medium carbonation and slight roasted bitter aftertaste.
Draft - Cocoa and some toast. Jet brown with a nice beige head. Light cocoa and dark toffee malts. Cocoa is the dominating smell and taste which is odd for the style.

This is the by far one of the best beers I've ever tried. Very well balanced with smoky and very subtle chocolate notes. Looks fantastic and goes down very easy with no aftertaste . Highly recommend 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, best before 4/3/2016. Pours crystal clear dark reddish brown color with a 2 finger dense and rocky light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Nice dense soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, light cocoa/coffee, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt and light earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, light cocoa/coffee, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Light herbal/roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, light cocoa/coffee, and herbal/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and light earthy hop flavors; with a great roasted bitter/sweet balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light dryness from roasted character as well. Very clean on lager flavors with minimal yeast ester notes present. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready, and slightly chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice dark lager. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and light earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink.  This tastes like a cross between schwarzbier and dunkel lager styles. A very enjoyable offering.

Bottle from Antenna America.
Served in a lager glass it is a deep brown with red accents that verges on black and an impressively thick beige head. The aroma is soft cocoa, chewy breadiness and an enticing semi-spicy quality. Medium to full bodied with a chewy texture but a raspy carbonation.

The taste is very quaffable with a balanced roast edge merged with chewy chocolate buns. Malt forward, tasty and interesting. A surprise hit with me.
Oh hey, this is some fine, fine product. Aroma is roast malt, cocoa, coffee, ether. Flavors similar to nose with roast malt sweet tang up front, then a touch of bitter. Great body. Super drinkable.

Bottle. Dark brown body tan head. Very nice roasted and caramel malts and cocoaaroma . Taste is nearly the same but with some spices. Mouthfeel is a little bit thin. Aftertaste is roasted malts and some malty sweetness. Very nice black lager.

Bottle not sure I got this one. Pours dark brown almost black, with an inch of tan head. Smoked Peat, dried leaves in the nose. Taste is smoked chocolate, leaves, earth. Tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

First had this sometime around 1998/99 west of the Mississippi but now its made it to PA. Always found the profile pleasant. Dark brown/translucent with light tan head. Hint of roast and caramel nose. Caramel with burnt malt finish. Thinner palate, mild hop profile. Nice balance of malt (up front) and roasty finish. Maybe not as memorable as when I first found this but it still holds a nice place in my heart based on that early experience.

From bottle at BKL München 2016.
Dark brown body, with a medium, creamy, dark beige head.
Aroma of toast, cocoa, subtle coffee, dark bread, some dark fruits.
Tastes of toast, espresso, caramel, cocoa powder, milk chocolate, some dark fruits.
Medium, slick mouthfeel, with an average carbonation.
Finishes smooth, medium dry, toasty, with cocoa, caramel, coffee.

Tasty. Very smooth, with manifold dark malts and a great balance between sweet, roasty and dry. Outstanding, unique style example, propably the best Dunkel lager Ive had so far.
Rund malziger, etwas herber Beginn. Wässrig bitter, geringfügig herb rund. Spritzig, rund. 11/9/10/9/11/9

Impressive head. Chocolate malty. Light astringent nose but mild. A decent beer. Toasty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Really delicious dark beer with hints of Belgian dubbel/quad (at first) and American porter dryness(at the end) mixed together.

On tap at New Belgium hub DIA. Pours deep reddish brown / black, beige head. Aroma is prune, roasted malt, caramel, smoke, candied fruits. Flavor is sweet malt, candy, caramel, floral notes, light pine.

12oz can. Sweet, flowery aroma. Nearly-opaque rootbeer/black color with minimal head and persistent lacing. Strong malty and sweet flavor quickly dissipating to finish somewhat walnut and hazelnut, slighty bitter. Good with pie, not so ood with salty snacks. Will buy again.

This is actually a delightful malty brew. Pours a purely black body with a thick, frothy beige head. The nose is bready with a light toasted caramel malt. Sweet malty front with a light grassy hop and a mild toffee, hazelnut note. Finish is mild and lightly bitter with a great balance and a light floral note.
Bottle, deep brown beer, nice cream colored head, decent lace. Aroma malt, faint metal. Taste chocolate, dark fruit. Palate is light, carbonation about average. A touch sweet, but nice!

Poured from a bottle. Pours a dark mahogany to black with an off-white ring. Light roasted malt aroma with hints of yeast. Smooth, light malt flavor with a slightly dry finish. Not very interesting or refreshing. Ordinary. OK but not remarkable.
Roasted malts and cocoa aromas. Taste is cocoa, raoasted malts, faint caramel and figs, then a touch of earthy hops in the finish.
Has a nice chocolate malt aroma. Taste is a good slightly toasty malt with a nice chocolate aftertaste. Good.

12 oz can. It poured a dark brown with a two fingers of a tan head that quickly dissipated. The aroma was a roasted chocolate malt, while the flavor included dark chocolate, raisins, and some coffee. The mouth feel was moderately thick and creamy.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2016 Re rating:  So I bought a sixer of this and drank a couple.  Really didnt like it nearly as much as the first.  Flavor was too mild and watered down.  Decent but not worth buying

Really liked this one. Sort of like a Schwartzbier, sort of like a bock. Good aroma, mouthfeel and flavor. Winner!

12oz bottle from the new Folly pack.

3/4" lite tan head drops leaving some lacing and rings... dark brown..not black.. clear deep chestnut red when held to a light.

Aroma is fruity yeasty notes and chocolate dark roasted malts.. cold instant coffee.. no hops to speak of. As it warms, some earthy hop notes become evident.

Dark malts and dark dried fruit are the main flavor components.. with more coffee at the front.. Chocolate grains and restrained dried cherries and raisins.. Hops are more prevalent than the nose.. earthy hops mix well with the front-side palate.. more yeasty fruitiness .. not Belgian but not necessarily American..not sure.

Fun beer that I always overlook just because it is on the shelves.

12oz bottle, poured into a plastic cup. The aroma is malty caramel with a light spice, and a late-emerging fudge with nuts. The beer is oily and clear with a caramel hue and a sudsy, tan head that displays good sofy retention and good lace. The taste is medium sweet and a mild, medium light bitter. The texture is oily and smooth with a mild fuzz. The medium body has flavors of dark fruit followed by chocolate and caramel. It finishes crisp and spicy clean with a slightly roasted tone and flavors of fudge and nuts. The aftertaste is mellow and lightly bitter with a roasted coffee hint, chocolate, and a smokey dryness.
Bottle. Aroma is chocolate, nuts and brown sugar. Flavor is sweet but with enough hops to balance. The lager yeast is hard to discern, but the sweet nutty flavor is bold. A smooth sticky finish.

Draft at Moriartys. Dark brown pour with some khaki foam. Burnt chocolate malts. Unexpected large amount of spicy hops. Cold coffee. Roasted nuts. Cocoa nibs. Celery hearts. Poppyseeds. Balanced but feels lacking a clear direction. Hints at a Doppelbock but feels more like a mix of a Black IPA and a Porter.

Pours dark brown with nice head. Aroma of chocolate, dark malt, with a touch of coffee. Taste: very nicely balanced black lager with a clear character. I like to chocolate taste, which is however not too intense. Very good.
Nice dark brown color with slightly persistent head. Lasting semi sweet bread aroma. Malty taste of grain and bread with a medium mouthfeel. Faint carbonation.
Bottle at charles street, mariposa. Black color, tanned head. Aroma has roasty notes, chocolate and some malty sweetness. Taste has chocolate, burnt sugar, some coffee.
Smooth and balanced. Chocolate roasted malts and hops. Empty follow through, the beer simply disappears, a good sign of a good beer I say. Simple and sweet.
Robe brune avec des reflets cuivrés. Arômes de chocolat noir et café. Goût chocolat, fumé, fruits noirs, caramel, biscuit. Final fumé. Longue en bouche. Une bonne bière.

deep red with a quick off white head. Nose is roasty with a touch of brown sugar. flavor quickly shifts from roasted to a fairly generic sweetness and a dry finish. a little sticky but a very good example of the style
chocolate, resin, toffee, red, black, clear, minimal head, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, fizzy,
Not sure what isnt doign this for me, i guess there is a strange smokey flavor at the end that kind of takes over the malt flavor.

Black lager.   
こんがり香ば&

Pitch black in the glass. Espresso crema head... Or I want it to be:) it's exciting. Flavours of espresso & rye. Cereal grain on the nose. It's a terrific lager.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with an offwhite head.Some roasted malts on the nose. Nice, smooth black coffee, roasted grain, velvety mouthfeel. A nice brew.
Crisp lager with more malt backbone. Darker and chewier than standard lager, but still low bitterness and smooth mouthfeel.
Dark brown appearance. Chocolate toffee front with a slight caramel mix.  Not as good as I remembered.
Pours black, medium head. Aroma is toffee, cocoa, dark malts. Taste has some tang, then sweet malt, cocoa on the finish. Full mouthfeel.
My go to beer when I cant find a German my favorite from Collins. Pretty color
Drank from bottle after a long slog biking in moab. Good roasted flavours, dried fruits, Malty. Yummy.

12 ounce bottle. Deep mahogany color. Fluffy beige head. Light roasted malt nose has a hint of nuts and smoke. Sweet roasted malt flavor has spicy notes. Milk chocolate, cola, raisins, vanilla and herbal hops.

Bottle 35,5cl / Botella 35,5cl.
@ R & J Liquors, Granby, CO, USA
A: Dark brown / Marron oscuro.
T/S: Roasted malt, caramel, coffee, chocolate / Malta tostada, caramelo, cafe, chocolate.

355ml bottle in Brisbane. This one has big (lightly milky) chocolate malts on the nose and tongue with a medium smooth palate and sweet biscuity finish. Its all about the malts for this beer. Goes down easily with a lightish carbonation. Pours deep red-brown with a decent-sized foamy beige-coloured head.

Delicious! Possibly the best black lager I have tried. Goes well on a warm fall day into a cool fall night. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark with a tan head. Solid bitterness upfront gently washes away to chocolate sweetness. Medium body with light carbonation.

355ml bottle. Pours a clear mahogany with a medium, short lived, beige head that laces. Roasted malt aroma with dark chocolate. Sweet flavour of roasted malt and dark chocolate with a dry, coffee finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Smooth and very drinkable.

Originally rated on 1/10/08. Pours a nice very dark brown/ black body, the taste was a little toasty, with subtle hints of chocolate. Smooth and a little sweet,it is a little watery though. it still is a really good beer.
draft - nose is caramel and bread. sweetish. Not much to this but I wouldnt mind drinking a liter of this.

A roasty caramel aroma with a hint of coffee. Totally dark as a black lager should be. Minimal head. Heavy, coffee-ish taste with a hint of chocolate perhaps. While not at the top of its class, (Shiner Black Lager out-does it) it is nevertheless worth a quaff.
12 oz.bottle into pint glass. Pours dark brown. Roast malt and coffee aroma and taste. Less bitter than expected.

Bottle into tulip. Dark ruby almost black w decent head that does not last. Caramel malty aroma. Biscuits and grass. Dry to almost tart. Effervescent. Hints of yeast/Vegemite. Decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark Brown in color with a medium head. Aroma is light malty sweetness but kind of weak. Taste is also a tad weak. Actually for a mega brewery beer its not bad.

EBD 8/9/15. Pours an almost pitch black. Outstanding head volume, lacing and retention.

Mild nose of roast, chocolate and herbal hops.

Light medium body with a smooth texture. Normal carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and a finish that attempts to be prickly.

Very good flavor profile that is medium in intensity, not complex but is well balanced. It begins with a mild blend of roast and chocolate. The middle brings a bit of hop flavor (herbal) and mild bitterness. As the bitterness fades, a biscuit sweetness emerges to balance. The slow fade finish yields a bakers chocolate note.
Pours a dark red brown color with khaki head. Smooth. Chocolate and coffee flavors and aromas

뉴 벨지움 브루어리 - 1554 블랙 라거 5.6% ABV 

다크 초컬릿 풍미의 맥아를 사용한 벨기에의 블랙 라거의 복각. 1997년 홍수로 유실된 맥주 레시피를 벨기에까지 가서 조사하여 복각 시킨 블랙 라거 

 구수한 곡물향에 입안에서 넓게 퍼지는 커피향 전국구 브루어리들은 다 평타는 치는데 기대이상의 맛은 없다 in Albuquerque

https://twitter.com/MaekJuBot
Poured a medium brown with a beige head. Atoms of light roast, grass, and mild chocolate. Flavor was similar, nothing amazing but a very clean and.tasty dark lager.

Deep brown pour, tan head, a bit of lacing. Nose is dark malts, shadow of dried fruit. Leaning sweet, but earthy. Middle shows smooth dark malt, hint of coco, some spice lurking. Medium bodied. Finish dries somewhat, leaving the earthy/coco flavor in command. Good.

ANITHER HEAVY LAGER, BUT THATS OK. ,MANY PEOPLE ARE SCARED TO DRINKS LAGERS. ITS NO PLINY (TOP BEERS IN THE EARTH SEVEN YEARS IN AROW) IMAGINNE THE PEOPLE TRY DRINK REAL PLINY (MY FAVERITE$ EHEHEHEHEHEH 1454 IS HEAVY LAGER WHAT TASTE LIKE FRUITS AND A LITTEL SPICE. PRETTY GOOD MY SUGESSTON IS MORE HOPS. I LIKE IT.
Very nutty in taste, light malts/nuts in aroma. decent carbonation and lacing. Black/dark brown in color,
12 FL OZ ($9.99 6 pack) pretty good dark beer. has enough ABV to qualify as an actual beer so its got that. taste is smokey and has good suds.

Pours dark chocolate color. Decent head. Taste of caramel and chocolate, very nice malt. Did not taste many black lagers before so this one is a nice surprise. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This was a good beer it was smooth and allowed me to enjoy the beer without all the hops that tend to overpower. I like to drink multiples of this beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I think my first black lager I ever had. Kinda blew my mind a little bit. Very delicious beverage, light with just the right amount of dark malts to make it interesting.

12 oz pour from refrigerated bottle into a shaker pint. Pours an attractive off-white one-finger head with moderate retention and lacing. Dark-brown to black and nearly opaque. Nose is milk chocolate and malt. Medium bodied and creamy. Really well done body. Taste is a little roasty, some chocolate, a light candy sweetness. Very little bitterness. A hint of dryness. Well balanced. A very drinkable beer.

On tap, at Willies in Navy Yard. Draft, pint glass. Appearance is deep brown with a small amount of tan head. Aroma is milk chocolate and light caramel, roasted but not bitter malt. Taste is chocolate with mild toffee notes. Palate is moderately carbonated. Very smooth.

Dragged this back with me from Las Vegas. 12oz bottle, enjoy by 07jun15. Pours coffee black with a beige head that falls quickly. Aroma is dark dried fruits, caramel and chocolate. Flavor follows... raisin, date, caramel and chocolate. Mild carbonation and a hint of mineral in the finish makes this just shy of cloying.
Strong coffee and chocolate notes in the taste, and aroma sits really well on the palate well balanced.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2015 Pours into glass a dark glass brown with tan head and lace. Aroma is light coffee and chocolate with a roasted malt. Taste was malt heavy with chocolate in the background. Slightly malty and coffee in the finish. Enjoyed.
Old rating. Dark brown pour. Roasted malts, some caramel, slightly charred, chocolate, oats, spice, mild bitterness. Nice beer.

Bottle - 355ml. Opaque black body with an average beige foamy head. Lovelu malty/hoppy aroma with chocolate and roasty hints. Its well balanced malty taste carries roasted cereals, woody and chocolate notes. Ends with a robust bitter/roasty finish. Well done.
Bottle to a pint. Deep mahogany pour with ample foamy tan head. Toasted malt nose. Fresh bread, cocoa and dark roast coffee beans... Tasty and easy to drink...

1554 definitely looks like a beer should, with gorgeous layered lacing, a huge foamy tan head, and a gorgeous, nearly opaque dark reddish brown hue with notes of crimson when held to the light. Aroma is sweet and fruity with roasted malt and dark chocolate. The flavor delivers smoky roasted malt and tobacco, with a bit of dark chocolate and nuttiness. Also a little bit of bitter hops and a light but noticeable alcohol warmth. Sparkly, moderate carbonation; a pleasant light and creamy mouthfeel. A solid year-rounder from NB.
Bottle from SJ. Some nice notes of roasted malts, bread, chocolate and burnt malts. Body was thin, but overall not a bad representation of the style.
Pretty good very mild coffee, some caramel. Enjoyed the crisp clean lager characteristic. Not a huge fan of this style but this one is better than most.

12 oz bottle pours dark brown and barely translucent. Big off white foam head. Hints of oats, chocolate and coffee aromas. Taste is creamy, roasted malts and slightly nutty. Smooth and balanced finish. Good brew.
Poured a dark brown color with a lot of malt rye and yeast flavors. Dry and medium finish.

12oz bottle poured to pint glass. Nice thin off white persistent head moderate lacing. Smells of toasty malt and faint coffee. Rich deep mahogany color. Mild coffee taste, sweet malty backbone and mild yeast flavor. Nice flavors and a dry finish. The best of both worlds easy drinking like a lager and nice flavors of a darker porter. Cheers!

Tasted from draft. Pours a dark brown with slight ruby color. Off white head with good lacing. Aroma is sweet, mostly caramel. Taste is nice clean toasty lager. Very smooth. Flavors of nuts, caramel, toffee and slight chocolate flavor. Medium sweetness with minimal to no detectable bitterness. Definitely a top tier dark lager.

Rich and frothy with a wonderfully sweet aroma tinged with malt. Taste is full bodied with a lightness permeated with strong malt notes.

12 oz to glass, clear darkish brown with a small off white rapidly diminishing head.Slight malt aroma,medium body with average carbonation, and a rather abrupt finish.Medium sweet but just missing the mark on flavor. Not a bad beer, just not a really good Black Lager.

On tap at world of beer, Jacksonville. Pours dark teddy brown with an off white head. Hint of sweet malt in the aroma. Not much else. Medium body, medium carbonation. Some sweet dark fruit, lemon... Pretty dull really.

Pours blackish red with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts and some chocolate. Taste is much the same; simple and refined. Subtle noble hop finish at the end. Not a super complex beer, but excellent for casual drinking with dinner.
Pours black with a large white head. Aroma is sweet and tiny bit roasted. Very smooth mouthfeel. Taste is a balance of sweetness and roastyish bitter flavors. very drinkable.

on tap @ River City / Jacksonville FL --- Clear brown color, 1" beige head, sheets of lace. Aroma of malt. Taste is rich caramel malt that grows lightly into a smooth palate, turning just a little bitter (bringing things back toward balance) in the finish. A solid, tasty brew.
Pours a clear dark brown with light tan head. Aroma is sweet fruit, plum or fig. Sweet taste is very drinkable, nice black lager, not bitter.
12 oz. can from Folly craft 12 pack. Very smooth. I like the slight hop. Nice indeed.

High rating. Excellent brew. Not overdone no overkill. Smell dark roast and chocolate. Some cocoa in the taste nuts as well dark roast as well. Chewy mouth feel. Reminds me of a good Midwest bock. Nice body slightly bitter finish. Easy drinking smooth
 Wow best beer Ive had in a while.

From site: Born of a flood and centuries-old Belgian text, 1554 Black Lager uses a lager yeast strain and dark chocolaty malts to redefine what dark beer can be. In 1997, a Fort Collins flood destroyed the original recipe our researcher, Phil Benstein, found in the library. So Phil and brewmaster, Peter Bouckaert, traveled to Belgium to retrieve this unique style lost to the ages. Their first challenge was deciphering antiquated script and outdated units of measurement, but trial and error (and many months of in-house sampling) culminated in 1554, a highly quaffable dark beer with a moderate body and mouthfeel

Simple clean black lager. Chocolate. Dry finish.

Dark lager.
Spicy flavors. Well balanced beer! Loved it!

Twelve ounce bottle purchased as part of a mix six pack purchased at
Delhi Walgreens. Very dark brown/mahogany color, assertive malty nose with lots of chocolate. Flavor like the aroma not as strong as the nose advertised. Not bad. This is one of those beers I wish I could go into the hundredths for--Id give it a 3.25--but Ill give it the benefit of the doubt and round it up to 3.3. Tasted on July 4, 2014.
Chocolate resin and caramel on the nose. Black as night with glimmer of red around thinner sections of the glass. Very smooth and sweet taste with a momentary bitter. Easy drinking enjoyable.

Best by date: 03.23.14.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a wine glass on 12.23.13.

A: Opaque black. Some red can be seen at the bottom of the wine glass. No head.

S: Malty, roasty chocolate. Delicious.

T: Roasty oak woodiness, sweet chocolate. Dark berry follows.

M: Smooth.

O: Its an ale. Its a lager. Its an alager...or maybe lagale. Despite how New Belgium defines it from moment to moment, its good.
12 ounce can purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $8.99/6-pack Very good.

Nice aroma of dark malts, with perhaps a hint of chocolate. Through halogen the color is deep ruby red; otherwise black. A tan head that dissipates rather quickly. Substantial mouthfeel, hint of sour, which could be the acidity. There is a toasted malt aspect, but in the end there is a very light bitter. Quite nice. Relatively dry.
Draught sample. Reddish brown pour. Aroma of faint bitter chocolate and nuts. Medium bodied, very smooth finish.

Mild roasted aroma, pours a clear ruby red with a thin off-white head. Mild chocolate and roasted notes, fading to a short roasted finish. Light bodied, and really easy drinking. Most of the complexity comes from the malts, with just a small hint of hop characteristics. This is one you could sit and drink all day.
This beer was the one that started me on a path to better craft beer. Dark, sweet, and a hint of smokiness.
Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, sweet, very easy drinking. Feels light in the mouth and overall is an enjoyable beer.

12oz bottle from Ptaz! Thanks bro! Pours a dark brown color with ruby red highlights and a finger of frothy tan head. Aroma of lightly roasted coffee, cocoa powder, toasted nuts, and whole wheat bread. Taste of bitter weak day old coffee, earth, nuts, caramel, and whole wheat bread.

12 ounce bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a clear brown with a beige head of foam. Good retention. The aroma is roasty and nutty, good malt presence. The taste is delicate nutty notes with mild sweetness. Medium to high carbonation. Light to medium body. Pretty enjoyable.

355 ml can as New Belgium 1554 Black Lager. Clear deeper copper, finer lasting tan foam. Darker c-malt nutty chocolate aroma. Taste is roasty toasty malty caramel, milk chocolate, nutty, faint Noble influence. Average carbonation, medium bodied. Very nice. MLF (More Lagerboy Friendly)
6-pack from Giant, served in tulip glass. Very dark brown, faint malt nose, minimal head from light carbonation. Mildly bitter taste and nice clean finish.

Bottle, thanks in-laws! Nice dark brown with foamy head - looks great. Toasty malt aroma. Really nice chocolaty malt taste. Medium to light silky body. Clean. Bursting with flavour. This is one the best dunkle type beers I have ever had, well done.
Pours dark brown almost black with a smallish tan head. Aroma is earthy, biscuity. Taste is malt with hint of coffee. Smooth finish with ever so slight hop presence. Pretty good beer.
Excellent beer, great taste, surprisingly smooth. I liked it so much at the bar, I went to the store and bought some to take home.
Pours dark with an off-white head. Aroma is malt, chocolate, roasty and lightly sweet. Taste is light to medium sweet leading to a dry roasty finish. Decent.

12oz bottle --> snifter. Dark brown. Not too heady. Smells like roasted malts and raisins. Tastes chocolate-y and malty with the smoothness of a fine whiskey. None of the typical lager skunkiness. Drinks dry, smooth and clean like a good stout.

dark brown, almost black, with a thin off-white head. aroma is bread, coffee, and toast. flavor is toasty bread, with some cocoa and coffee.

12 oz bottle. Aroma: roasty and malty, with hints of toffee, dates, vanilla, and leather. Taste/Palate: starts sweet and crisp, and finishes creamy and slightly dry and astringent. One of my favorites from that brewery!

Poured from a 12. Color is dark, looks very inviting! Flavor has a nice maltiness to it. Yet fairly smooth with just a slight astringent feel on the tip of my tongue. Finish is slightly sweet and velvety. Great beer!

"looks and tastes more like a robust brown, porter, or most closely-a black lager. full flavored, but not overpowering on the belgian yeast strain. just a hint of spice in there with all the roasted malty flavors. good beer."

12 oz bottle at home. Pours with just a few bubbles, moderate lacing. Gorgeous dark color; hints of deep burgundy and caramel dominate. Aroma is somewhat faint, but lager-like. Overall very nice for the style. Normally Im not into New Belgium but I really enjoyed this one.

Poured from a 12oz bottle tasted of chocolate and caramel...a thicker and more refined taste than the Shiner

Aroma is a breadiness, dark roasted malts and slight fragrant hops. Taste is a very well balanced malt/hop profile. Malts are sweet and roasty yet finishes very smoothly. Light hints of toffee and dark chocolate and coffee. Appearance is a clear dark amber with a thin pearl head that retains fairly poorly.

Bottle from QClub at Justin's bday. Surprisingly chocolatey aroma and taste while still being light and crisp. Better than expected, would get again.

Dark brown appearance with a large, off white head and good lacing. Toasted malt aroma of nuts, licorice and toffee. Transfer from BA review on 5-25-13-
 
 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance- The brew pours a deep brown color with ruby highlights shining throughout. Upon pouring there is a one finger tan head that fades slowly over time to leave persistent foam on the top of the brew.

 Smell- The aroma has a nice roasty malt aroma mixed with notes of an earthy hop. There are nice smells of chocolate and coffee as well as a caramel smell giving it an overall sweet and toasty smell.

 Taste  The taste begins with sweet caramel and some sweeter chocolate flavors. While sweet, there is some more roastier flavors with some bready notes as well. Some nut flavors come to the tongue along with flavors of dark fruit. More toward the end some lightly bitter flavors of coffee and an earthy hop come to the tongue leaving a moderately sweet and smoother roasted more porter like flavor is left on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the brew is on the thicker and creamier side with a medium to slightly lighter carbonation level. The creamier body and lighter carbonation are great for the sweeter and roasted more porter like flavors of the brew allowing them to fully sink into and be sensed by the tongue.

 Overall  A rather tasty brew. A little on the sweeter porter like side but still quite drinkable and refreshing.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2014 (Bottle) On paper everything seems fine with this beer. But it really lacks any kind of personality. In the end, its by no means bad (in fact its quite drinkable), but its also a pretty simple and forgettable beer.

Slight notes of chocolate...not much else. Nice ebony color with a tan head that is thick. Sweet, roasted malt up front. Hints of bitter chocolate, and smokey molases. Finishes dry and sweet with a hint of bitterness. Nice beer.

Bottle: Very dark brown, hints of ruby with a lasting, creamy tan head. Moderate lacing. Aroma of toasted caramel malts, mild grape sweetness, bread, yeast, a touch of roasted grains. Flavor exhibits a mild vinous character; grape skins & mild alcohol. Notes of toasted bread, dry caramel malt, cocoa dust, a bit of unsweet chocolate in the finish. Notable hopping with a leafy & ashy character, slight bitterness. Faint clove in the aftertaste, Belgian yeast esters coming alive. Not bad for what it is, blurring the style guidelines a bit.

Pours a very dark brown with a light tan one and a half inch head that leaves a nice lace. Dissipates fairly quickly. Nice roasted chocolate flavor as well as aroma. Good lager with good smoky character.

Great full flavored lager that has an incredible malty kick to it. The smell is as amazing as the taste.

text: 12oz bottle, roasted malt aroma, tan head. Flavors has some stout characteristics, not nearly as heavy and without the bit of a stout. Clean qualities as well. A little heavier than a lager, fits dunkel character. Definitely worth the try!!

Pours black with hints of chestnut and a yeasty, lacing tan head that fades to a chunky coating. Aroma is nuts, earthy chocolate malts and mild darkfruit. Taste is a bit thin, short and syrupy. Flavor, however, is very pleasant. Roasted toffee, raisins and a hint of noble hops to finish. Mild carbonation and an active mouthfeel. Overall tone is sweet with some roast and some bitter out back. Very drinkable and even a bit stout-like.

355mL bottle BB JUL14
Pours an attractive deep garnet body, a bit of clarity to it. A dense off-white foam holds, leaving clumpy lace in its wake.
Good intensity of aroma; dark grain bread, burnt toast, brown caramel, hint of almost clove-like spice.
Nice smooth carbonation, has a creaminess about it bolstered by a good amount of body; certainly more than expected with a beer of this strength.
Palate follows on with more notes of bitter chocolate, cola, burnt caramel, dense breads, savoury spice and a hint of coffee grinds. Dry finish, moderately low bitterness.
Very well made, very tasty, very drinkable. Certainly a good sort of "gateway" dark beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark black with a thin off white head. Aroma of chocolate malt. Tastes like a porter but a lot lighter in the palate and stomach.

text: Bottle to pint. Looks good for the style; cola with thin off-white head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells of dark malt, chocolate, and lager yeast. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Solid beer.

Pours a deep mahogany color with a small head and bits of lacing. Aroma of dark fruit and malt, with some chocolate in the background. Taste of malt, dark fruit, with a bit of citrus and chocolate giving the it a mild sweetness. Light bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body, smooth and clean. Nice take on an old recipe. Nice beer that goes down easy.

Straight from the bottle so Im not sure about the head, flavor is very intriguing though. some nuttiness with some coffee, caramel malt as well with a hint of banana on the nose. really nice overall, though Im not sure I would want more than one in a row.
Not sure this is an ale at all. Tastes like a dark lager and says black lager on the bottle. Shwartzbier? Good beer to have in a mixed pack but i wouldnt want this too often. Unique though...
Their best brew by far. So completely different from fat tire for which I am very thankful for. A good standby stout!

Coffee-like roasted, subtle banana yeast aroma. Sweet, coffee/chocolate malt flavor; a little fruity, subtle raisin-y flavor, and New Belgiums yeast character. Kind of bitter in aftertaste--but its offset with some sweetness.

12oz bottle, purchased from Crown Liquors in downtown Indianapolis several months ago. Best by date is 06-Jan-2014. Dark brown color. Good half-inch thin khaki head. Good retention. Leaves good thicker lace, nice full reaches. Medium body. Smooth, lighter carbonation, kind of soft, and slick texture. Light bitter, light spice, moderate sweet taste. Some dark fruit, syrupy aroma, caramel. Some milk chocolate. OK dark ale... A little light and sweet for me though.
dark but not deep,,,,, caramel, hay, cereal, chocolate, nuts, coffee, roasty, grass, red, brown, black, clear, minimal head, tan foam, light sweetness, medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation,

12oz bottle poured a medium brown with off white head. Nice lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, some chocolate possibly some caramel. Mild bodied beer the flavor is complex enough. Nice malt flavors mixed with the chocolate. Overall pretty decent for black ale. Not really any hop character.
A nice smooth black ale that ends with just a hint of chocolate flavors. This will be enjoyed.

On tap at Red Robin. Appearance: deep brown color, clear small head, ok lacing. Aroma: roast coffee, hazelnut, bread, caramel, Palate: relatively full body, smooth texture, average carbonation, Taste: sweet throughout with a light chocolate bitterness at the finish. Overall, always a smooth beer and something you can sit down with a six-pack of easily.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2015 A great ale with a great story. This black ale has notes of toasted barley and subtle chocolate all the way through. Its wonderfully complex and surprisingly refreshing. Theres always an undeniable novelty that goes with drinking an old-style ale. 1554 takes that novelty and turns in into a bona fide excellent beer experience.

Reviewed 06/27/10

Poured from bottle to New Belgium tulip.

A: Deep cherry red/mahogany ale with excellent clarity. few thin ribbons ascend to replenish glossy, light tan sheet over top ale.

S: nutty, roasted barley nose. Very slight earthy hop.

T: tastes a hint astringent. Reminds me of a burnt, sour porter.

M: Med body, low carb. Slightly sticky.

D: I have no desire to drink this beer again. I can, however, see why it appeals to a larger micro drinking market. Falls into the dark beer category for many folks.

Serving type: bottle

12-20-2010
Delicious dark Belgian style ale with smooth lightly toasted barley flavor & a dry finish

This is a good one. Kind of tastes like a porter. Pours very dark. Its bitter at first but goes down so smooth. Got this in a sample pack at a local liquor store and I was impressed by this one the most.
One of my favorite beers, really easy to drink with so much flavor, there are dark malts, dark fruit as well as some sweet notes maybe from a bit of light chocolate.

A: Very roasty. Smells like a porter. Citrus lemon or something in the back. 
A: Looks good, Head retention is alright. Color is dark brown clear reddish.
T: Tastes like porter meets lager (dare I say baltic porter) Nah, more acid citrus note. A little thin and light. Watery. A bit malty.
P: Very light on the palate. Some decent flavors. 

This is a pretty solid beer. Nice roasty note balances well with the maltyness. A solid everyday beer.

FROM NOTES: October 18, 13. Poured from a bottle into a chalice. 

A: Caramel malts, dark fruits (dates, plums) and a light grassy hop note. 
A: Pours a deep, dark brown with a light tan, finger width head.
T: Toasted caramel, roasted coffee, chocolate malts.
P: Thin but nice, low carbonation.
O: Solid Belgian dark ale. Not outstanding but pretty darn good.
Bottle. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, roasted malt. Taste is well balanced and a bit sweet. Very nice!
Dark reddish brown pour. Nice malty smell. Has a very light crispy roasted malt taste, but still has a lot of flavor. Can also taste some caramel and plum.

12 oz bottle: Aroma has got a nice malt characteristic with a bit of plum notes as well, a bit of roasted and toasted notes too. Appearance is a dark black color with a thick slightly tan head. Taste has got a nice full malt backing with a roasted caramel characteristic. Palate has got a nice malty note. Overall, good stuff. Cheers!

12oz bottle. Pours soda brown with a large tan head that leaves plenty of lacing. Malty aroma and taste of chocolate, toffee, roasted malts, hints of coffee and earthy hops. Sweeter than expected, reminiscent of a sweet stout. Great slight hop bitterness, cream and toasty malt in the finish. Medium to full bodied, creamy but slightly thin texture, low carbonation. Very easy drinker. Excellent and very enjoyable!

2013 bottle to a tulip glass. Pours a very dark garnet brown with a fizzy tan head and moderate lacing. Aroma is a mild roasted malt with some chocolate and dark fruit. Taste is roasted malt, some coffee, chocolate. Well carbonated thin-medium mouthfeel with a bit of a sting. Reminded me of a brown ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good mild black ale. Poured from a tap, a dark dark red with a white head and a lot of lacing. Nearly no hops, almost entirely roasted, coffee, and dark tastes with a bit of sweetness. Despite the taste, not all that heavy to drink, theres a thinness to the overall finish that is altogether pleasant but unexpected. Its actually a relatively good black ale.

Rated oin 5-11-2009 (Bottle with Best Before: 18Sep09 on the label) This beer pours a medium sized, very fizzy beige head that mostly diminished, transparent reddish brown body, fair amount of lacing, fizzy, and fast rising carbonation. The Aroma is malty, chocolate, roasty, and sweet. The Taste is sweet, malty, chocolate, and has a dry finish. The Palate is smooth, thin and this beer is light-medium bodied. In conclusion, this beer is very quaffable, a session beer, worth trying, and a beer I would drink again.
Pours a black color with off white head. Roasty, charred wood, malty aromas. Malty, roasty, fruity flavors. Lighter bodied for a dark malty beer. I could knock back a bunch of these. Very Good.
UPDATED: OCT 13, 2013 Main go-to dark beers thats easy to drink but packs ton of flavor and depth. One of the few new Belgium beers I drink and welcome regularly. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A superior medium-bodied brew from New Belgium. Pours a very dark blackish burgundy. On first taste this struck me as being incredibly balanced compared to most of the beers Ive recently triedthe taste is practically perfect in its own way. Hints of dry chocolate and a preponderance of malt. At its modest price, this refined yet sessionable ale is one I would recommend for nearly any occasion. Respect the 1554.

PS I saw one reviewer compare this to Killians Stout.  This is superior.

Dark brown pour large beige head medium carbonation aromas caramel nuts grain the flavours chocolate caramel oily grain the finish interesting ale cereal like notes good malt tastes earthy ale goes down well
On draft at Half Moon, Phoenix. Flavors of breadiness, dark fruit, raisins, chocolate, porter, roasted malts. Medium bodied. Nice.

Bread and chocolate in the aroma. Pours a near black color with a beige head with good lacing. Good mouthfeel, creamy, touches of roast, chocolate bread, clean finish with a touch of fruit, good stuff
A very dark beer, with a medium head. The aroma is malty. The malt slightly dominates the hops, and the caramelized malt is of medium body and strength. Good taste, but not exciting.

This reminded me a little of a schwarzbier. Slight woody and roasted aroma. Nice dark color with a good head. The palate was too light and watery for my taste. Good carbonation though. Mix of flavors with some roasted malts, not much in the way of hops but more wood and a little spice. Seemed very German to me.

On draft at 2013 Tour de Fat in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco. New Belgium Brewery puts on this fundraiser every year to benefit the SF Bicycle Coalition and Bay Trails. New Belgium donates the beer and we enjoy a day of music, fun, and sun in GG Park. I agree with others description of 1554 ale as tasting like a porter. While this is not one of my favorite styles, New Belgiums version of a porter is better than average.
pours near black with off-white head. aroma of toasted malt, bread, hay. tastes of yeast, bread, chocolate and coffee. palate is too carbonated.
Roasty and toasty malt with a hint of cocoa, Very smooth, full bodied, leading to a long and satisfying finish. Very good.
Chocolate with a little coffee. Sweet toasty malt. Very much reminds me of Killians Stout.

Black. Hint of choc but mainly coffee but not hard grain. More like the roast of the beans. Not a bad beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown pour with a thick mocha head. Aroma is chocolatey, coffee, yeasty, bready. Flavor is very chocolatey too. Mild roast. Some raisin. Sweet bready finish. 

---Rated via iPhone
It may be true to style, but its much too sweet for me--almost treacly sweet. Cut down the sweetness, and the flavor would be superb--a nice dark, brown ale with a slightly bitter finish.

Bottle: Poured black with foamy head. Smell is toasted chocolate. I was surprised by how heavy the beer is. Literally it feels heavy in the glass and it is thick is my mouth. Most black ales I have tried are much thinner than this one is. It feels thick and heavy in my mouth but washes away like water. The taste is a little chocolate with a little roasty aftertaste to it. Overall a really nice beer even though the taste could use some help.
January 2012. From bottle. Poured dark brown with a tan head. Caramel, roasted malt, dark fruit and yeast aromas. Good balance and complexity.
Tasty ale...like a thinner version of a porter. Sweet malt aroma. Taste is cocoa, dark chocolate fruit, and some coffee or malt. Yum.
Bottle->shaker. Dark brown with foamy offehite head. A: roasted malt, nuts, hint of chocolate. T: cocoa, malt, some dark fruit and coffee. OK, but nothing special.
Pours thin and dark with little head. Aroma is toasty with a bit of chocolate maybe. Taste is light and sweet.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. There are some chocolate and nutty notes. A slight fruity character that works well with the malts. The body is a bit thin.
After so many misses this is the kind of beer new Belgium should make. Nice toasted malts and good depth. Just stop making the other crap like shift
Poured from a cold bottle. Dark drown color almost black, small off white head. Roasted malt smells. Light smooth roasted malt flavor. Nice beer
I really like this beer. Its a great cheap six pack that you can find at bottle shops. Nice, refreshing, dark ale.
Chocolate aroma. Chocolate notes. Full malty body. Nicely balanced by hops...not too bitter.

Appearance was clear reddish black with creamy tannish tiny diminishing head, spotty lacing. Aromas are chocolate, deep fruits, hints of coffee, toffee and grains of paradise. Taste are soft cocoa, coffee, leather, fig,spicey malts with earthy hops, no alcohol. Palate was soft smooth CO2 wih medium body, earthy lasting spicey smooth finish.
