Good attempt at ...? similar to many European styles, flavorful, but not overpowering...dunkel? porter? retty good.

A very malty ale. Not terribly bitter or hoppy. Smells very malty. Has a slight fruity taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark brown. Nice malty flavor with some funk from the yeast. Had numbers of times over the years.

Bottle. Solid chocolatey, roasty ale. Slightly thin. Overall pretty tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: This beer offers little for aroma. Very little of the hop aroma comes through although a great deal of the malts do offering a subtle carmel/roasty notes.

Apperance: The beer is brow but not opaque it pours with a good tan head

Taste. Despite being a Brown Ale this has a fairly light feel to it. Much of flavor comes from the malts which offer a Chocalatey/Malty flavor to it. 

Palate: The beer has a very smooth medium mouth feel. While not a sessionable beer it does drink very easily. 

Overall: My Favorite Brown Ale Ive tried so far. Although Im not a huge fan of the style I can see myself buying this beer plenty more times.
Smooth, roasted coffee and chocolate flavor. Poors with almost no head. Improves as it warms up.
On draft. Nice color suggests robustness to come, but the beer disappoints with thin, watery taste.

16 oz draft at Catalina BBQ Company in Tucson. Pours very dark brown with beige head. Aroma is dark fruits and chocolate. Taste is moderate- dark fruits, caramel, chocolate. Medium bodied. Smooth finish. One of the few New Belgiums that I like.
Dark pour with a nose of dark fruits. Taste is a little sweet with a hop/dark fruit. Different kind of beer. Not bad.
Tap. Dark with tan head. Hints of chocolate and malt. Chocolate aftertaste. A good light bodied beer.

NB 1554 is one of the blessings of modern life. I originally bought 1 bottle, not knowing what to expect from its dark appearance. It has none of the overpowering nature present in some dark beers, but instead possesses a gentle, drinkable nature. Its kind of like an ultra-dark amber lager, and I now buy it by the case (when I can find it).
Picked up a couple bottles as part of a pick six at the local store, now I know that I can go a head and get a full six pack. Tasted like a light stout, very enjoyable complex flavor profile.

Bottle at local pizza place in Greeley. Pours a dark brown with an off-white head. No real lacing. Aroma has figs, light chocolate and some earthiness. Taste is of chocolate, nuts, dark fruits, a hint of belgian yeast and some caramel. Medium bodied. Finishes fairly short and dry with nice woody sweetness. Interesting and subtly tasty.

Very dark brown pour, small tan head.
Chocolaty roasty-sweet aroma.
Creamy chocolate flavor like a milk stout
Light bodied for such a chocolaty beer!
Black, beige fluffy head. Aroma of toasty malt with a little caramel, chocolate and a clean roastiness. Flavor similar with some dry bakers chocolate and a roasty finish.

Bottle, 7C. Deep brown with a beige head. Aroma of bread, chocolate, plums, mace. Medioum bodied. Taste is only a little sweet with nice chocolate, gentle toasty/ roasty malt, hints of dark fruit. Gently spiced finish. Quaffable, interesting, balanced.

A whole basket full of contradictions -- all worth examining over and over to get to the bottom of whatever the questions were when we started. Looks heavy, goes down lightly. Smells chocolatey-malty, has a bitter finish. I could go on but that would only delay my next swallow.

Color is black as promised with about 1/2 inch of beige head.

An almost lager nose with apparent roastiness (almost burnt character), chocolate, and malty sweetness. Taste is the same.. Reminds me of a doppelbock. Body is full without lingering aftertaste.

I liked it, but Id rather have a stout or a doppelbock. This beer was somewhere in between

Pours dark brown with a full tan head. Malty, chocolaty aroma also with some dark fruit and toasted malt. Light lager style sweetness with addition of some toasted malt. Nice toasted malt, cocoa, lightly smokey finish. Medium bodied, thin palate with soft carbonation.

12 oz bottle. Appearance liquorice black and red. Thin, off-white head w good lacing. Aroma roasted w slight lager sulphur. Flavour roasted, dry, astringent, w long finish of dark choc, liquorice and roasted malt. Mouthfeel highly carbonated, quite thin, refreshing, and brief. Overall a drinkable, dark, summer staple.
This is actually a Lager, not an ale. For a great dark lager, this historic beer is well balanced. Great color and flavor, good mouth feel and retro nasal. Malty sweet, and toasty.

From a bottle. S - toasted malts, and sweet malts lead the aroma. Coffee grounds, molasses, a d raw cacao. M - strong carb. Light medium body. Weak palate. T - weak palate follows the nose. O - Simple sweet black ale. 3
Classic dark Belgian ale. Bitterness is medium to low. Mouthfeel is medium. Flavor of roasted malts. Easy to drink. Nice.

Appearance: very deep amber color, almost black, has a smaller dark tan head that fades quickly

Aroma: chocolate, wheat, coffee, 

Taste: coffee, wheat, 

Palate: highly carbonated, leaves a bit of a coffee aftertaste

Overall: not very complex to me, coffee overpowers the taste buds and that's the main taste I'm getting, still it's not so potent that it's undrinkable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Some nice chocolate and dried fruit up front. Tastes lighter than it looks, with a little too much sweetness for that amount of body. It definitely comes off as more ale than lager. A good intro to dark beer for the uninitiated, but not really anything special.
Bottle. Pours opaque brown with light brown head. Aroma of spices. Taste of chocolate and roasted malts.
Pours black with a tan head. Smells of smoke/roasted malt, chocolate and dark fruit. Taste upfront is  roasted malt, a little bitter hop followed by sweet fruit and a chocolate finish.
Very simple beer. chocolatey notes. tasty liked it. you can taste the belgium yeast profile nicely.

Great balance.  Mild to the nose.   Not too sweet, yet very smooth and easy to drink.  Nice blend of flavors with a nice Smokey and woody finish.  Very little taste of alcohol and minimal hop presence.  I can easily enjoy several of these in a sitting.  My favorite from this brewer.

Poured a deep dark brown with a slight head which disappeared quickly.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Taste was a smooth coffee with a touch of grape and a thin mouthfeel and quickly dissipating into a touch of alchohol coming through.

Pours dark brown with tan head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is lightly toasted malt, caramel and chocolate.  Taste is like a light porter, with the flavor one notch less than the aroma.  Flavors of smoky, woody malts and some cocoa.  Starts strong and finishes light.  A stepping stone to the more robust porter style.

This is probably my 2nd favorite brew from New Belgium, behind their Abbey Ale.  Pours a dark brownish that looks reddish in the light. I think its beautiful.  The aroma is smoky, burnt coffee.  The flavor is somewhat unique.  It tastes like a porter, but its lighter and dryer.  Understated might be the best description.  It might make a good intro beer for people who havent yet acquired a taste for robust porters.  Overall a very good beer.

Dark brown coloured body with a very light copper glow at the bottom - a very nice gradient to the beer and a thinnish, one centimetre tall tan head - nice look. Aroma of slightly toasted malt, some raisin, prune and earthy notes and a hint of caramel and metal in the nose as well. Medium-bodied; Assertive peat and slightly smoked flavours with a bit of lactic sugar, some minor maltiness and a definite pale character. Aftertaste shows a very mild finish with the caramelised sugars standing out the most along with a hint of milk and some light smoked flavours. Overall, a decent beer for sure, but nothing amazing or spectacular. The story is neat and that is just about the best thing regarding this beer. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased and given to me by my brother-in-law from Harris Teeter in Raleigh, North Carolina sampled at home in Washington on 30-May-2013.

I can't believe it took me this long to rate this. One of my favorites.       

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz Bottle A - Pours dark ruby brown with a nice creamy beige head. Good retenition/lacing. S - Roasted malt and cocoa. T - Dark malts, chocolate, faint hop character, and some toffee without being too sweet. M - Medium bodied. Mild carbonation. Soft and creamy texture. Dry finish. O - Very enjoyable.

A dark ale with a thin foamy head.  Malty with hints of chocolate.  Subtle and not very bold.  A pleasant drink, but forgettable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Woooooow, this is like the colour of Burgundy when held against the light and dark blood when out of it. There is a latte coloured head that was voluminous but subsided and left good lace in time. Smells of charry oak, coffee grounds and dark chocolate. It even smells good enough to drink. Cool in the mouth with slightly creamy carbonation. The flavour isnt as deep as the aroma somehow but this impresses with a mousse-like carbonation. The finish is of on-going burnt toast and charry cocoa. Started strongly and had a muted but elegant finish. I still liked this beer a lot.

Choclately and light for such a dark ale. Not very strong taste. Decent. Not a fan of the genre. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I like to bbq spl meats and make delish kabob for the love of many. This beer has spl choco and smoky flavour like bbq smoke kabob or goat and other glorious meats. I like to sip and enjoy after long day in field.

New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Ale has a thick, creamy, beige head and a dark brown appearance (reddish, under direct light), with a nice lacing sheen left behind. The aroma is of dark roasted or slightly burnt barley malt, sweetness, and a bit of cocoa. Taste is of those things, plus bread crust and a mild hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium, a bit soft, and slick, and New Belgium 1554 finishes mostly dry, refreshing, and easy drinking. Overall, this is a very good beer, and I think its worth a try. RJT
Bottle. Nice malty taste, balanced malts. Couldnt drink many of these, but a good ale.
Pours a dark brown with an impressive head. Smells of chocolate and biscuit. Taste is chalky and chocolate. Palate is rather thin for how dark it is. Overall not bad but not great. Might buy again.
Dark brown appearance similar to a coke with medium head.  Taste like smoke coffee with good balance of malt.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2014 Pours dark caramel color with a frothy tan head. Roasted malt smell. Roasted malt, caramel, toffee and some chocolate flavors. Smooth finish and medium body.
dark black an appearance. earthy toasted malt. a little too watery and carbonated. doesnt taste too full bodied.
On tap at Pizzaria in Portland. Nice glowing brown body with medium tanhead. Nose is roasted malts. Nice smoky flavours with caramel, coffee and chocolate in there as well. Enjoyable.
Perfectly balanced and very drinkable. The prefect beer for a stout lover when they want something lighter.
12oz bottle pours a dark brown with a lot of head. Mild malt and roasted flavors.

Poured from bottle into a fluted glass. Thick foamy head that remains goes from an inch plus down to 1/4 inch. Aroma is smoky. palate is light for this dark of a beer. very drinkable. decent lacing along sides of glass. Color and taste of Coffee and chocolate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good; but not one of my New Belgium favorites.  Kind of like a muted strong stout.  Has the coffee/chocolate notes, without the depth or ABV.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brown that glints red in the light. A foamy cream/tan head that attenuates to lacing around the glass. A dark roasted malt aroma with notes of Belgian yeast. The first pull into the mouth promises mild creaminess. Pleasant smooth creaminess over the entire tongue with a mild bite of coffee acidity on the back of the tongue. Fireplace or BBQ smoke throughout. Nothing special, but quite drinkable.

This ones gets better as it warms. Pours dark and mostly black with a faint red hue and fleeting head. Aroma is nutty, malty, and slightly sweet. Taste is toasted malts, slight coffee, and nutty. Finishes smooth and somewhat dry with a great aftertaste. Really solid.

22oz bottle. Clear dark brown with a foamy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, spice, dough and herbs. Flavor is zesty spice, chocolate malt, dough and a light hop bitterness. Medium body with a fairly dry mouth feel. Nice beer, lots of flavor and very drinkable.

The aroma wafts strongly of roasted malts and not much else, which still makes the smell quite hearty, but there is also a hint of leaves. The color of the beer is very dark brown with a prominent off-white head that disappears quickly. The taste is mildly sour, slightly sweet, slightly bitter, and a touch umami, and the palate combines a medium body, average carbonation, long finish, and a creamy texture.

Bottle 12fl.oz.Clear medium to dark red brown colour with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, chocolate, light roasted. Flavour is moderate sweet with a long duration, sweet malt, caramel, light chocolate. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130112]
Nice dark beer with a rich flavor...calls itself a black ale, but its pretty close to a stout.

Reddish mahogany. Medium frothy head, some lasting. sticky lace. Aroma is fruity, roasted malt, chocolate, caramel. Medium to light body, Smooth and creamyish, roasty, easy drinking. Flavor is malty, roasty, caramel, a bit of coffee, some chocolate, slight fruit. Unique and tasty.

aroma-chocolate and fruit. fig. sweet. excellent.
Very nice tan head.  
Tastes smooth, malty, fruit, roasty.  chocolate at the end. very smooth aftertaste
Smokey, light and very alcoholic-tasting. Pretty disappointed. I expected more for a dark beer.
I really like this beer. Its a great cheap six pack that you can find at bottle shops. Nice, refreshing, dark ale.
UPDATED: MAR 21, 2014 Really tasty.  I am reminded of London Porter, one of my other favorite brews.  Very well balanced and eminently quaffable.

Pours dark black with minimal tan head. Aroma is malty with chocolate notes. Also roasted notes to complement the color. The taste is bitter and sweet similar to dark chocolate. A bit of an acidic finish makes for an interesting and delicious beer

Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, cocoa/chocolate, & some caramel; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, cocoa/chocolate, and some dark fruit; Nicely balanced; Easy drinking - pretty decent.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with red highlights.  Aroma of coffee, cocoa, and sweet malts.  Taste just like the nose, coffee grinds, dark chocolate, and sweet malts. Nice roasted malts throughout.  A bit thin, but enjoyable.  Nice balance. A bit tart on the finish.
On tap at the New Belgium Hub. Dark and roasty. Tastes slightly like coffee beans. Medium carbonation.
On tap at Hot Tomato...Dark appearance but taste is surprisingly lighter than color.  Cocoa and slight coffee..mvery nice

12 oz bottle.  Almost black with a nice light tan head and patchy lacing.  Smells mostly malty, coffee, cocoa and toffee with herbs/spices and dark fruits.  Surprisingly lighter body with a smooth, dry feel.  Roasted toasted malts and a bittersweet balanced flavor.  Wow, I was wrong about this one, great feel and flavor.

Bottle from Whole Foods El Segundo. Yeasty, light chocolate aroma, with some spice. Clear dark brown with a very thick, fluffy tan head. Light coffee and some chocolate in the initial / mid is smooth and slightly sweet / finish is rather bland. Thin palate. A bit sweet, overall, and not "dry," as the label claims. Not bad.
pours black with a disappearing white head.  leather and berry aroma. taste is plum, maple and roasted malt.  bittersweet finish

Aroma is of roasted chocolate and dark fruits. Appearance is black with a large tan head that dissipates quickly. Tastes of cocoa, graham cracker, and sweet malts. Palate is thick and creamy. Overall an excellent beer that I always enjoy drinking.

Pours a very dark but relatively clear red brown. Aroma is roasted, slightly smoky, slight chocolate/cocoa. Flavor is sweet malt, slight candied dark fruit, chocolate malt, mildly smoked fading into nutty, very mildly bitter malt finish. Mild alcohol in finish. Moderare carbonation and medium-light body. Havent had this one in a few years, enjoyed it a lot more this time. Flavorful, sweet, and drinkable. A very solid beer.
Smells chocolaty. Tastes lightly of coffee. One of New Belgiums best. And surprisingly light in calories XDXDXDXDXD

Bottle courtesy of dad, my real dad, while in Madison, GA. Pours a deep amber brown body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is chocolate and light sweet roast. Mouthfeel is medium to light with notes of sweet dark coffee roast, toasted malts, cocoa and bitter chocolate.

Pours dark, almost black, with a red hue when held up to the light and two finger beige head.  The aroma and taste are both primarily roasted malts, good but not complex.  The aroma and taste remind me of a stout more than anything.  The feel is not as creamy as a stout though with more lively carbonation.
Poured a cola color with a light tan head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, coffee, nuts, and dough. Taste is chocolate, coffee, caramel, black pepper, with a nice bitter sweet finish.

12 oz. bottle pours a very dark reddish brown with small beige head and good lacing.  Aroma is full of bready malts, chocolate, and some dark fruits.  Taste is slightly sweet fithout much of a finish.  Easily drinkable. Tastes something like a thin porter. Body is medium with average carbonation.  Very good for such a widely distributed beer, even if its hard to classify.

The taste is nice and light. Only a hint of belgium beer. Overall a pretty decent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a very nice rich black on tap. Smooth drinking with a nice tingle in the mouth. Well balanced between hop bitterness and malt sweetness. Not very much discernible nose. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
An amazing lesser known beer. I always bring this beer to gatherings and everyones always surprised how good this is. If you like Fat Tire you MUST try 1554!!!
On tap at New Bohemia.  Late night Saturday happy hour for $3 - cant beat that.  Darker pour than I expected for some reason.  Body was a little light, but still and enjoyable beer.
Bottle, SBT. Ruddy brown, roasty caramel, sweet, mahogany wood. creamy, some metallic notes. Some sour tinge. Would have guessed it was a mild porter.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Hazy dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dark fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. 120113
Bottle @ Berliner Weisse Takeover Ulfborg, 2013. Pours ruby amber with a white head. Caramel, grain, toffee and mild spices. Smooth. Tasty.

Bottle @ FOneFan, 5.6%. Dark brown/red with small beige head. Aroma is light roasted malts, chocolate, caramel and dark fruits. Flavour is malt, caramel, medium sweet, chocolate, little bread and nutty.
Pours a clear reddish dark brown.  Aroma is sweet and toasty.  Taste is roast, chocolate, and and very sweet.
From a 12 bottle shared at home.  Pours a clear cola brown with an off white head.  Earthy malt aroma.  Big malt backbone with little hop presence.  Smooth finish.

Pours a rich and dark brown with two fingers of tan head. Aroma is of dark fruits mainly prunes. Taste is slightly musty with more of the dark fruits and eventually gives way to a subtle smokiness. This is my favorite beer that New Belgium makes.

Pours a pretty deep garnet, clear, with a big frothy fluffy tan head that persists throughout the whole beer. Smells are roasted and sweet, much like a porter. Tastes are roasted, slight floral and slight cooked vegetable to me, and a little nutty. Enjoyable. Mouthfeel is a little pungent and the body a bit flat. Its possible I drank this a little too warm but I dont think so. This beer does take on a strange aroma once at the end, or room temp. Like an average dinner cooking, strange. My score reflects the initial aroma only.
Pours cola brown. Its a bit roastier than Id have thought. Quite minerally, with some dark fruit and a bit of caramel, but its actually pretty dry. Nice mouthfeel and full body. Not bad.

P:  Dark cola appearance with thin micro bubble khaki head. Minimal lacing and slowly active carbonation. 

S:  Coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa powder, fresh baked biscuits, and roasted caramel surrounded by an musty earthy base. 

T/M:  Rich milk chocolate, bittersweet dark chocolate, French roast coffee, sugared dates and an overall rich malty palate.  Medium body with soda carbonation. Finishes dry with bitter dark chocolate and a timid chalky aftermath. 

O:  I like this for a go to beer when you want an  enhanced flavored sessional beer. Nice malt blend with an appropriate amount of bitter dryness to round out the sweetness. I will purchase this again for sure. Cheers!

Light bodied dark ale. Biscuit malt taste is present. Chocolate is also there. Clean finish - session style dark ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Very sexy looking beer, decent lacing and surprising alcohol legs with a head of maybe a finger that dissapears very quickly. Poors blackish and it is VERY dark red when light is shining through. Chocolate and dark fruits are coming through on the nose. Getting a hoppy, malty  taste on the front and middle of the tounge with a very dry and slightly chocolate flavored finish. Good beer!

Ruby-edged black with a whipped tan head.
Caramel, roast,cola scent.
Taste is sweet malt, chocolate, nuts.
Very pleasant.
Dark brown appearance, roasted malt and some hops in the aroma.  Flavor was a nice rich malt with a balanced hop bitterness.  I really enjoyed it.
Pours black but thin. No head. Aroma was chocolate malt and dark fruit. Taste follows with some hop bittering. Thin feel with slight metallic taste.

Very nutty aroma to this beer. The appearance is a dark pour with a medium head . The taste is surley toasted malts with finishing hints of chocolate. Very smooth drinker. A creamier beer that i have had.

Short some of the more prominent Lips of Faith beers, this is one of the best New Belgium beers.  A nice dark brown appearance with a medium head.  Medium body, slightly watery texture.  Chocolate and brown sugar. Nice.
Pours dark brown with a light head. Aroma is a dark mocha with hints of caramel. The taste is smooth with less of a creamy mouthfeel than a stout, of course, but full and satisfying.
Substantial head, sweet malts leaning towards creamy mocha. Hints of hops just to give it good balance and a smooth caramel finish. On the light side for a black ale. Tasty.
Pours a dark brown nearly black with an off-white head, the aroma has chocolate mixed in with dark fruit, the flavor has malt and chocolate in the finish. A very nice beer.

Pours a near black color with a nice small head that fades slowly.  Aroma is fairly faint and smells like a pale lager with a hint of chocolate.  Taste is entirely different though.  A lot of roasted malt comes through in the flavor but the pale lager background is still there.  Finish adds a light chocolate taste.  Very smooth.  Medium body, smooth and somewhat creamy mouthfeel.  A fairly unique beer.  I would call this a black lager but this has a much thicker and creamier mouthfeel than a normal one.

Two fingers of tan head. Dark brown body, almost black.
Smell is a strong roasted malt. Nice.
Tasty with roasted malt balanced with a mild bitterness. The malt comes through nicely.
Smooth texture with a light to medium body and moderate carbonation.
Pretty good Black Ale. Great balance of roasted malt and bitterness.

Bottle, 
this ale had a clear dark pour and gave a one and half finger light tan colored head that receded to a thin cover and ring, hold the glass up to a light and this beer is a ruby with black-brown edges, the center of the glass had a strong flow of bubbles with many little streams elsewhere in the glass, it left some finger and spots of lacing on the sides of the glass, there was no sediment in the bottle, 

the aroma were toasted and roasted malt, chocolate, cola, a little licorice in the background, and hints of earth, 

it had flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, roasted malt and toasted bread sweetness, a little licorice in the background, 
some earthy notes, a touch of molasses sweetness, 
the roasted malt was out front, there was a little bitterness from the roasted malt, 

the mouth feel was light on the palate, average to lively carbonation, 

this was an ok drink.
Dark brown pour with way too much head.  Taste is nutty, a hint of chocolate.  A bit watery.  Not bad, but nothing great.

Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle: The aroma consists of light-moderate chocolate, light caramel, and roasted nuts. It pours a orangish-brown with some transparency. It has a small beige head that quickly fades to a thin ring. The flavor starts with chocolate and caramel. The finish has light roasted nuts with the slightest hint of smoke. Its light-medium bodied with moderate carbonation.
Chestnut/brown pour with creamy off white head. Caramel malts, slightly toasty nose. Medium body with a velvety mouthfeel. Sweeter towards the end. Not bad. Really hard to pin down.

This one's hard to figure out.  Dry, lighter flavor for a black ale, but the flavor is quite good and the malt does come through. If anything, it's a little on the thin side. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good beer, nice taste, smooth, wish it had a bit more flavor though...just a hit watery and no smell

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep black color with medium beige head.  Aroma is roasted chocolate malt.  Malty flavor, slightly sweet with roasty finish.  Medium-bodied with creamy mouthfeel.  Reminds me of porter, pretty good.
Pours a nice chestnut brown with nice off white lacing. Aromas of cocoa and dark fruits. Flavours are roasted malts, cream, cocoa, and some sweetness. Nice.

Bottle--pours a deep, deep brown and a medium head.  Aroma of nuts, roasted barley and some caramel with light carbonation.  Easy, smooth drink with nuttiness, a touch of hops and some caramel.  Nice stuff.  Bruisin Ales.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap - average size foamy head, almost black color, roasted malt aroma and flavor, tastes of fair chocolate, smooth creamy texture

The pour is black w/ a thick tan head that slowly fades. The aroma is full of malts & coffee flavor. The taste follows the smell to a tee. It has a creamy mouthfeel & goes down smooth. Drinkable & flavorful. A very, very nice brew.
Appearance is small brown head with deep brown. Aroma is pretty sweet. Taste is a nice toasted chocolate malt. Overall very good.
Probably New Belgiums best, but all of their beers are better on tap than in the bottle. For some odd reason, most of their bottled beer has a soapy aftertaste.
Excellent. Perfect roast. Reminds me of moose drool. Coffee chocolate finish. Will have again.
Pretty black color, but bland roasted flavor and thin body. Many other 5.6% ABV brews with more flavor!
nice smooth black ale.  not something I would like to have all the time, but a good roasty flavor with a decent hop balance.

On draft at Buffalo Wild Wings. 

The beer is dark brown, approaching black, with a quarter inch of beige head. The aroma brings some Belgian style malts, chocolate, a touch of grain. The flavor brings some sweet milk chocolates and some bready malts. Not the most refined flavor, but easy enough to throw back a pint of this. Light to medium in body and fairly creamy on the palate. I drank a lot of this beer in college, so it was nostalgic to return to it after a long hiatus.
Bland, water, and just nothing special. Appearance gives it a look of a heavy brew, but it is very deceptive.

On tap poured a clear dark brown fizzy tan head w/ nice lacing. Mild aroma of caramel. Taste is a mild sweet with roasted sweet finish. Flavor of chocolate, roasted malts and light coffee. Light to medium body.
Pours a translucent brownish-black from the bottle with dissipating, bubbly tan head and little to no lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and lager yeast. Taste follows, kind of bland. Meh.
Dark brown colour, tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Similar taste, slightly sweet and malty. Some fruity notes in there as well. Very smooth and drinkable beer.

This pours a dark brown with a slight off white head. There is a slight scent of roasted malts mixed with a mild yeast tone. The taste has a mild roasted malt taste. The texture and volume is perfectly done. Smooth, tasty, and refreshing! A rather boldly made brew that most will find very likeable. A great brew for those looking to start drinking dark beers but cant quite handle a porter or stout yet. A great beer for the price!

Cola pour with a foamy tan head. Roasted malt and coffee aroma. Taste is quite bitter, lots of coffee.... this isnt at all what i was expecting. Sort of smells like peanuts? Weird.  Its a nice session bitter.

Poured from tap. Appearance is deep brown with a light amber tint and a small white head and goo lacing. Roast, caramel, biscuit, brown sugar, and nuts in the aroma. Taste is nutty, roasted malt, dark fruits, a touch of cocoa, cereal, and light grass. Medium mouthfeel with low carbonation. Smooth, nice sipper, with roast characteristics, but not overly roasted like you get with some beers in this style. Solid offering.

Reviewed 8/31. 12 oz bottle poured into a Duvel tulip.

A: Pours a dark burgundy color that shows traces of carbonation beneath the tint. The one finger offwhite head doesnt retain as well as Id like in a Belgian-style ale, but it leaves a nice ring of lacing.

S: Chocolate, slight roasted malts, pumpernickel bread, and plums. Almost porter-esque in its aroma, and an impressive one at that.

T: Initially, theres a wave of coffee and light ash (not necessarily roast) that envelops the tongue. Whem given time to sit in the mouth, it will finish in a fruity manner, with both dark and lighter fruit esters. Some finishing dry, bittersweet chocolate also appears. Two flaws here; the coffee almost takes on a vegetal tone at times, and its not particularly exploding with flavor.

M: Its hard to describe the general feel. Its smooth in general, but has a yeasty astringency to it on the finish, and is a little too heavy for its mellow flavors. Drinkable enough.

O: While its good, I think its too hard to drink given its mild flavor profile. Its still worth a try and I might even get it again in the future.

I enjoyed this beer. Great for some who wants something a little darker than a brown ale but not as dark as a porter. Pours a dark color and leaves a white head. Has a nice smooth aroma of roasted malts with a hint of chocolate. Taste is much the same. Roasted malt with notes of chocolate, mild carbonation and is fairly smooth on your palate after the swallow. Overall, a great beer.

355 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown, almost vlack colour with a white head. Aroma of toasted malts, raisins and bread. Flavour of toasted bready malts, grass, syrup and dark chocolate. Medium bodied, oily mouthfeel and a sweetish finish with bready notes. Rather simple but works very well. Would work nicely with all kinds of dishes.
This lager (yes, thats correct) features a rather simple aroma of roasted malt.  The flavor at first seems quite subtle; the strongest flavor comes in the finish, then lingers on and on.

Pours murky deep brown with a large, rocky, quickly dissipating off-white head. Nose is dark fruits - plum, prune, date, some spice, a little doughy yeast and wood. More luscious dark fruits in the middle along with some liquorice and some sugar. Quite light bodied, a little oily, soft carbonation, no hint of alcohol at all. Easy drinking, nice.

Poured from the bottle, thick black with tiny brown head.  Earthy malty aroma.  Nutty stout.  Smooth oily and easy drinking.  Not amazing or that original, but a good beer.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled.  Pours ruby brown with light beige head.  Faint aroma of chocolate and caramel.  Alcohol flavor is most prominent up front, developing into bitter coffee and chocolate, which gain a bit of sweetness toward the finish, which is dry and malty.  Mouthfeel is a little thin, but smooth.  Medium bodied.  Not a very well-balanced beer, a bit too much roast malt bitterness.

Bottle from Big Sur. Ruby-edged mahogany with a falling, nicotined beige foam. Aroma of carob, orange, leaf matter and lightly cocoa-dusted roastedness. Full and smooth with a gentle carob, orange (Smartie), black bread, black cherry and insinuating cocoa character. The flavour profile and smoothness of any one of hundreds of English milds/smilds/porters/storters/dark malty bitters. Church End Stout Coffin springs to mind. Not bad.
Pours predictably dark, with a substantial off white head. The head holds for a while, very good lacing. Soft mouthfeel. Nice chocolate flavor and malty sweetness. Very enjoyable.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a very dark brown nearly black with an off white head and spotty lacing,  the aroma has a good amount of chocolate mixed in with some dark fruit, the flavor has a nice fullness of malt and chocolate in the finish, mouthfeel is thick through out and really works, pretty darn good.
UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Very full flavor.  So smooth and dark.  Creamy.  Pairs perfectly with an extra sharp artisan cheddar.  As if the two were made for each other.

Pint on tap at Creegans.  Black color, light lacing, "toasted" aroma, slightly bitter taste matches.  Not very complex, perhaps its not meant to be, less impressive after drinking hundreds of "actual" Belgian beers.  Simple, good...not great.

20oz @ Horse Brass. Pours black, small tan head, good foamy lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, some chocolate. Flavor is same-- nice & light mouthfeel. Not too sweet. Highly quaffable, but enlightenment not guaranteed.

A great every day beer for the dark beer drinkers out there. Not too heavy with a great flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black pour, and yes Im enlightened...roasty, chocolatey and tasty with some bitter chocolate aftertaste.  Enjoyable!!
Reddish-brown w/ a tan head. Caramel and roasted aroma. Flavor was lightly sweet, touch of bitter. Caramel, roasted malt. Easy to drink, not much complexity.
A good dark ale with a sweet taste along with the usual coffee and chocolate, similar to a milk stout. Here the malt is mostly in the aftertaste.

Very easy to drink. Some chocolate malt flavors. A bitter after taste. The chocolate taste lingers. You can feel the maltiness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Roasted malts with a hint of caramel makes up the aroma. It pours a deep dark ruby tinted brown with a mostly diminishing pale tan head. Good lacing present. The taste is roasted malts, nuts, and coffee with just a hint of and chocolate. There is malty,nutty, slightly bitter aftertaste. The palate is medium with medium+ carbonation. Overall, this the type of beer I enjoy drinking. I had forgotten how good it is. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown/black with a bubbly white head that fades somewhat quickly. Smells light with mild toasted malts and light hops. The taste is crisp and refreshing but a little too much like a macro brew for my taste. Ok but I would never seek this out again.

1000th rating. Dark brown colour with white head, fades, not much carbonation, kind of underwhelming  palate. Aroma of prunes and sweet malts. Taste of coffee, dried fruit. Not bad, but I found the palate a bit flat.

I poured this New Belgium Black ale from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip style beer stein. It poured dark, frothy, almost coffee like in color with the aroma of toffee and malt.  Tastes dry though strong in flavor with roasted malts and bitter coffee. Overall a good beer, but not my style.
A very nice dark ale which is not too heavy.  Silky mouthfeel and slightly smokey aftertaste.
UPDATED: NOV 2, 2013 Dark beer with medium body and lighter taste.  Definite chocolate taste with hint of coffee.  Smooth finish with little aftertaste.

Deep cloudy brown with a small pale head. Aroma is caramel, Belgian yeast, dates, figs, chocolate. Sweet on the palate with a medium finish, slick mouthfeel. No hint of bitterness. Taste is raisins, chocolate, treacle. Easy drinking.
dark brown black coloured body with a off white head a roasted malty aroma a spicy malty caramel sweet taste with a little bitter finish
Tap @ Taphouse Grill, Seattle. Huge creamy head with excellent duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are catamel, nuts, malt and hops. Nice and smooth.

hazy mahogany with a thin beige head. soft medium body with high carbonation.

aroma: black roasted barley (soft like carafa special), notes of prune and licorice root.

taste: black roasted barley, caramel malt, licorice root, cola, and soft woodsy hops.

Aroma is malty and sweet. Very dark slightly opaque brown. Sweet nutty and smoky flavor, with a nutty finish.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with large dark brown highlights and medium light brown head.  Thin lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and light roasted aroma.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, and bitter finish.  Quite a bit of flavor, pretty good.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2012 Caramel, nuts, malty almost wine like hints of flavour and palate.  A great take on ale without the bitterness that scare away non beer drinkers .  Nice appetizing dark pour and smooth body, a beer that has substance in its malts rather than overhopping to mask their absence.  Very interesting & unique almost like a very tame and restricted barleywine.
170712. Tap at brouwers cafe, seattle. Pours black with a nice head. Aroma nuts, oats. Sweet malty taste. Smooth finish. Not Bad.

Amazing from New Belgium. With Brad and Matt at Yard House. Denver, Colorado on July 16, 2012.

This is one of my go to dark beers when Im in the mood.  Usually finish my drinking experience off with a beer like this.  Its fairly close in taste to a good porter than other black ales Ive had, just a little more coffee/cocoa taste to it.  Not too smooth or creamy, has a nuttiness about it, and bits of New Belgiums familiar after taste signature in most of their beers. I like my Black Ales to have a little kick to it, and this one does particularly when its fresh.
I have yet to come across a bad New Belgium beer.  This one is dark, thick head and med bodied.  Finishes with a little toasted chocolatey caramel sumpin.  Really good dark, not too heavy.
Every New Belgium beer out there is great! Im a huge.fan & look forward to many more!!

Numerous bottle, some draft.  Cola pour with a small fizzy head.  Nose is roast, peanut shells, light peat, cocoa.  Flavor is similar, kinda watery and ultimately very boring as it never really takes any one direction.  meh
A black colored beer, with a light beige head. The aroma of roasted malts, some coffee with hops. The taste of dark malts, fruits and some hop. the aftertaste is sweet with hoppy notes.
Poured dark brown with a nice head and some lacing. Some sweet chocolate notes balanced with some bitterness. Well made, excellent beer.
12 oz bottle. Pours black and looks like a porter. Medium body with rich taste. Hints of cocoa... Would be good paired with pizza

New Belgium 1554 - Pours dark brown to almost black; good head and lacing.  Aroma of cocoa and bready malts.  Taste is similar.  Reminds me of a mix of a brown ale and a porter, kind of like Abita Turbodog.  Solid beer.

Pours brown black with off white head.  Nose is notable for chocolate and bitters.  On the tongue smooth and frothy with immediate hazelnut, water, and finish of chocolate, and subtle cinnamon and nettles.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear very dark brown with a 1.5 finger light tan head. Good lacing and head retention.

Aroma of cocoa, light roast coffee, and toasted malt. There is also a lactose-like sweetness on the nose and a light touch of dark fruit.

Coffee up front in the taste with a hint of cocoa powder. Roasted malt and slightly tannic. Dark fruit towards the finish along with a light bitterness. Mouthfeel is a little bit sticky.

Overall, an ok beer but kind of lacking in all areas. A little underdone I felt.

Reminds me of English Porter. Lifted aromatics offer a hint of roast and a little mocha. Killer mouthfeel here and a balanced palate. Roasted chocolate at first leading to a refreshing effervescence and just a touch of blue fruit on the back end. Light and nimble- easy to enjoy.

12 oz. Bottle. Historically interesting. Realistically porter-like. Roasty coffee chocolate porter-like scent. Black pour with brown showing around the edges as light leaked through, white head fizzing down to a white ring. Coffee with cream taste up front, like a cowtail candy, chocolate note, and a bitter sweet finish. Medium bodied, silky smooth mouthfeel. Very tasty.
Dark, but not in the traditional sense, its very pleasant. A chocolate coffee taste. The aroma should be made into an air freshener. Tis very filling though, almost like a stout. Delicious.
12 oz bottle pours nearly black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste was the malts, chocolate and a hint of hops.

Mocha and straw aroma. Not much head but attractive dark red. Subtle taste with complex and long-lasting finish, including chocolate, roasted coffee, and caramel. Extremely interesting and easy to drink too!
Dark, great color, drinks easy like a lighter beer. Subtle chocolate notes. Fantastic.
Love this beer. Great malt and caramel flavors, with a hint of chocolate. Easy to drink. Awesome!
One of my favorites. It a darker beer but doesnt taste dark. Plus it has a hint of chocolate!
One of my favorite staple beers.  Malty carmel .  Never overbearing.  Drinks like a lighter beer than it is.
Bottle. Definitely one of my favorites... dark, but not too heavy. Highly recommended for casual drinking, with a meal or with friends after work.
Dark brown with amber tint and tan head. Fruity aroma. Malty taste with fruity flavors & chocolate notes. Some yeasty spiciness in finish. Smooth.
Great beer overall! Chocolate, coffee, woody, vanilla, caramel, bread, earthy, basement aromas

Tap. Pours clear, dark brown with thin, creamy off-white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is caramel and toasted malt, earthy hops, figs, woody notes and light toffee. Flavor is sweet malt upfront with good supporting hops and dark fruit esters; dry, semi-sweet finish. Medium body, low carbonation, and low warmth.
It poured a deep mahogany red color with a little white head. The aroma was toasted bread and some fruit. The taste was dominated by roasted malt and mild chocolate.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2012 Bottled.  Poured into tulip glass, dark dark amber color with no head.  Aroma of roasty malts, chocolate and vanilla (a candy beer!).  Taste brought out more dark chocolate and hints of coffee.  Finish was earthy and bitter.  Very much enjoyed.

Poured this beer from the bottle into a 4oz sampling glass.  The beer had a dark amber-brown color with an amber hue, along with an average-sized foamy off-white head with good lacing, average cling, and modest retention.  The beer had an aroma of earthy and grainy hops, with touches of chocolate, coffee, and caramel, along with a straw component.  Its taste featured a blend of caramel and chocolate malt, along with a very light bitter grainyness and a toasty effect.  The beer had an average wetness with a lighter mouthfeel, and lower carbonation and life, and was a bit thin.

A good beer. Have never been a huge fan of New Belgian beers, but I like this one. Very black pour, and smells of both chocolate and vanilla. Very malty taste, a departure for New Belgium. Can almost get a little too sweet. But very tasty. Had in the bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with a lasting half inch head. Nice aroma of creamy malt, coffee, chocolate, and some nice hop balance. Medium bodied with a nice smooth palate. Could pass as a light milk stout almost.
Pours nice and dark. Has all the awesome characteristics of a porter. Roasted aroms coming off it with hints of coffee to the flavor. Surprisingly light, it finishes very clean.

A beer with an opaque black color, 1554 has a delightfully smooth body for such a dark beer. It has a slight caramel flavor, with the barest hint of coffee highlighting the taste. Great overall beer, appropriate for casual drinking. 

-The Djinn

I enjoy this beer fairly often....Not too heavy yet full of flavor.  Dark and roasty with just enough hops to remind me that they are there.  Very easy drinking and low in abv, makes for a good sessionable winter ale or a very good dinner compliment.

Bottle in the New Belgium mix 12 pack.  Pours a clear but super dark mahogany brown, thin head.  Smell is cocoa and chocolate all over with spice.  Taste is more cocoa, and some roast.  Body is quite thin like lighter lager, but taste exhibits some decent flavor.  I see that they are marketing this as a spring/summer beer, but I would prefer the Dig or Ranger in the pack.

Originally reviewed: 5/19/10. 12oz bottle poured into a goblet. Pours a deep dark mahogany/amber with a thin beige head on top. Disappears quickly, leaving behind some lace and sip rings. Some light toffee and molasses make up the nose. Not a whole lot going on there. 

The mouth is firm. Some good carbonation backing, and a smooth finish. Nice. Nothing in the flavor really stands out. I dont notice anything that specifies this as Belgian in the flavor. Its got some semi-sweet toffee, light bitterness, and a mild finish. I rather enjoyed this one, but it was sort of bland in the process. Expected more from this, but Id gladly have it again regardless.

Poured from a bottle into a stein. Frothy tan head that maintained through drinking. Nice dark color. Aroma of rich malt and chocolate with a medium bitter and light sweet flavor. Medium body with a slick texture and lively carbonation. Nice long finish. Overall a solid dark ale.

12oz bottle into a tulip. Best by Apr-08-12. Whoops, Im a few days late.

Appearance - Poured a deep and somewhat murky brown. Some amber/orange highlights when held in the light. Small and short lasting off white creamy head. A thin ring settles around the edges.

Aroma - I like the nose on this one. Chocholate malts, roasted coffee, yeast, some spice and hint of earthy floral hops.

Taste -  Semi-sweet dark chocolate malts, Belgian spice and yeast, before a slightly more bitter coffee finish and a touch of floral hops.

Mouthfeel - Medium bodied. Dry. A little too high on the carbonation than I would have expected. Bitter earthy coffee finish. But it has a depth of flavor and aromas that make it an alright beer to try. Although I doubt Id ever really seek it out again.

May 2010: 22 Fl Oz bottle obtained from a Lees Discount Store in Las Vegas, poured into goblets in the garden of our B&B just outside Zion National Park after a full day of hiking and staring at rocks!

Dark and moody looking, a thin off-white head sat on top, some to be a wisp and collar, no lacing appeared.

The nose was all chocolate, dark, rich and inviting.

Chocolate dominated the taste, some coffee hints tried to break through, but the dark chocolate beat that back into submission.

Different and enjoyable, not sure I could have drank the whole bottle though.

I know. I am not known as a Belgium fan. Usually like the simpler elegance of a German. But having tried and enjoyed Hoptober and Fat Tire recently, I thought it would be great to try something dark. This one was a very pleasant surprise. Downed the entire 22 oz myself (and that says a lot). Deep rich brown/mahogany in the glass with a creamy rich tan head that fell but maintained a presence (nicely lacing the glass) all the way down. Flavor was a touch sweet buttery malt, a touch roasted chocolate and a touch of bitterness--all in perfect balance. Rendered the whole incredibly smooth, creamy and without any odd flavors that may have impacted drinkability. Very good and Im hoping that we get the smaller bottles out here very soon. One Id keep around for daily consumption. Wow.
Nice fresh aroma, and good looking dark pour with slightly tan head.  Great flavor with a smooth chocolaty finish.  Solid beer.

Pours a clear dark brown color with small tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of roasted barley, smoke, some vanilla and malts.  Taste is malty, with some roast and smoke. Finishes a bit on the dry side.

pours very dark brown almost black, but able to see through, with a head that disappears very quickly.. The aroma is malty and some chocolate.  The flavor is sweet, with some bitterness, it has a burnt flavor towards the back of the palate, and caramel up front folowed by chocolate.  The body is a medium body.
Pours dark brown color. Smell is of coffee, chocolate and hint of vanilla. Taste is caramel malt, roasted coffee and again a hint of vanilla finishing with a slight bitterness. Medium bodied.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black with finger thick head with light brown head. Moderate amount of lacing.  Roasted malt with a hint of coffee and a touch of chocolate. Mild herbal hops. Moderate carbonation with medium body. Long finish that is mostly coffee and malt. Good beer.
Poured at home from a 12 ounce bottle  into a pint glass -- very dark almost black with a creamy head.  Mild aroma but a wonderful taste lingers on the palate with a dry chocolaty  taste.

Sweet. It has a thick, foamy head when you pour it; so much so that pouring it was a pretty slow process. The smell is indistinct, but the taste is really clean and sweet. Not remotely bitter at all. I struggled to detect the hops. All that comes through for me is rich, smooth, sweet malts. Its like a glass of buttered wheat bread.
Pours a black color. Smell is mild, some coffee. Taste is also mild, some coffee and chocolate, a bit different for this style. Overall a decent brew.
The beer has a deep brown color. I got subtle hints of a fruity coffee aroma. The taste has a bit of coffee mixed with chocolate and fruits. Very drinkable beer
Deep brown colour. Tan cap. Steady lacing. Subtle fruity coffee nose. Dark fruit taste, offset with coffee and a bit of chocolate. Very drinkable.
Pours very dark brown with super thick light brown head...aroma is raisens and coffee.. Taste is a smooth drinking chocolate malts some fruit.. Awesome beer

On tap at airport in Denver. Dark brown color with amber shining thru when held to light. Good head and light tasting. Some burnt malt taste with some sweetness overtones. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This Traditional Ale poured a deep, dark red colour with a big, creamy, tan coloured head. To the nose there are scents of coffee, cocoa, burnt malt, caramel and brown sugar. First sip was rich with flavour of caramel, light coffee, dark chocolate and toast. Finish is roasty with coffee and roasted malt flavour lingering. Very good!

On tap. A deep brown color and a foamy off-white head and lacing. The aroma is toasted malt with a slightly nutty note. The flavor is light, with some  semisweet toasted malt and a smooth, creamy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown with a thick mocha head. Nose is chocolate, malts and some sweetness. Tastes of hot chocolate and burnt malts. Rich and creamy.
Dark brown with amber tint and tan head.  Fruity aroma.  Malty taste with fruity flavors & chocolate notes.  Some yeasty spiciness in finish.  Smooth.

dark brown color with ruby hues when held to light. There is a one finger cream colored head that lasts a decent amount of time and leaves some thin lacing.  Smell is roasted and toasted malt. Palate is mostly dark malt up front, with a bit of sweetness. Notes of dark fruit and chocolate come through after a few sips.

Smells like dark malts, smoke and cocoa powder.  Tastes like chocolate, crackers and some orange notes.  Lush mouthfeel, with these dark malts it has a full body but not sticky presence.  Finishes clean with some chocolate and dark toast.

The nose is sweet yet roasty. Coffee aromas dominate with collaboration from bready toast notes. The beer is deep brown with a small head. The taste echos the coffee, malt, and bread adding some subtle dark fruit.  The body is medium and the beer is very smooth if a little sweet.
Dark black.  Thick tan head.  Very roast.  Tastes like coffee.  Somewhat sweet.  Ok beer.

Poured a very black with a slightly tan head. The aroma has some barnyard and sweet dough. The taste is certainly on the dough-like sweet side, though there are just enough aromatic hops that balance it out quite well. Very decent beer.

Nice nose of mild raisin and fig.  Nice brown sugar hint.  Taste is much of the same.  A good introduction to classic Belgium ale...from a sorta mainstream stance. Is very well executed. Only sorta thin

Pours a nice caramel brown color with a nice size head that goes away quickly. Little lacing on the sides.Smells of dark sugary candy, raisins, nutty, a little spicey alcohol at the end. Nice full body taste, toffe like, roasted malts.
Hint of chocolate aroma. Smooth, medium bodied, slightly coating mouthfeel. Very solid well balanced beer.
Clear dark brown with very think cream head and lasting lacing; chocolate malt aroma and flavor with a nutty background; hint of coffee with a light bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours a near-black body with a deep bronze hue, covered by a big, creamy light beige head. Very impressive. Nose is toffee, chocolate, caramel and hints of vanilla and candy sugar. A bit sweet, but unusual and nice. Taste is dark malts, milk chocolate, hints of toffee and sugar. Smooth, velvety mouthfeel. Very drinkable, despite the dark flavors. Complex enough to be interesting, original enough to remember and light enough (nearly) to be a session ale. Good stuff indeed.

Deep brown, opaque, with a very short brownish head. Good lacing throughout. Lots of chocolates dominate the nose, along with toasty nutty coffee notes. Taste is well balance, good semisweet malts with cocoa and coffee flavors, rounded with bitter hops.
12oz bottle: Appearance is dark brown with minimal off white head. Aroma is malty. Taste is of caramel malt and some yeast.
Des notes de torréfaction, cassonade et chocolat dans un corps moyen à la buvabilité décente.
Bottle.  Nice red-brown color, clear, decent head.  Nice malty aroma, but not overly pungent. Carbonation seems high, flavorful finish.  Good complex full beer.

Picked this up as a single for $2 from a beer store in Delaware. Best before April 29th, 2012. Poured into a Duvel Tulip

A - Half a finger head that disappears almost instantly colored wood brown. The brew is dark brown only if you show up to a light. It looks black but is clearly just a very dark brown with no sediment.

S - The malts are slightly chocolatey. Im getting some half and half cream and some earthiness. Maybe some light wood scents and some spices but theres not a lot going on for smell.

T - The start of this is a classic Belgian ale. Im geting some candied yams, grapes and the yeast is almost like wild grapes and perhaps some orange creamsicle. Its pretty disappointing.

M - Lots of carbonation explosion that exposes some raisin taste. Theres no linger and no real aftertaste of anything.

O - I was very excited about this beer. now, Im disappointed. Its light enough to drink daily and, for the price, I guess its great. Ill rate this based on availability and price, not on how amazing it is.

Spicey aroma of lightly roasty malt, chocolate, and a bit of yeastiness. Tad earthy as well.  Taste shows a lightly roasty malt backbone. Chocolate, dark fruit and a hint of spiciness. Decent balance. Pleasing malty sweetness lingers a bit at the finish.
Pours a nice clear reddsih black. Taste of malt, slightly sweet. smooth and drinkable. No the greatest, but still Thumbs up.

It pours an attractive coffee brown with a thin to medium head that leaves a creamy curtain as its drank. The beer smells a bit sour, sharp, and I get a trace of roasted sweets.  It tastes similar to this save maybe chocolate or coffee and the followup is tangy.  I do love a sipping beer and 1554 certainly delivers.
Outstanding brew!  Deep, dark, roasty flavor.  Long malty finish. Just the right amount of hops for a delicious balance.
Feb 8, 2012 tap at Valley Tap.  Dark brown with some red pour, nice head and lacing.  Aroma of malt, dark chocolate and belgian yeast.  Taste is similar, palate a little thin and some carbonation.

Pours a beautiful, clear ruby with a small cream head that does not linger. Aroma of roasted malt, biscuit and cracker. Chewy mouthfeel follows through with the same roast, malt throughout and a sweet finish. Slight watery finish

Tasted on draft at the Nashville Beer Festival.  Pours clear, very dark amber, with an average beige head.  The nose is toasted chocolate malt along with some light aromas of nutty vanilla.  The flavor is malty chocolate, toasted and roasted, with the same nutty vanilla and a hint of bitterness.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long, roasted nutty vanilla finish.
Dark, malty, chocolate taste.  beer is smooth and looks great in a pint glass

Bottle 355 ml
 Aroma:  soft warm welcoming aroma, dark malts mixed with hop. Very nice blend.8- 
 Appearance:  dark brown into black. Bone white , lighter top with lace.
 Palate / Taste:  medium bodied. Soft , musky, earthy, gentle carbonation. Quiet mild yet not boring. Bit of mystique feel found in here. Perfect daily choice. Splendid offering.

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass. Color was brownish black, but closer to black. Just over an inch of head. Tannish white lacing with some sporadic bubbles in there. Healthy amount of film on the sides.

Smelled dark chocolate malts. Also coffee, caramel and toffee in there as well.

Tasted malts, but couldnt distinguish the favorite. If a gun was to my head, Id say dark chocolate. Definitely dark malts, but relatively bland overall. Nice smooth finish. 

Medium body. Creamy finish. Average carbonation. Smooth abrupt finish.

A decent beer overall. Nothing too special, but it gets the job done. Id give it another go some time.

Bomber bottle.  Quickly dissolving dirty sandy head with covering but thin and fast lacing over a dark red body.  Fragrant soap, with notes of funky fish, grocery aroma.  Mildly sweet taste like sweet milk chocolate.  Palate is medium thin body with good carbonation and pleasant feel.  Overall, OK.  Draught is better.
Dark thin mouth with good blend of flavors to a faint chocolate-coffee flavor. Alwats This is one of  my stand by beers
Dark brown color with a thin head.  Resiny, earthy and roasted aroma.  The taste is chocolatey in this light to medium bodied brew.  The finish is chalky and bitter.  Interesting beer overall.

Location/Date:Bottle on January 7th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours like cherry coke with light head. 
Aroma: Aroma is of roasted malt.
Taste: Decent amount of hops, nice roast taste, faint chocolate.
Palate:Slick body.
Summary: I enjoyed this beer, especially for its alcohol percentage.
dark appearance.  roasted malts and a slight taste of chocolate.  slightly sweet.  a fairly decent dark beer.  good for a winter session.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 1/4/12


Aroma: The nose is mostly malty, made up of caramel, roasted malts notes, bread, fruit, and a little spice

Appearance: A clearish brown color with a slight red-orange hue and a creamy beige head and heavy lacing

Flavor: The taste is fairly sweet, with a caramel malty presence backed-up by some other malty components

Palate: Medium bodied (leaning toward the light side), a smooth and creamy feel, and a great drinkability

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty nice beer overall.  It has a clean, smooth malty flavor that works really well.  The caramel malts, and the other malty components, combine together to make a quality offering.  This one may not be the most extreme or complex beer out there, but it seems to be rather well made.
Dark brown with small tan head.  Malty sugary aroma.  Medium body, a little sticky.  Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, malts, slightly too syrupy but still pretty drinkable.  Ok.

Decent sized off-white head of fine bubbles.  Distinct aroma of black licorice when you first pour the brew.  Dissipates to a malty aroma with some light chocolate and dark fruit.  Color is a very dark brown with a reddish hue.  Moderate body and maltyness.  More light chocolate, toffee and some soft biscuity malts.  Pretty soft and velvety mouthfeel.  Certainly a brew that you can drink easily without a lot of dryness and bitterness.

Dark red-ish color, coffee and chocolate hits the palate, good winter ale, mild spice, not bitter...not my favorite New Belgium ale, but not bad either.

Enjoy-ability - 7.8 out of 10

Bottle. Pours deep mahogany red with very little head. Aroma is toasted bread and fruit. Flavor is dominated by roasted malt and mild chocolate. A smooth and easy to drink beer for a wintry night. Would go well with nuts, fruit or salty snacks.

Nearly black in color, mild chocolate character, hops are similar to a stout, but this beer is lighter bodied. I do like this style, stout flavor without the thickness. Very little head, but that is not necessarily a bad thing with this one. A hint of olive in the aroma.

Look - Similarities  to the fat tire... hmm, possibly the yeast?  Khaki, creamy head, always nice when the froth tastes good.  Dark in color.  Taste has very mild roastyness, not much else.  Taste is big malty flavor, chocolate, roasty reaching for some coffee notes.  Not much hops at all, so theres not much balance.  Its kind of like a European beer, but without the underlying honey flavor.  Palate is kind of dull, not sure why it receives so many high marks.

Has an aroma of chocolaty malt, along with some herbs that I cant discern. Upon sipping some more, there is some strong caramel as well. The palate is pretty good; smooth, and strong bodied. A pretty good beer.
Pours true to its name with a persistent tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Pitted fruit sweetness on the tongue.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep mahogany, almost black in color. Relatively thin tan head that stands up. Nose of sweet malt, molassas, a bit of roasty notes in there. Smooth, very silky mouthfeel. Due to the use of lager yeast, no yeast in the profile. More raosty, toasty in the flavor than in the nose. A much better dark lager than the Guiness Black lager. An interesting beer.
From the tap poured a dark brown color with a good amount of head.  Toasted malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Bottle.  Different label than that in the picture.  Best before:  04/08/12.  A mahogany pour with a skim of a khaki head.  Cocoa, caramel, toasted pumpernickel, and a little grapefruitiness in the aroma.  Thin to medium-bodied.  Cocoa, caramel, and plenty of toasted maltiness start things off taste-wise.  Some bitter roasted coffee towards the end.  Touches of yeastiness here and there.  Kinda earthy.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head and decent lacing. Aroma is malty. Taste is malt, chocolate, some coffee. Very easy to drink.

12 oz. bottle in a weiznen glass pours clear, dark mahogany with a light brown head and decent lacing.  Lightly roasted malt aroma; chocolate and roasty; a bit musty.  Light medium body and oily texture . Taste lightly bitter with a very long dry and lightly burned finish.

Thanks to one of my cousins who brout this over for Thanksgiving.  With a bottle that apes Westvleterens, it better be good.  Good sized head on a dark brown pour.  Pleasant, bready aroma.  Fairly dry, with some esters, a little grain, and tobacco in the taste.  I like the story behind this beer.  It is good, but not what it purports to be.  It is fairly light and balanced, and is not a quad.  A good Belgian for the American palate.
A very fine malty stout, thick, they should serve it with a knife and spork. I want to grow a mustache for the sole purpose of serving as a flavor savor for 1554.

Pours a brown/copper color with a light tan head. The aroma is mostly of malt. The flavor contains a lot of coffee and chocolate, some dark fruit like prune and a solid roasted malt to give the coffee and chocolate a lot of fullness. Little or no hops. Medium mouthfeel and a flavor that seemed consistent from beginning to end.

Pours black with a medium tan head...nice lacing.  Aroma is lightly roasty...doughy...mild chocolate.  Flavor is slightly less roasty...notable chocolate...some yeasty notes...not much flavor really.  Mouthfeel is light and silky and the finish is mildy roasty.
Bottle from random refridgerator. Pours dark brown with a thin white head. Not much on the nose. Some malt and raisin notes on the tongue. Finishes clean.

Bottle->dimpled mug: pours a huge, rocky, brown head atop a clear, but dark brown body.  Aroma of yeast and some sweetness.   Dry on the palate, mildly sweet, and bitter, finishing with a syrupy mouthfeel.  A nice beer and one that should be enjoyed not quite as chilled as what would be otherwise expected.
Pours a nice black with a fair light tan head and some lace.  Aroma is of malts, caramel grains and a hint of vanilla and coffee.  Nice flavor, roasted malts, caramel, bread and a little vanilla.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XzxSgbmdSdA
<br Deep mahogany, ½-finger head, average lacing
<br\><br\>
Aroma: Fig, plum, caramel malts, licorice, bittersweet chocolate, hint of raisin + espresso 
<br\><br\>
Flavor: Medium body, sweet campfire smokiness, bittersweet chocolate, banana, plum, raisin, dark grape, spruce, hint of mint on finish, mint residual, crisp yet creamy, medium carbonation, mild bitterness
<br\><br\>
Pairings: Carbonara, mussels

Pours dark brown, ruby in the light, with a sizable off-white head. Nose is roasty, caramel, chocolate, and a little smoke. Taste is moderately sweet with some bitterness. Palate is light to medium, fairly thin, and clean finishing. It has quite a bit of complexity, yet is easier drinking. Its like a light belgian dubbel or almost similar to a dark lager. A solid, sessionable offering.

Whole Foods, P St, DC sixer ($10): Pours a dark brown color with a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is roasty like, and in my opinion, by the nose alone does not give a sufficient indication of what will be contained inside the glass. Upon tasting this, things get good. Roasted malts and chocolate are the most prominent aspects. However, I even got things like smoke in a few sips. Subtle and pleasant aftertaste is left in the mouth.  Not exactly sweet. Mild astringency. Light bodied, yet full-flavored. Im glad they pulled this one out of the history books.

Dark dark dark mahogany with a nice big tan head with very tight bubbles... laces nicely, and/or im an excellent glass dryer... malty chocolatey, roasty, chocolatey, light coffee, kinda of has a mild mocha coffee aroma.. fairly roasty, lighter body, more coffee than chocolate, but neither are that robust... nice easy drinking roasty light chocolate beer with a quick finish...

pours deep chestnut brown with a thin tan head. nose of molasses, chocolate, port, and dark fruit. Loads of roasted malt, bakers chocolate, nuttiness, and molasses. long, roasted-malty finish. very enjoyable.
Bottle. Looks like a coke. Smells roasty- kind of like coffee and maybe some chocolate. Lighter than it looks. Nice and dry though, with the roast coming through.

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish-brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate.  Sweet chocolate flavor with a hint of roasted malts.  Reminds me of chocolate milk, the mouthfeel is even kind of creamy.  Smooth, malty but slightly chalky finish.
deep brown pour with a creamy tan head. smells of cocoa and roasted malts. medium body with flavors of chocolate and coffee. burnt finish. very solid brew.
25 oct 2011, bottle. Really dark but brown. Nose is strong dark chocolate and wet bread. Med body and fizzy. Tastes like eating chocolate beans. Nice balance b/w dark chocolate and breast malt. Nice

355ml bottle pours almost black with a bold beige head with great retention and some really nice lace on side of glass.  Aroma is roasted malts and some chocolate.  The taste is roasted malty chocolate with a decent amount of hoppy bitterness.  For such a dark beer this one is pretty tasty and very easy going down.  Recommended.

22 oz bottle.  Pours near-black with some visible carbonation and a bubbly tan head.  Aroma is very roasty/nutty, almost smells like peanut butter, with some chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt, some smokiness, and some dark fruit.  Medium mouthfeel, a bit oily, finishes dry.  I didnt expect to like this as much as I did.

Tasted on tap at Blueberry Hill, St Louis, Missouri, USA. Clear, very dark reddish brown color with firm, lasting beige foam, good lacing. Ive never had such a dark beer that tastes like this. Lager fermentation finishes it cleaner, crisper, and less fruity than dark ales, porters, and stouts. Roasty flavors of unmalted barley, dark coffee and chocolate. Light-medium body, complex mouthfeel and neutral finish. Interesting and tasty.
By far the best black ale ive had to date. This beer is not to thick but has a big body flavor.

Pour is dark reddish brown with moderate white head.  Aroma is roasted malt with a hint of dark chocolate.  Flavor is sharp roasted malt with a smooth, subtle sweetness on the finish.  I wish the body was heavier, but overall pretty decent.

tap poured in a 16oz fluted pint glass. thick off white head, medium lacing, beautiful dark dark amber. Smell cigarette ash, toffee, grass, malt. taste Iron rust, black pepper, toffee and a hop-flavor like an altbier. medium/heavy carbonation.

Rich, dark brown, almost black color with a large tan head with a lot of tight bubbles. The aroma is of roasted malt and chocolate with a touch of caramel and bitterness. Though the smell is a little faint. The flavor, however, is nicely chocolately with mild malt that is just a touch subdued. A very nice tasting beer that I would definitely drink on a regular basis. Its a flat beer out of a bottle almost as if this was draft.

Rich, dark brown, almost black color with a large tan head with a lot of tight bubbles. The aroma is of roasted  malt and chocolate with a touch of caramel and bitterness. Though the smell is a little faint. The flavor, however, is nicely chocolately with mild malt that is just a touch subdued. A very nice tasting beer that I would definitely drink on a regular basis. Its a flat beer out of a bottle almost as if this was draft.

Ok Im a believer now!  Ive been trying several black ales and just havent found one that truly tempted my taste buds. That was until I enjoyed this 1554 Enlightened Black Ale by New Belgium brewing company in Fort Collins, Colorado. The beer is a lovely dark chocolaty brown with the scent of chocolate and dark roasted coffee and topped off with creamy tan-colored head that is not too thick nor is it too thin. Upon my first taste my taste buds went into total shock.  Did I really taste what I thought I tasted or was I just dreaming?  But the second taste confirmed it!  Flavors of strong coffee (much like espresso), chocolate and subtle hints of bitter malt.  One taste led to another and then there were none!

This is definitely one going into my Beer Hall of Fame!!

Bottle picked up in NC. Pours out a dark brown color with a small white head. Aroma is of roast, some chocolate, and dried fruits. Taste is of dried fruit, light chocolate, some slight roasty notes, mild yeast pumpernickle bread. Solid brew
Draft at Churchkey.  Aroma of chocolate covered pine needles.  taste is bitter cocoa, coffee grounds.  Nice roasty and bitter balance.  Nice one!

4oz draft from a flight at Hangar 9. Pours a dark black with a bunch of thick tan head. Aroma of coffee and black licorice. Taste is lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Starts sweet with milk chocolate and ends bitter with coffee. Medium bodied with a thick creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long bitter finish. Overall, very awesome. Absolutely something to drink again.

Truly fantastic it tastes and smells the way chocolate would if you could smoke the stuff the same way you smoke ribs, hard to beat especially at its price point

Aroma: Like warm chocolate dipped bread, slightly smokey and very warm

Appearance: Black and thick with a descent head

Taste: Not bitter in the slightest, notes of chocolate smoke and coffee. Not bitter in the slightest with very little flavor of hops which is my one and only complaint but that is well outweighed by its overall quality.

Palate: Smooth, pure liquid velvet 

.

A: The beer pours a very dark brown color with some reddish highlights and a khaki head.

S: A nice balance of roasted malts and sweet, caramel ones.  There is a nice creamy caramel note all the way through.  A nuttiness, almost like peanut butter, is also present.  Just a little earthy hops.

T: Slightly fruity, but otherwise, same story as the nose.  Nice light roast, toast, and caramel balance to this one.  A mild nuttiness, a hint of yeast, and some perfectly sweet toffee.

M: Medium bodied with a smooth carbonation.

O: One of New Belgiums best beers, actually.  Really solid stuff.

Beer pours a dark brown body with a light tan head that leaves great lacing behind.  It smells of chocolate and with maybe a touch of smoke to it.  It tastes of chocolate with a bit of nuttyness in it as well.  I thought before trying this beer that the abv was higher but it is only about 5.5% and such an easy drinking sessionable beer.  A beer I would seek out again if it was available to me thankfully i heard rumors New belgium is coming to Florida!
This ones a charmer.  Pours black and thin with little head.  Aroma is light roasty malts and candi sugar sweetness.  Taste is medium sweet with spicy hop finish.  Simple but unique and tasty.

1554 pours deep dark brown black with with a nice head of bubbles that leaves a very pleasant lace.  Nose is faint and somewhat watery.  Taste is a very mild but not weak malt presence with hints of caramel.  Body is medium, thin average carbonation finish is just a bit bitter.
Malt aroma is clean but mild. Pours a heavy red with a good tan head. Nice pacing. Body is full with a delicious roasted, chocolate flavor. Chocolate stays on the tongue and finishes clean too.

Sampled from 12 oz. bottle. Dark brown brew, translucent, with a good khaki head. Aromas of coffee, sugar, vanilla, and other tasty treats. A smooth, creamy texture reveals layers of flavor that include the rich chocolate sweetness of dark malts and the prickly bitterness of old world hops. Aftertaste is hoppy and lingers pleasantly. This is well worth a try.

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass dark, almost black, nice head. Hoppy-dry aroma. Starts malty and dry, scratchy, notes of liquorice. Finish a bit woody, but well balanced. Quite drinkable. Good beer!

Very dark brown pour with a pretty, very thick light tan head. Aroma holds pleasant roasted malt, chocolate, cream, and some nice balance between sweet malt and roasty bitterness. Flavor holds really beautiful cream presence, milk chocolate, and some pleasant caramel undertones. Reminds me a bit of a baltic porter. Light to medium body, low effervescence, very drinkable. Nice stuff.

On tap during 2011 Craft Lager Fest.  Very dark transparent brown pour with a light khaki head.  Aromas of black malts, chocolate licorice, and light molasses.  Flavor is a tad light though, but has toffee, cocoa, toast and very mild bitterness.  Interesting, but would be better if it had more body.
This dark ale reminds me a lot of black lagers.  Its definitely good, but worth the fuss?  The body is medium and the color dark like cola.  Nice malty/roasted notes.  Good, but not great.

Bottle. Pours black with thin tan head. Aroma is roasty, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is good, not too sweet, not too bitter, with smooth roasted malt flavor. Medium body and mouthfeel is accurate. Average length finish, relatively soft carbonation. Overall I like this one.

Bottle in Death Valley.
Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma moderate malty, caramel, roasted, black malts, and hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet, medium+ bitter. Medium body.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.
Black as the devils heart. A little bitter with deeply roasted caramel malts and perhaps something of (very) dark chocolate as well.
Tap at Brew Haven festival.  Sweet roasted malt aroma. Cola brown, medium tan head. Earthy, sweet malt flavor. Medium body.

12oz bottle. Another decent brew from NB. Little bit of a malty, bready aroma, but its rather weak. Looks great, very dark red and some decent lacing. The chocolate malts are most noticeable in this one which is nice, but other than that, theres not much more complexity to it. The more it warms the more the malts show up so dont drink this one ice cold. Overall its a good brew but not the best offering from New Belgium in my opinion.

Deep brown ruby hue clear pour beige head .... aroma is of chocolate and roasted malts .... taste is a good amount of sweet chocolate malt caramel malt and roasted coffee dry roasted finish ... not a bad dark brew medium bodied was a good dessert brew

Bottle: Porsche very dark reddish brown color with a light tan head.  It has the aroma of a very soft... Light chocolate, maybe a little malty sweetness.  The flavor is about the same as that... Light, sweet chocolate.  It doesnt have that bitter bite that youd expect looking at the beer.  It still leaves your mouth clean like a lager would... Great beer!

Deep brown with almost no head. Suprisingly thin for such a dark beer. Chocolate and coffee malts, but overall the aroma is lacking. Theres nothing on the nose, even after warming it up a bit. In my mind it doesnt justify the high ratings others have given.

12 oz. bottle. Pours black with amber hints and a thin tan head. The aroma is  smooth chocolate, cinnamon, peat and earth, a little roasted malts, and dates. The flavor is sweet and pleasantly spicy throughout, with a slightly bitter aftertaste. The palate is light to medium, crisp and lively, and very clean. Overall, this beer is easy to drink yet pretty complex.

I like how they took a dark lager and gave it a delicate yet slightly sweet malt profile which makes it an easy drinker but still has a variety of flavors at the same time. Aroma is my favorite part with the chocolate malts standing out with some hop presence. I want to thank the guy from Colorado at Chips in OBX for pointing this beer out.
No smell but it has the taste of chocolate and coffee its deffenetly worth trying

Pours a deep brown with ruby hints. The head is very large and fluffy and leaves sheets of lace on the glass.
