Wow there is a lot of stuff going on in this aroma, roastines, nuttiness, cavendish, mustiness, toast, all this sort of homogenizes a bit after a bit though and its not as pleasant to shove your nose into the glass as it was right at first. The flavor is fairly porter-like but fruitier. The beer features a nice shade of roasty bitterness throughout, the dark fruit is abound and some of that cavendish shows up here in the flavor as well. The hops are largely herbal and largely pushed to the background in favor of malty/yeasty complexities. Speaking of yeast, this beer has a nice banana character to it, not in a sweet or cloying way, its subtle but its quite nice. After a while some cherries and woodiness come to the party. Its a nice beer, I had neglected it for the last few years & I really didnt suspect that I would like it as much as I have in the past, the truth is that I think I like it more now than I ever did.
Smells like toasted Malts. Poor kinda flat or at least very light carbonation. Taste sweet very litter hops sweet toasted Malta. Ok.

Nice deep copper color.  Sweet aroma of brown sugar, spices, and hops with a somewhat earthy undertone.  Flavor is mostly caramel and biscut with spices, raisin, and hints of chocolate.  Slight tartness at the end that hangs, mild carbonation, easy to drink.

Pours a dark brown, slightly opaque. Nose is toasted malt, toasted marshmallow, and yeast. The flavor is toasted malt, barley, and a slight vegetal (carrot?) note. Slightly sweet. The finish is dry, but ends extremely quick. You have to get halfway through the bottle before it cloys enough to stay around. Finish is a little disappointing in this regard. Its also extremely watery on the mouth-feel. Overall good beer, though.
Pours a deep mahogany brown with minimal head. Aroma is of dark coffee and maple. Taste is malty sweet like syrup and finishes with a touch of spice.

Bottle. Dark copper brown pour which leaves a foamy kahki head that fades to a spotty film and collar. Aroma is nice roasted malt and faint potatos. Taste is more roasted malt and mild spice and biscuit. Palate is thin yet very chaulky and finishes dry. Cant complain.
Light body, roasted like a porter. Not very dark, allows hop character but nit much bitterness. Actually a little boring but a good solid brew

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2011 Pours a dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, some hoppiness. Flavor is dry; caramel, earthy, creamy, with a bitter chocolate finish. Incredibly drinkable. Great beer.

Ive been looking for this for a while, and I got it via a trade with Blutt59.  The aroma is roast, chocolate, earth, wood.  The appearance is deep brown, cream color head.  The flavor is more chocolate, or maybe cocoa or carob, caramel, brown sugar, fruit, wood.  Sweeter than the aroma indicated.  Medium in body maybe slightly thicker, creamy mouthfeel.  The finish is a solid pine and citrus hop bitternesss, which lingers.  Excellent.  Im always eager to try traditional ales, and this is a great beer in its own right.  Thanks, Bob.
a tasty and toasty black ale with plenty of flavors and chocolate going on here def. worth a sip
Dark brown, almost black.  Bready/toasty aroma, sort of chocolaty.  Very mild taste.  Pleasant. Unassuming.

Rich, dark brown, almost black color with a tan head.  The aroma is of roasted chocolate with a bit of caramel, though the smell is a little faint.  The flavor, however, is nicely chocolately with mild malt that is just a little subdued.  A very nice tasting beer that I would definitely drink on a regular basis.

~Biscuity, grainy aroma with oatiness and light earthy hops.
~Pours a deep red with small light brown head.
~Biscuity malt flavor milk chocolate and molasses notes, earthy hops.
~Medium light body, med high CO2. malty finish with light lingering bitterness.
~Ok brew. Carbonation was way too high.

Bottle. Poured dark brown with tall still head. Nutty aroma with a hint of apple spices and cloves. Sweet bready taste. Slight bitterness keeps it light tasting. Medium dry finish. Light body and texture. Med/low carbonation. An enjoyable and different brown ale.

Dark brown, nearly black pour with a tan foamy/fizzy head that dissipates quite quickly. Aroma reminiscent of a lighter porter or stout, mostly chocolately malt. Not much picking up much for hops on in the aroma. Taste mostly follows the nose heavy on the malt side, primarily chocolate with a hint of caramel. Mouthfeel is lighter than a porter or stout along with moderate carbonation. Overall, nothing really stands out as great here, however there are no serious faults to be found either. An extremely easy drinking beer with no traits that would prevent me from enjoying it again in the future.

Every once and a while you find a complete disconnect with what you experience with a beer and what, apparently, everyone else gets.  Such is the case with my third, yes, third attempt at enjoying a pint of 1554.  How can being Enlightened cause such befuddlement?  Dark and red-brown but not quite black, 1554 produces a lovely off-white head that is indeed sexy.  The nose, not so much, weak and hinting and roasted malt and some coffee.  The texture is surprisingly thin, which kills any lasting chance for the flavor to make an impression.  Classic dark beer notes flit about in the brew, but fail to hook up with any yeasty Belgian spice.  Pretty disappointing pint.  What am I missing?  (1/18/09)

Tap @ New Belgium hub, DIA. Pours black, but tranperent, with a white head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, light citrusslike hops. Taste is caramel, nuts, raisins, malt, nuts and lightly bitter hops. Medium body, soft carbonation. 140411

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 Very good beer. I dont think many people will find it too strong or too bland, regardless of their preferences. It is balanced, tasty, really easy to drink, and yet its got some degree of complexity going on. I love the malty, chocolatey aroma/taste, which has got some fruitiness to it (and a hint of caramel if I recall). I would have given it higher marks if it were of a stronger flavor, and it definitely lacks some body, but otherwise it does a very good job. It has got enough carbonation to give it a nice palate.

Very nice.
Aroma and flavor reminds me of a little of a Schwarzbier.
Malty, toasty.  Am I detecting a touch of raisin flavor?
Just enough hops to bring down the sweetness.
I like it

The beer pours a black color with a tan head. The aroma is heavy on the roasted malt and chocolate. An extremely malty beer that smells like a stout. The flavor is a mix of chocolate, ash, roasted malt, coffee and cream. A great mix of flavors that all meld very well together. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice Belgian-style stout. One of the better year-round New Belgium beers.

pours deep black slightly off white one and a half finger head, that goes quick but leaves good lacing. smells like chocolate. medium bodied, drinks slick. chocolate flavors with slight roast. good beer. really sort of in between. i like that this exists.
Tried this beer at the Casanova Beer Cave Festival (2011), had a pleasant taste.
A very nice dark beer. Can taste the dark chocolaty malts. Can also taste the coffee and nuts flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2013 Almost black, with ruby highlights and a huge, lacing foamy head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and spice. Taste is malty with a slight chocolate character. Medium and softly carbonated. Pretty good stuff.

Poured from a 12oz bottle.  Pours black with some beige head.  Aroma is chocolate and toasted malts.  Taste is similar to the nose.  A dry mouth on this one.  This was one of my go-to beers for years before I became exposed to many other craft beers.  Still very good, but suffers somewhat due to the competition.
Very good black beer. Nice malty taste. Good overall beer.

On tap at the brewery. August 2009. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a deep dark brown with an off white head that has some pretty good retention. The nose brings forward some light chocolate and dark fruits. The taste is slightly roasty with some dates, plum, and chocolate. Good mouthfeel with nice carbonation levels. Drinks nice and easy.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-29-2010

Poured into my New Belgium etched snifter glass. Color is pretty close to black. Head is thin, but nice and the etched glass keeps it going. Good lacing down the glass. Aroma is mild, but of roasted barley. Flavour is very smooth, mostly malty, some chocolate, and coffee flavours with a slight bitterness. Palate is medium bodied and has a long finish. Overall a decent dark ale that is surprisingly light and appealing.

This is another beer that is darker than i feel it should be.  when I buy a dark beer I want full flavour and a rich colourful finish, this however is kind of dull. Do not get me wrong its a pretty good beer and serving it at or slightly warmer than the bottle suggests will make the experience a bit more worth while.
On Tap at Map Room.  Pours dark amber with malty nut notes that show deep bread on the palate.  There are some light notes of fruit that show into the finish.

A clear, dark copper pour with a rocky, tan head.  It has a woody aroma with some dark chocolate.  The medium body has an oily texture with average carbonation.  The taste is mildly sweet with a semi-dry finish.

12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is a dark brown opaque color with medium off-white head.  Aroma is primarily the roasted malts with some nuts, toasty breads, and hint of fruitiness.  Taste is surprisingly subdued for such a dark ale.  The flavors are centered around the roasted malts with a noticeable nutty and cereal taste.  The hop presence is only slight with a mainly earthy character.  Palate is medium with nice carbonation, perfect mouthfeel making it very drinkable beer.
Best US beer.  You will enjoy the New Belgium 1554 best in a glass.  Smoth teast  and is not hoppie.

Great brew from New Belgium.  Pours a dark, dark brown, with a foamy tan head that dissipates rather quickly.  Aroma is somewhat faint with hints of nuts and light caramel.  Wonderful taste with a chocolate finish.  Very smooth and velvety on the palate.  Would definitely drink again

Bomber bought at BevMo a year and a half ago ($2.79).  Pours a dark brown with ruby red highlights and two fingers of beige head.  The carbonation is intense with lots of small bubbles sticking to the inside of the glass, giving this the appearance of Pepsi.  Aroma of stale toast, dusty roasted malts, chocolate, some dark fruitiness, and a hint of ash.  Flavor has long-lasting lightly sweet chocolate, roasted malts, toasted nuts, a bit of smoke, and hints of dark fruit.  Medium body with some lingering chocolate.  Nicely complex and readily drinkable.  (1282, 476)
black with tan head. aroma and flavor are of mild coffee and nut. could be a porter but for the lack of intensity of flavor. i actually thoght this was a shwartz beer.

Overall a wonderfully made beer.  Full of malty goodness and one that can be drank over and over, never growing old.  Not so big that ones the limit.

chocolate, roasty
Dark, Ruby when light held to it, white foam
Malty, hints of chocolate
Light body
Creamy off white head over a black (but not opaque) pour.  Nice chocolatey toasted aroma.  Pleasing small bubble mouth feel with a sweet malt chocolate finish.
Probably my favorite mass produced product from NB.  Pours carbony and black.  Relatively thin with notes of chocolate and yeast.  Only slightly hoppy.  Fairly robust for a black ale.
probibly the best thing in NBBs line up.  smokey and malty like guiness, but  with a slight sweetness. almost like an odd porter. not my cup of fermented goodness

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2015 Really good beer for the price.  Easy drinking for a darker beer.  Pours deep brown from a bomber with a generous head.   Pairs well with strong cheeses- can stand up to assertive flavors.  Coffee and chocolate come through in the finish, but doesnt have a heavy mouthfeel and not overly spicy like some darker beers.   Could be a bit more hoppy for my palate, but easy drinking and smooth if not spectacular.   Would pair it with a spicy chili dinner next time.

A very dark pour with a small, tan head. The light allows a dark amber color through.

S: A toasted and smokey smell. Some sweetness.

T: Smokiness dominates, though hints of sweeter flavors and alcohol are apparent.

M: Rather light bodied and smooth, hence the name I suppose. There is something of a creamy finish, but it still goes down well.

D: Quite drinkable, more than one might expect. It goes down rather well. There is some lingering taste, but its light enough for multiple. Certainly one of New Belgiums better brews, in my eyes.

(beer tasting @ Montys Krown - Rochester, NY: bottle - 12 oz) Dark brown, almost black pour, with a frothy off-white head. Sweet and malty aroma with nice hints of chocolate, coffee and some dark fruits and spice. Flavor is just as complex. Mild chocolate and coffee balance with a very mild roasted note mixing with a light fruit sweetness and a lightly bitter spice finish. Very easy drinking.
Spectacularly average. I dont know what they were trying to replicate here, it is bland, generic, whatever.

Bottle served in an English pint. Pours very dark amber-brown. Large khaki head of good retention and very nice lacing. Sweet malty aroma of chocolate, dates, nuts, and roast. Mild sweet, mild roasty flavor. Medium body, oily-thin texture, soft carbonation, and a short finish.

Poured into a New Belgium "globe" glass.  Color is dark brown black with a tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma is roasty and chocolatey with coffee notes.  Flavor is sweet caramel malts with nice chocolate notes.  Despite the appearance the body is very light.  Overall this is an excellent beer that has the flavors of a stout or a porter with the drinkability of a much lighter beer.

From bomber.  Pours dark amber/ruby with a frothy one-finger tan head.  Sweet creamy aroma of caramel and nuts.  Warm nutty biscuit flavor, with some dark chocolate.  Mild carbonation and medium body, with a lingering warmth.  Technically this bottle was past its expiration date, but I was surprised at how decent this beer was.  Quite enjoyable, especially for three bucks.

Deep brown with a tan head that quickly settles, but leaves lacing down the glass all the way to the finish. Aroma of caramel and sugars, one of the least hoppy New Belgium beers. The flavor is fairly light, mild sweetness transitions to mild bitterness. Medium-light bodied, not as good as i remember it, maybe paled in comparison to so many flavorful beers or maybe the latest brew is less bold.
An ale that hints at chocolate malts, mediumly malty, a pretty good, unique ale.
Looks like CocaCola. Very nice cream colored head that lasts. Not a strong aroma, but a wonderfully smoky flavor with chocolate and vanilla hints.

From a bottle, poured into a New Belgium globe glass - full, malty, smooth, balanced mouthfeel and taste. Low carbonation, low acidity. Caramel and light chocolate notes, neither is overpowering. Thick, dark, nearly opaque red-brown body. Latte colored head pours thick and quickly diminishes leaving a light lace that lingers . Easily drinkable, one of the most enjoyable New Belgium beers in my opinion. However, it does still have a hint of that curious "New Belgium" aftertaste (what IS that?? Kind of tastes like astringent dirt - all New Belgium beers seem to have it. Is it hippies??).

1554 is a great beer, and as a history buff the story behind it kind of gives me a beer hard on. haha, but on to the beer, The aroma is very slight, but nice. The Appearance is lovely, very dark, with a very well sustained head throughout your 1554 experience. the taste is very good. at first the brew has somewhat of a coffee taste, and a sweet chocolatey aftertaste. On the palate, the brew is very smooth and ideal in such a dark brew.

I highly recomend 1554, for someone just getting into darker beers, its not as heavy as most stouts, but a helluva lot heavier they most ales.
Pours a dark brown color with a light brown head. Smells of coffee. Taste is rich and flavorful. Has some nice coffee notes and malty tastes. Delicious
nice beer, brownish red por with beige head. nose is nutty with some choc. flavor is similar, easy drinking. interesting beer

12 ounce bottle-  the first thing I noticed was that this is a beautiful beer.  Mahogany brown with deep red highlights.  Had a khaki head as thick as an ice-cream soda that lasted the entire glass, ringed lacing until the end.  Rich smokey aroma, smooth, full pallet and a caramel/bitter flavor.  Very nice, very enjoyable.

12oz bottle.
Dark brown pour, minimal tan head.  Roasted malt, cereal aromas.  Nutty chocolate flavors.  Very interesting brew.

Very interesting brew.  Pours dark, dark brown, with a little red tint when held to the light.  Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel with a little bit of carbonation.  Flavors are dark chocolate with subtle, tart, fruity undertones along with roasted caramely malts.  All the flavors are well represented and balanced.  This is one of the better brews I have had from New Belgium.

Received in a trade with sfromdawes, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a dark brown, with ruby highlights. Two finger off white head dissipates quickly, but laces all the way down. Aroma hits with chocolate, coffee, some dried fruit and a little barnyard funk in the background. Taste is creamy chocolate, some fruit and some caramel. Full body, creamy mouthfeel, just enough carbonation the tease the tongue. Great tasting brew, not sure Id call it a Belgian Dark, but tasty just the same.

Bottle.  This was interesting fare.  A dark brownish-red pour released smells of bread and cereal.  The taste was a complex mix of roasted, caramel, and chocolate malts, touched off with a finish that was different, but a bit too carbonated for my liking. An enigma, but a great beer.

Beautiful creamy dark color.  Aroma was really pungent to me with a decent malty aroma.  Taste is well balanced medium sweet with a little sourness on the finish.  Palate is lighter than the beer appears, not really creamy, which makes it go down quite easily.

Poured into pint glass from bottle at cellar temperature. Weak but pleasant aroma of toasted barley. Beautiful dark amber color, looks black until you hold it to the light. Excellent foamy head that stays till the bottom of the glass with elegant lacing. Taste is bold, starting with a slightly alcoholic nip at the start, melting away to a warm roasty malt with faint sweetness. Finish is harsh, reminds me of burnt toast, burnt and bready. Mouthfeel is lighter than promised and I would have preferred a bit more body though the finish coats the mouth and lingers. Overall a fascinating experiment.

12 oz. bottle served in shaker- poured a darkened transparent brown, fluffy off white head formed, minimal lacing.  Aroma of coffee and nuts- alrighty.  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, malt was somewhat roasted by the feel, middle has some light chocolate, finish is somewhat lingering.  Nice.
This is a good solid beer. One of the staples in my fridge for several years now.
Not overly-complex, but works in terms of roasted and toasted maltiness. Strong chocolate and coffee tones with a smooth finish.

Very aromatic, chocolate and roast. Appearance good, with a good frothy head. The flavor is nice but not very complex. More clean than a typical dark beer, very little hop balance.  The palate is thin. Pretty nice beer but not great.

12oz bottle Pours a very dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma is malty, cocoa, and slightly charred. Taste is malty, with a nice creamy, smooth body. Hints of coffee and spices add to the flavor. Good Beer.

Bottle.  Clear mohogany brown with a film of beige head.  The aroma has some grainy dark chocolate, but it really comes out in the flavour.  There is roast, and something else in there too, maybe some berries.  Its on the sweet side, although the finish is relatively dry.  Medium-low carbonation.  Not bad, but it really doesnt stand out in a crowd.
Very thick and smooth. Color is very dark. Has a nice simple flavor. Good sipping beer.

Draft pour in lake Tahoe. Interesting story about this being an ancient medieval recipe. Makes me wonder how authentic it is, since it tastes just like other porters. Which for me, is a good thing. Another good beer from New Belgium.

On tap at the Alamo Drafthouse Lakecreek in Austin, TX. This is a curious beer from a curious brewery. The brewers are of course famous both for their faithful interpretations of complex Belgian styles and for their rather lowbrow offerings that serve as gateways (or, unfortunately, stopping points) for those just venturing beyond the shores of lake macrobrew. This starts as if it belongs in the former category, with rich roast aromas of chocolate and coffee. Yet the body is thin and the finish simple and unsatisfying. There is no Belgian yeastiness to speak of, and what might have been hopped enough to make a clean, bitter aftertaste - a la an American strong ale - merely passes itself off as clean because it is quick and unmemorable. A curious ale that is better than Fat Tire, but unworthy of the brewers better offerings.

Bottle and tap. From such a dark beer, I was expecting something a little stronger. The dark brown bee had a off white head that slowly diminished to a nice lace. The aroma was moderate, with oats, nutty malts, and some chocolate. The initial taste is a little sweet and lightly bitter, and had a long duration. I definitely got chocolate and a bit of coffee and nuts.
Flat roasted malt aroma.   Bitter roasted malt taste, fairly basic. Medium body strong aftertaste.  Rated higher than I would expect.
Dark brown pour with tan head and lace. Aroma is roasted malt and a bit of peat. Flavor is flat roasted/smoked malt with very subtle bitter. Medium bodied but a bit fizzy. Nice beer.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle and produced a good size head and a nice dark brown color. It has a cocoa aroma with maybe some caramel to it. Very smooth taste and medium finish. Very good beer.

This beer, though an ale, tastes like a stout made for people who hate stouts. And what I mean by that is the flavor of the beer is watery, without the gristle that a more formidable mouthfeel would have, and easy to drink for people who generally prefer fizzy fluff like Bud or Fosters. The chocolate undertone is definitely available, though not top drawer, and there is an unusual nutmeg sensibility to the beer that crawls over your taste buds like a furtive iguana on a bed of rocks. Not a terrible brew, but mediocre as all hell.
Pours dark brown with a bubbly off white head. Nose is roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit and toffee. Flavor is medium chocolate malts and a dry finish.
Part of a six pack that Shawnee sent me for my bday,  Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is caramel and coffee.  Taste is similar with notes of roasted malts.  Delicious.

THOUGHTS: Sort of like a Belgian take on an English mild. Very nice, but I was expecting something more unique, like the first time I had a sour ale or traditional ginger beer. This was more of a combo of other things that Ive tried. It also finishes almost a little too dry.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was nearly black in the glass with red highlights and a large, off-white head that mostly, but slowly diminished and left fair to good lacing. The aroma had moderate to heavy, cereal, oats, roasted and nutty malts, and chocolate milk; lighter chocolate and coffee; light yeast; along with a little soy sauce; licorice, cola and sort of a Capn Crunch thing going on. The initial flavor was sweet and slightly bitter; while the finish was rather sweet, light to moderately bitter and ever so slightly sour with a long duration. There was chocolate milk, cola, very bitter chocolate, very dark chocolate, yeast slight licorice, a little coffee, nuts, roasted malt, chocolate cake, chocolate granola and slight black cherry. The light to medium body was oily and then very dry with lightly fizzy carbonation and a lightly astringent and very dry finish.

Served: Poured from bottle to pint.

Aroma: almost like Mocha coffee, roasted nuts. Almost like a nice artisan bread

Appearance: absolutely beautiful deep pitch back amber color. Nice foam head though it does dissipate fairly quick.  It may not taste to much like an ale but is is definitely black.

Taste: With the aroma and color I expected more chocolate but no what you get is a smooth roast without a hint of bitter. 

Palate: I could drink this all day. medium body, creamy and light on the carbonation. Wonderful aftertaste that will stick without for awhile 

Overall: fantastic beer, it is highly drinkable and should appeal to almost any palate. I have not found many parings it does not work with. Recommended for anyone trying to get off the beaten path and into the real world of beer in all of its glorious verity.

12oz bottle pours dark cola in color with medium bubbly head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee roasted malts, nuts, and slight vanilla. Taste is similar to aroma, very smooth and well balanced , finishes with a nice bitter chocolate. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2010 Pours a black amber with a fizzy white head. The aroma is faintly of chocolate and other malts. Tastes malty, but not of chocolate, and the alcohol is not overpowering. Medium-bodied with a fizzy smooth texture and average carbonation, the 1554 Enlightened Black Ale finishes long and smooth with light bitterness that really completes the experience. I will definitely drink this again.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2010 This black ale is the best bang for your buck. For its taste and its price this beer is the complete package. When you are wanting a heavy beer full of flavor this beer completes the criteria.

Dark brown pour, large bubbles in the head.  Toasted aroma, actually reminding me of a vegetal wine aroma.  Smooth flavor from the moment it hits your tongue, gradually fading.   A touch of sweetness, but mainly just a smooth toasted flavor.  I like it, and could probably drink several in a row, but nothing amazing.

Pours opaque black with tan beige head. Aroma is roasty, with chocolate tones. Flavor is initially more roast nut flavor which turns to more chocolate tones on the finish. Palate is very nice, smooth and creamy, slightly silky. Overall quite nice, although nothing extraordinary. I would drink again on tap if I had the chance.

Very nice offering from New Belgium; pour gives way to attractive frothy head and aroma of sweet roasted malts; tastes is complex w notes of coffee and caramel, very nice mixture of flavors in this unique brew

ya gotta love new belgium, those wind-powered hippies really know how to brew an adult beverage!  this beer pours a deep brown, with a quickly dissipating head...looks like it would be a heavier beer but drinks very smoothly. tastes of carmel chocolate and malt...good stuff

Light head, quickly dissipating.  Aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate as well as in the taste where a slight bitter toastiness hangs around at the end.  I am not a big fan of many New Belgium offerings, but this one is quite nice.  Basically, a Belgian Stout.

Bottle:  Pours black, barely see through it.  Held directly to light there is a little amber on the edges.  Small tan head head dissipated quickly but left some decent lacing.  Initial aroma of coffee, followed by chocolate.  Taste of chocolate first with a coffee finish  a little smokey as it warmed up.  Nice and smooth and a little roasty nutty.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2012 Tasted from a 12 oz. bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Creamy, dark head with a very deep copper-black body.  Very sweet dark malty head and a slightly smoked dark malty body. Great beer.
Pours dark light a porter with a small off-white head.  Aroma of chocolate, smoke, and soy sauce.  Taste is chocolate, walnuts.  Complex black ale.  Pleasantly surprised.
on tap upstairs in brewery during the tour.  Pours a blackish brown.  tastes of delicious espresso, biscuits with bitter dark chocolate.  Real great beer id like to have again some day.

The flavor has some coffee notes but big on the chocolate malts. It has a pretty rich and bold feel

Aroma is sweet chocolate and a little hops

Pours a black color with some brown hues when you hold it up to the light. It has a nice mocha head and lots of sticky lacing

The finish has a strong chocolate finish. There is a sweetness that tends to linger. Not a bad beer but I wouldnt be reaching for this again anytime soon.

Very dark amber color.  Chocolate, coffee, vanilla, nut aroma.   Full lacy head.   Light sweetness with a bit of bitter near end.  Medium bodied.  Creamy texture.  This is really good.   Havent had too many black ales before, but I will try more now.  Will be lookin for this again.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2012 One of my favorite beers, the 1554 has light chocolatey notes that compliment the medium-heavy body and slightly bitter finish.  Never gotten to try it on tap, but I eagerly await the day.
Very smooth and roasty with just a hint of hops. Solid, but nothing especially groundbreaking.

Pours dark reddish brown/black with off white head, aroma of biscuit, dark malt, roasted malt.  Taste up front is some dusty chocolate, big bready biscuit middle, touch of caramel, and a roasted finish.  Not too bad!

Aroma is strong biscuit earthy. Smell like all the NB beers. Dark brown black. Small white head. Taste is interesting. It appears NB has found a way for me to enjoy the same overpowering biscuit flavor they put in all their beers. Very malt forward beer. Biscuit earthy chocolate. Just a slight hint of roastiness. Sweet. Bittering hops present to balance malt but that is all. Hops not for flavoring as far as I can tell. Palate is nice and medium+. LIngers nicely, coats tongue well. Overall, a unique beer with a definate NB taste. Good beer, I enjoy it more than anything else they produce.

Gifted a bottle and told it was too hoppy, however I opened it expecting something different... Not hoppy at all, actually quite malty but the finish is that of a Belgian and perhaps some yeast, I do note the bottle is "expired" by 3 weeks lol

Bottle. Pours a dark red-brown, almost opaque, with a creamy head. Smells of malt, spice (cardamom?), and figs. Taste is rich and dry, with espresso and date flavors along with amazing dark roast. Mouthfeel is surprisingly light and refreshing. Very very good.

1554 is a "dark", medium body lager.  Chocolate roasted malt, with a bit of smoke aroma.  Initialally more malt upfront followed by a slightly spice finish.  Overall the malts and hops used in this receipe are incredibly balanced.
This is my favorite beer in the New Belgium lineup. Great dark hoppy flavor that is surprisingly smooth. I recommend this one to all and I will continue to drink this wonderful brew

i was shocked or my taste buds have changed....new belgium is making a lot 
bigger batches of beer than when i used to live in the southwest...i think a lot of there beers taste different  than they used to taste ......... but this black ale is really good im very pleased with it over all and i buy lots of it !!!!!!!!

12oz. bottle poured into a pint glass. Best before date is October 24th. Pours dark brown with a half inch of light brown head that quickly dissipates. Minimal lacing. Interesting rich malt aroma. Chocolate and toffee with just a hint of coffee. Medium body and low carbonation. Seems a bit heavy for only 5.6% abv but the finish is clean enough to still make it easy to drink. Very smooth texture. The malt lacks some personality on the palate though. A little bit of coffee flavor comes through but other than that its just medium roasted malt taste. I would much rather this were a little lighter. It might make a good session beer then.
Pours a deep ebony color, nose is like toasted bniscuit with cocoa, taste is drinkable, mildly roasty, hint of chocolate, nice level of acridness.

Bottle.  Pours brown/ruby color with white head.  Smell is sweet and spicy with yeast overtones.  Caramel and burnt aroma as well.  Taste is roasted malts, caramel, and nutty.  Light body, soft carbonation, and very smooth.  An overall good brew.
full bodied.  not to thick but very rich flavor.  over all a good beer very drinkable.

Bottle pours deep reddish brown, nice 2 finger tan head that hangs around a while, very nice roasted malt aroma, soft carbonation, light slippery mouth feel, soft roasted malt taste, chocolate under tones, a very nice brew with nice balance

Trying to get my hands on as many New Belgium beers as I can, since South Florida doesnt get any. This was a pretty good place to start. The beer was light in body, nutty/barley aromas, and very drinkable.

Pours dark black almost opaque. Aroma is sweet roasted vanilla. Flavor is nicely balanced roasted malt with vanilla and a slight touch of cocoa and spice. I usually dont like this style but was pleasantly surprised by this Ales smoothness.

Considering that this is the least expensive beer in the 22 oz. premium line-up it certainly delivers on many levels.  The aroma is of chocolate malt, roasted grains, and a little smoke.  Dark brown pour with a small, creamy head with nice lacing.  Flavor is dominated by a dry chocolate sensation but  is of a medium body, which makes it a very flavorful session beer.  Something about it reminds me of my mothers cedar chest.  The hopping is just right for the style, not too bitter.  Thin texture, soft carbonation, and mellow, easy finish.  A nice change from the regular mouth-full-of-hops IPA.
1554 is a solid dark ale with a great carbonation for its personality.  For how dark it looks I would set this beer at medium to bold taste.  Enlightened black ale is the perfect name for this beer.
Very nice. Interesting style that pours a nice medium-black with good sized head. Taste is very smooth, with hints of chocolate and malt. At times sweet, but very toasty. Recommended.

bottle.  Pours opaque black with tan beige head.  Aroma is roasty, with chocolate tones.  Flavor is initially more roast which turns to more chocolate tones on the finish.  Palate is very nice, smooth and creamy, slightly silky.  Overall quite nice, although nothing extraordinary.  Still, very much recommended.

Caramel followed by toasty, nutty flavor and then a very strong chocolate flavor.  The strong chocolate aftertaste just sticks with you.  The second one was a bit colder and much more enjoyable.  Not my favorite style, but it was decent.
Ive had this a couple times, at Riddles and Blueberry Hill in St. Louis.  Its excellent paired with food.  Good, not great.

On tap at the Yard House in Phoenix. Seeing this is actually the reason I got the six pack. Otherwise, I would have gotten a pint. Incredible beer. Pours a dark brown with a latte head. Rich and complex. Starts off significantly chocolate and finishes with a coffee bitterness. Thick and creamy the whole way around. It is rare to get complexity like this in session-able ABV.
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2016 This is pretty good.  Complex-ish and rich but quite drinkable. It is nice to have the option for flavorful beers that arent 10% abv.  Serving: Bottle

12oz bottle, poured amber-black with a big foamy beige head. Nose is roast malt and dark cocoa, a little prune and coffee, a faint note of banana. Palate is nutty, liquorice, more roast malt, some sweetness in the mid-body. Dry, sharp and roast bitter aftertaste. Dangerously quaffable and a definite hit.

Brown, mahogany, and a wisp of black sits pretty under a café-late head with the consistency of whipped mousse. She is puffs and sticks in clumps to the sides of my glass while her middle half resembles a round marshmallow puff. A few swirls later and I am reveling in burnt toast, ash, charcoal, sweet mesquite crackling in the fire pit, licorice root, dates, figs, and burnt sugar sweetness. Her nose is light, refreshing, and invigorating; a culmination of all the sights and smells one enjoys while sitting bedazzled before fireplace. My first quaff is sweet, mild, and generous. Ive actually had the 1554 before, but it was at least a couple years ago and no tasting notes were involved. Licorice root extract mingles with liquid smoke and mesquite. Pumpernickel abounds both freshly baked and slightly burnt. My palate dries with ash and an almost rauche-like essence. Far from a one flavor aroma, she winds her way into prunes and dates immersed in home-made fudge as chocolate angel-food cake drifts on by. By no means is 1554 a heavy beer; each quaff is at the most medium-bodied with very little chewiness. Her smoke weaves while pumpernickel bakes, date and prune infused fudge cools, and chocolate cake tempts. Now, if all of that sounds good to you, than what are you waiting for? Get your hands on a New Belgium 1554 Black Ale and enjoy; you cant have mine because I already drank it.


If you are reading this New Belgium, Im waiting for you. Maybe not patiently, but surely.
Beers from this brewery have been hit or miss.  This one was surprisingly a hit.  I had in 12 oz bottle.
bottled. pours dark brown with a small tight light tan head. smells of chocolate, leather and toast. similar taste moderately sweet with a slick  lasting finish of chocolate.

Pours a black mahogany with a light brown mdium sized head, mostly lasting with some nice lacing. Nose is malt and caramel. Very creamy on the palate. Taste is coffee, chocolate and caramel. No hops flavor but finishes on a slightly sweet note. A very good beer that is a good companion to grilled meats, especially burgers and brats.

Tap at Billy Goat Bistro in Ouray.  Pours a dark ruby with big off white head and decent lacing. Aroma of roasted nuts and caramel malts.  Nice dark malt cháractor with just the right amount of sweetness. Despite its darkness finishes smooth and crisp.

Pours crystal clear dark brown with a big, dense, frothy off-white head.  Malty aroma with hints of berries and alcohol.  Sweet taste of roasted malt and caramel, a little sour bite on the end, and astringent alcohol finish.  Thin body, low carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a dark ruby/amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hints of chocolate. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Black; ruby highlights with medium cream-colored head. Very pleasant coffee and CO2 nose. Flavor leans a little chemical, but neutral malt, roast, and grippy minerals mostly obscure it. "FT" house flavor is mercifully absent.

Freshness date: Best before Feb. 27, 2009

Color is a deep amber, almost like a shade of blood. Pours a nice pillowtop head with great lacing.

Smell is off a smokey flavor and some coffee also. Taste is pretty similiar, something tastes like smoke here. Had a great balance between the malts and hops.

This is a very smooth beer and not and a lot lighter than I had expected. This beer leaves the mouth very, very dry.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-10-2008 00:44:26
Great black ale.  Tasted on tap at the brewery and in bottles.  Smokiness is the most balanced Ive tasted.
Bottle. This beer has a deliciously dark body and a full, satisfying flavor. The flavors a bit lighter than a stout or porter, but it has those same chocolatey undertones. Delicious.
Bottle.  Pours dark, dark brown.  Medium biege head.  Aroma of coffee with chocolate.  Tastes sweet and malty.  A good experience.
Bottled sample.  Great tasting beer. Nice carbonation.  Malty and slightly spicy taste.  Looking forward to another one

pours dark with a nice head. smells like coffee and chocolate, nice. tastes like malt, roasty, and coffee (upon further drinking, waay too much coffee) with a slight bitterness. i thought it was too carbonated at first, but i let it sit a little and it seems better. 

overall, pretty drinkable.
Flash got me this beer.  Wow, its like a chocolate bar!  Lite finish.  Very nice body and quality, overall; shabang!
Pours a deep mahogany with a dark tan head.  Roasted malt with coffee and chocolate scent.  Nutty also.  Very malty taste with powerful chocolate notes.

Deep dark pour from a 12oz bottle. Aroma of roasted malts, earth, and minerals. Creamy dark roasted coffee flavor, burnt malts, light sweetness in the flavor. LIttle hops, but a nice lingering burnt grain finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2010 Purchased on my trip to Nashville. Pours a deep copper-brown colour with a big beige head that is foamy, has great retention and lacing. Red highlights are seen through it. A nice blend of aromas of coffee and caramel with notes of hop and grainy malt. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel that is silky. The taste has cream, coffee notes, roasted malt, vanilla, mild caramel and chocolate. Not too rich in flavours, just well-balanced. I really like this one as a desert beer when you do not want too rich.

Verre de dégustation provenant dune bouteille de 12 oz dégusté au Mondial de la Bière 2010 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Odeur de caramel avec une pointe terreuse. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée voilée avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de noix avec une pointe de café. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #3053)

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with medium tan head that lingers around.  Roasted malts in the aroma.  Roasted malts in the taste, but a bit of coffee in the finish.  Slight bitterness.  Not bad at all, went great with a pizza!

Pours dark brown with a light tan head.  Aroma is malt with some roast coffee character. Taste is of good malt, roast coffee and sugar,   My favorite of the New Belgium line-up (sans the Lips of Faith series).
Sampled at Mondial 2010. Dark red-brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is brown malt, toasted malt, nuts and wood. Flavor is wood, nuts, toasted malt minimal hops and a sweet finish.

An interestingly nutty dark lager.  Facinating simply because I didnt really know what to expect.  If I stood back from this beer, Id probably say that there is a rich flavor, but it is thin - somewhat high in the carbonation.  Dark - almost black in color with a frothy white head.
Good beer from the draught. Bottles do not have the aroma or flavor for some reason? Pionner in Lauglin has it in the river bar.
Pours a dark black color with a off white head. The smell is if coffee, roasted malt and some chocolate. The taste is malty and very robust. A decent beer.

Dark, dark brown, but with a very light, but off-white head.  Aroma is of the chocolate malts by far, which prepares you for the taste of the same.  Finish is slightlly bitter and (weirdly) pleasantly harsh.
POurs a deep dark brown with small head.  Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee and earthy.  Taste is bittersweet.  Medium mouthfeel, this is a very smooth brew.
Very dark red/black opaque color.  Aroma filled with dark chocolate.  Malty chocolate flavor with good carbonation.    Good tasting beer that not too thick or strong.

Dark cola color with a very frothy, small, light tan head that retains well and leaves thick curtains of lacing. Roasty aroma with toffee, pils malt, and faint coffee. Sweet flavor, lots of roast, some chocolate, and a touch of coffee. Thin but heavy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Not bad.
Pours a dark cola brown wot a thin white head. Aroma is roasted malt some residual sugar sweetness. Smooth mouthfeel, a little thin. Interesting beer.

On tap at the Fox and Hound in S.Houston ina pint glass.  Hard to see in dim lighting, but the BT poured with no head.  The color is dark.  The smell is Malt, dough, and licorace.  The taste is Malt and licorace.  A little thinner and lighter than I had hoped.  Certainly, no bad tastes to it and easy to drink, just not that impressive.
Aroma is lacking, just some very mild malts.  Flavor is lightly sweet, with some initial bite and a nice, smooth palate.
Smooth, dark, melty, chocolaty ecstasy. Vanilla, delicious, amazing dream. Tastes like the year 1554.
chocolate, hay, roasty, herbs, leather, dough, earthy, butterscotch, raisin, black, cloudy, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation,

Everything about this beer was very mild, but put it all together and this was a very easy drinking smooth beer. This would be an excellent session beer at 5.6% ABV. It poured a clear brown, like a cola, with a creamy light tan head. There were nice orange highlights in the glass as light passed through. The aroma was mild with some chocolate and malt. The taste was slightly dry with a nice mild chocolate flavor along the lines of a cocoa powder. The beer finishes very smooth and melow with a mild chocolate flavor that just fades away. Very easy drinking beer.
Yummy malty black ale. Medium bodied. Smoky floral aroma with grass and bread. Rated 10/25/09

Pours a dark ruby brown with thick fluffy beige head.  Aromas of chocolate, toast, spice, plums, and toffee.  Mildly sweet toasty malt, toffee, and dark fruit lead into a very lightly bitter, spicy, herbal finish with coffee notes.  Medium body and creamy texture with average carbonation.  Relatively rich in flavor for how incredibly quaffable it is.  Very nice, especially for the price.

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  Slightly hazy dark amber with off-white head.  Aroma is both earthy and roasty.  It has a slightly sweet flavor on the tongue.  Fairly thick body, with average carbonation.  Goes down pretty easy.  I could drink this regularly.

Clear chocolate brown with thick frothy tan head and lots of lacing.  Strong coffee smell with some maltiness to back it up.  Balanced taste with some roasted coffee and a bit of bitterness.  Very creamy mouthfeel and exceptionally smooth going down.  Overall a great pleasure to drink.
Dark amber color with a thick off white head. A smoky flavor with a toasty coffee finish. Not as much flavor as I expected and not as good as I had expected.
This was a very good beer, especially for those who like darker beers. The taste was decent and the beer has a good body.

Bottle. Seems to be a dark amber color with a brown head.  Chocolate and woody smell.  Somewhat sweet chocolate and toffee flavor.  Got this in the New Belgium Folly Pack variety package, probably my favorite of the mix.  5.6% alcohol.
(12 oz. bottle). This sample is 2-3 years old. Chocolate, roasted coffee and some caramel are evident in aroma. Nice malt sweetness on the tongue with a dry-almost smoky finish.

Poured to fluted fest glasses at Brixies Spring Tasting in Brookfield, IL. with a clear, amber/brown color, average, off white/light tan foam, and minimal lacing. The aroma was toasty malt, with hints of nuts, cocoa, and caramel. The flavor was similar, adding some light hop bitterness that carried into the finish. Enlightened more by the story than the beer, but basically enjoyable.
Bottle: Pours very dark brown with foamy beige head that leaves lost of lacing. Aroma has lots of roasted malt. Light sweet taste with a medium body. Overall very clean and drinkable dark beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a brackish brown, if almost black. Nice malty aroma, slightest hops notes, with toffee and chocolate hints as well. Taste is chocolate malt, with some nuttiness. Not overwhelmed by the strong chocolate flavors, but a nice blend of flavors. Would recommend serving in the 50 degree range, to bring out the best in this black ale.
A clean, refreshing black ale, reminiscent of BB Porter, having a nuttiness not to overbearing to be a thirst quencher. I would call the body quite light. Slight sweetness to the taste.
Has a bit of a chocolate, coffee flavor. This beer claims to be brewed according to a 16th century recipe. Whether or not this is true, 1554 is a excellent beer, for a sophisticated evening.
Moderately toasted cracked wheat nose. Clear garnet brown, thin head. Roasted malt, ending with smoke, overly alkaline. Filmy mouthfeel. Quite bland.

12 oz bottle.  Pours deep red with an off-white head.  Aroma has a very toasty aroma, but nothing more specific.  Flavor has lots of toasty, nutty, and earthy flavors and some smoky and roasty tones.  Aromas not great, but the flavor is quite nice.
Pours a medium brown. Aroma and flavour of hazelnuts, caramel malts and yeast. Interesting one.

Got this in a great BIF package.  Pours dark brown with a slightly almond head.  Aroma is very malty with wood and nut.  Taste is very malty with a little nut and earthy tones.  Very nice beer but a bit on the heavy feel.

This poured a dark malt color with a hint of red. Great flavor for a heavier beer. I dont know exactly how to explain the taste other than it was a bit smokey and had a few good spices in it but not too many.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2011 Bottle. The pour was a deep rich black with a reddish hue, it had a small creamy off-white head that dissipated almost fully although it did have some fair lacing. 

The aroma was heavy of roasted chocolate malts a light sweet doughy yeast and a touch of resin hops with a hint of caramel and smidgen of coffee.

It tasted slightly sweet with a nice hint of chocolate in the beginning and finished with a nice bitter sweet flavor that had hints of chocolate, caramel and an had an ever so slight presence of dried fruit and hops at the end with the flavor fading quite fast. 

Mouthfeel was medium to full in body with the texture being very creamy at first then becoming mildly dry with a flat carbonation.

Overall a very tasty brew, great for sitting around a fire on a cold night or having with dessert after dinner.

Red/black color. Aroma is of dark fruits and chocolate. Thin body. Taste is interesting- dark chocolate (reminds me of hershey chocolate actually) with wine like flavors(?). Pleasant carbonation. Dry but a long finish.

Thin black pour with small tan head. Some rich roasted grain in the nose, along with a fruity lager yeast ester.  Flavors are sweet roasted malt, light toffee, dark fruity sweetness, brown sugar, with that fruity lager yeast dominating the finish.  The palate is a nioce balance of roasted grain, sugary sweetness, and fruity lager yeast.  Good stuff and easily repeatable.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Café Sveavägen, Stockholm. Deep amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is bread, fruits, wood and some mild grassyness as well as spices. Flavour is burnt sugar, mild sweet wooden notes, some bitterness and also mild toffee.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm, 25 Feb 2009) Dark brown colour with brief, beige head. Malty nose with toasty grain, raisins and dark fruit. Malty, slightly roasted taste with notes of chocolate, coffee, dark fruit and a mild, spicy bitterness in a fairly dry finish. Crisp and clean. Medium body. Nice and tasty beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a creamy, one finger, khaki head; head fades to lacing.  Interesting aroma of cracked wheat, toasted malt, wood, bitter cocoa, roasted almonds.  The toasted malt/almonds really come out to me here, great combo.  There is a bit of an earthy/mineral-like component as well.  Finish is bitter black coffee with a splash of cream.  Medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and a low-medium level of carbonation.  To me, this is one of the most pleasant beers to simply drink.  I liked this one quite a bit, definitely a rebuy.

The aroma is roasted and sugary. Flavor is moderately sweet earthy and spicy. Slight notes of coffee/chocolate. Great balance. Finishes a little alcoholic. Way better than the only other New Belgium beer Ive had (Fat Tire).

12oz bottle, best by Mar 2010.  Pours thin dark brown with ruby highlights, a one finger light beige head.  Retains a small cap and leaves a few large spots of lace.  Aroma is of moderate strength and features sweet caramel, a little chocolate, roasted malts, some smoke, raisins and other dark fruit, molasses, some yeast & bread.  No noticeable hops.  Flavor is underwhelming, light bitter chocolate, dark roasted malts, a little caramel, a touch of sweetness.  Mouthfeel is on the full side despite the thin body, medium carbonation.  Easy drinkin, just needs more flavor.

Rich black-brown with amber hues, tan head. Aroma is caramel, spice, coco  with some background smokiness and pungency. Tastes sweet and roasty, bitter and earthy, dark fruits and spice in the finish. Body is surprisingly light with a balanced finish. This beer is quite tasty and drinkable.

Purchased at Winslows Tavern, Greenville, NC

Dark but not pitch black in color.  Very inviting scent.  Tasted darker/richer than it looked.  Very satisfying.

12 oz bottle from Paul U.  Dark amber pour that looks black once its in your glass.  Thin white head that mostly fades but remains on the edge of the glass.  Aroma is slightly yeasty but mostly dark fruit (dates maybe?).  Taste is a bit understated but very good.  Like the aroma its mostly a dark fruit flavor and has a nice sweet finish.  Very drinkable beer and one of the better ones Ive had from New Belgium.
Very drinkable, but nothing outstanding about this brew. The style is just not anything that really excites me so i was biased from the beginning. Great malt flavor and smooth delivery.

12-oz bottle Specs Houston, TX - Aroma: caramel; Appearance: clear, redish deep-brown color, light-tan head, laces; Flavor: sweet, salty, caramel, chocolate; Mouthfeel: medium bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation; Overall: a wonderfully clean fermentation, easy drink dark ale with an amazing caramel and chocolate aromatic and flavor that finishes with the caramel and chocolate.  Just can not help to wonder how good this would be in cask.
Got this as part of a sampler pack.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and malt.  Decent flavor, little bit of chocolate, slight sweetness.

12oz bottle from Market Street.  Clear, dark brown pout with a little ivory-colored head.  Smells lightly sweet, spicy (cloves), a bit of chocolate and smoke.  Tastes of toasty malt, cloves, some cocoa and yeast.  Active carbonation and a lively mouthfeel.  Slightly spicy and chocolate-ish finish.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark reddish brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is slightly sweet, rich malt, a little chocolate, coffee, vanilla, hazelnut.  Flavor is all that and smoky, rich milk chocolate.  Finish is actually pretty dry.  Deep flavor, but light palate -- very drinkable.  Not sure how to categorize this:  somewhere between a dry stout and a schwarzbier.  Tasty -- will drink again.

Pours a reddish color.  Small pale head dissipates quickly. Aroma is mostly toasty and smoky with a touch of something sweet - maybe vanilla. Quite malty taste, like it smells. Finishes quite sweet with a malty, chocolatey note lingering.  Quite different, and not in a bad way.

How on earth New Belgium decided on a light lager yeast for a beer from a recipe from 1554 is beyond me. Louis Pasteur did not discover the mechanism behind fermentation until centuries later. This aside, it is a decent enough beer. Garnet red w/ big head of mixed bubbles which leaves tons of lace. Not quite stout dark but the same kind of deep red color. Nose is dominated by a coffee-like roast character, very smooth and easy on the nose w/ a husky grain overtone in the background. Flavor is very much in the same vein and the mouthfeel is quite light w/ perhaps a bit too much carbonation. Bitterness in the finish is mild and again quite fitting for the coffee-ish character. Probably this recipe could be adjusted to make a great porter or stout but as it is it does reasonably well as a light-bodied dark beer of indeterminate pedigree.
Kinda reminds me of Dogfish brown only not as good. Its is close to black. Very nice and smooth.

This beer pours dark brown/black. The aroma is a mild one of coffee beans. This aroma continues to the palate and is enhanced by mild carbonation. This beer is fairly smooth in body and has some nice bitterness to it as well.

bottle - Pours a clear deep ruby red color with smallish light tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma has vanilla, ash, slight roasty notes, subtle smoke, continental malts and lightly toasted oak. Flavor is malty, slight chewy, with some roastyness, wet oak, touch of tobacco smoke. Finish is just on the sweet side of balanced. Overall this is pretty decent. Not something I would reach for frequently, but on occasion this could be welcome.

dark brown, small off-white head, lots of lace.  smoky nose of roasty and chocolate malts, perhaps a creamy vanilla touch.  roasty malt in the flvor with creamy chocolate notes.  medium bodied, smoky finish.  interesting, if not exciting.  on tap @ tribes alehouse in mokena.

Pour nice and dark. Smell has some vanilla and roastiness.  Taste includes some very nice coffee notes with a hit of chocolate.  It is smooth and refreshing on the palate, borderline watery but avoids this.   Some light lacing left.  A nice dark beer that has a light flavor and body.

Nice malty nose with roast notes. Pours a reddish brown with a resilient tan head. Excellent lacing. Flavor is roasty but mild with a soft mouthfeel and little hop character. A slight burnt bitterness rises in the finish.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of light malt, slight Oreo, and slight smoke.  Poured copper/very deep amber in color with a small, creamy, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Very slightly sparkling.  Some tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is slightly sweet.  Tastes of malts, light nuts, slight caramel, and hints of sugar and chocolate.  Medium body.  Slick, then slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, light nut, and slight caramel finish is a tad dry.  Really boring.
Very dark red, no head. Light, light floral aroma. Flavor is hard to pin down... sort of like a doppelbock, sort of like a stout... but with a little English-style ale-ness. Thin feel. Eh.

Clear, dark brown color with a small, firm creamy head.  Smoky, creamy roasted malt aroma.  Dark roasted malt flavor with a bitter cocoa accent.  Light to medium body with a smooth creamy finish.  Its a tasty stout if not terribly deep or complex.  Definitely worth a taste.
22oz bottle. root beer like in color and head. lot of carbonation. light aroma of dark fruit. forward taste of chocolate, light roast in the finish.

I feel like Im slamming a perfectly good beer. But to be honest... this doesnt taste like a belgian dark ale. This is more like a porter.

Ok so maybe this is the exact recipie based off of something in 1554, so maybe Im wrong. But overall I feel as if I"m just getting the same flavor profile that New Belgium ships with all their beers.

It pours a clear dark brown, odd choice of words I know, but with Belgians I expect something heavier in the appearance. This is very clear and very uniform.

The taste has lots of tastes you could pull from a porter; coffee, biscuit, etc. It is a bit watery.

Mouthfeel is also a bit watery.

Overall... is it good? Yep. Would I drink it again? Yep. Do I (in my uneducated opinion) think of it as a Belgian Dark Ale? Nope.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Bomber. Pours black and creamy with thick, milky head. Aroma is roasted malts and slightly smoky. Taste is creamy with light roasted malt flavors and coffee bitterness.  It finishes dry and smooth with a faint, smoky aftertaste. Overall flavor is similar to a mild stout. Not bad.
Tap.  Mahogany pour with off white head.  Not much nose.  Roasty/smokey taste but thin in the mouth.  Would have liked a little more body.  Flavor is ok but watery.
Bottle.  Pours clear brown with an average off white head.  Bitter cocoa aroma with some grassy tones.  Mostly sweet flavor with a slight burnt finish.  A little thin but very smooth.

Dark, clear amber brown with thick khaki head. Aromas of coffee, malts and some hops. Fairly mild, but pleasant. Starts with a thick, creamy mouthfeel turning medium bodied, with light crisp carbonation. Malts, some coffee with a little sweetness. Slight earthy hops at the finish. A nice, subtle and very drinkable ale.
Dark brown to black color, creamy lively head, smooth caramel and roasted flavors with very little burnt after-flavor. Matches perfectly with spicy Indian food. Good body, good balance.

Had high hopes for this one but was a bit dissapointed.  Pours an extremely dark amber brown with large bubbly foamy mainalla head.  Aroma is sweet with dark cherries and slight roastines - not very apetizing.  Flvor is extremely light and a bit watery - slightly sweet with a bit of a cardboardy flavor.  Overall, just so so.

Poured from 12oz. into a New Belgium chalice, that nifty new one.  Dark brown with foamy light tan head.  Aromas of chocolate malt and raisins a bit of citrus.  Mildly sweet to the taste with a hint of bitterness and a good aftertaste that lingers in the mouth.  Darn good, I think it is one of their best beers.
Dark brown color in the glass.  Mostly malt flavors with toast and chocolate notes and an almost earthy character to the beer.
Dark, nice with little sense of hoppiness. Dry, mild and satisfying with a taste that doesnt linger. Id drink it again.

Pours dark, clear amber with a small but fluffy, khaki head. The aroma is of toast, cherries and berries. Mild spices. The flavor is the same with a bit more fruitiness. Orange, banana, and a hint of chocolate. Very light on the palate, borderline watery with a toasted almost roasted/smoky finish. Kind of strange, but pretty good.

How the hell have I not rated this?! On bottle and tap numerous times the past few years. Had it on tap for apres ski in Steamboat just recently. Clear, dark brown color with black center. Decent creme-colored head with a light aroma of smoke and charred malt. Flavor is simple, with toasted malt and dry dark chocolate. Finishes smooth and easy, with a light body. A consistently good beer from New Belgium.

12 oz. -> snifter.  Poured a very dark brown, with subtle red undertones; an off-white head, which dissipated; subtle lacing.  Smells of that classic New Belgium cereal smell, roasted and caramel-y, with a very, very slight sourness.  Tastes of coffee; cereal; grasses or hay; and dark, overly ripe fruit.  Mouth feel is dry, almost powdery (?!).  A fine beer for drinking while - or rather in place of - studying for law school finals.  Ah, priorities....
Black pour. Medium body and crisp on the palate. Flavor of caramel and pale malts. Sweet and balanced.

Pours what appears to be black, but up to light it is a bit translucent, very clear beer.  Head is nice and frothy, takes a few minutes for it to subside.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee with a touch of earthy hops.  Medium-full bodied with a thin, creamy texture.  Flavor consists of malty chocolate with medium sweetness and a hint of bitterness.  Cleans up real well on the finish.  Overall I think this is a great beer.  Easy to drink. uet very tasty.

Pours dark brown with a fluffy off white head.  Aroma is light chocolate and nuttiness.   The flavor is sweet, chocolatey, and finishes dry with a bit of smokiness.  Drinks like a porter.  Overall, a solid beer for a good price.
This beer has a thick, syrupy body and a caramel taste that is mixed with a dark-fruit flavoring. Long-lingering aftertaste.

This is a pretty good beer, one of the darker beers Ive had (Im a n00b :P )
I like the subtle hints of chocolate.

Pours deep brown, nice thick head with good retention. Slightly fruity malty aroma. Light fruity flavor with strong malt hues and little bitterness. Strong  mouthfeel that is exceptionally smooth with low carbonation.

22 oz bottle - Roasted malt, sweet nose. Lots of bittersweet chocolate on the palate, but immensely satisfying. Super clean and light bodied, but it only serves to accentuate the great malts. Dry and long finish that begs for another sip. "highly quaffable" indeed.

Nice dark caramel appearance.  Head is very very thin, almost none.  Lacing is minimal.  Good aroma.  Surprising malt flavor at first.  Palate hits with a nice sweet tone late.  Good tasting beer.  I recommend this beer for someone looking for a nice dark ale that is not as strong as an Imperial stout.  This is a good session beer.

12oz bottle 
Appearance: Dark brown/reddish with a off white head, only a little lace left in the glass. 
Aroma: Roasted malt with some coffee 
Taste: Roasted malt  with some hop flavor 
A real good beer that I could (& will) drink more than one.

Thanks to the Tampa Crew for the share.  Pours brown-amber with an off-white head.  Nose is malt, fruit, sweet banana, and an almost raisiny quality.  Mild barleywine flavor.  Flavor is lots of sweetness, malt, raisin, light chocolate, caramel, and goodness.  Medium bodied and sweet.  Nice, enjoyable offering from New Belgium.

Draft at the Dubliner in St. Louis.  Pours a deep but clear brown-amber color with a small beige head.  Aroma of dark and dried fruit, caramel, sweet roasted malts, and earthy notes.  Flavor has notes of all of the above in addition to nuts, chocolate, and just a bit of bitter hops.  Medium bodied, with a syrupy, sticky mouthfeel.  Not bad, but strikes me as just average.

Courtesy of Ramoned. Pours deep amber with off white head. The aroma has cherries, prunes and dates to go along with muted malts. The taste begins with a brief pulse of sweet malts and grains followed by dates, prunes, raisins and cherries. It evens out into the finish.

One pint bottle. Pours with a nice slightly brownish, very black coloring. Head is about half a finger and sticks around. Flavor is of malt and a tad of chocolate. Lacing is superb. Palate is just the right amount of carbonation with a slightly syrupy feel, but not at all disgusting in that malt liquor sense.
Great beer.
26th June 2008. Smooth dark brown ale - no bitterness. A mildly chocolate dry finish. Very drinkable and its always nice to see these ancient recipies revived!

yes yes yes
una cerveza oscura sin la ceniza.  me gusto.  ademas despues con chocolate ecuatoriano 75% cacao impresionantemente similar.  bien hecha la birria.

On tap at Goodfellas in Chapel Hill. Pours a clear, dark brown with a liberal, tan, fluffy head. Has little retention and leaves some okay lacing. Big roasty character, earthy grain, bitter chocolate, sort of earthy dirtiness. Taste is malty, roasty, lots of hazelnuts, some chocolate and coffee. This is sort of close to a schwarzbier. A bit thin on the palate though. Not bad.
Chocolate went great with this beer.  Not as full-bodied as I would have thought and a bit thin for what I was looking at.

Dark brown in color with a off white head that diminishes quickly.  aroma is pretty malty with caramel, some light licorice, grain, fruit, some light earthy hops.  Taste his malty, very light dry chocolate hints, some fruit, some malty sweetness with a very light hop bitterness in the finish.  medium bodied.

Draft sample at Black Sheep Pizza. Near black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of pale malts, caramel, underpinned by some dry black malt notes. Mild fruit upfront in the mouth, followed up by more dry chocolate and caramel notes. For all of the fruit and roast notes, the finish is quite clean and lagerlike. A strange beer as it has both schwartzbier and stout qualities, but isnt really one or the other. Solid and easy drinking overall.

Poured from bottle into Flat Earth Pint glass.

Dark brownish-red with very thin head that leaves bubbly receding lacing.

Aroma of light roasted malts, dark fruit and earthy spiciness.

A lot flavors going on here. Tastes almost like a cross between a Schwarzbier, an English Brown Ale and a Belgian Ale. Roasted malt character (with a hint of coffee) competes with sweet fruit and an earthy yeast character. Overall I like it, but it is a little bit of a mess.

Moderate carbonation, medium body, strange finish. Slightly thin but not as bad as many other New Belgium brews.

Quite nice unique beer. Very much worth trying and would have again every once in a while. Probably the best of New Belgiums normal line-up, which, unfortunately, isnt saying much.

A wonderful deep mahogany Ale. Has a creamy light tan head. Tastes sweet with subtle Carmel and chocolate undertones 
The aroma is similar to the taste.
Comes in a bottle, best from tap. currently my Favorite Beer.

22oz bottle served in an oversized snifter. Pours clear brown, appears black in the glass, topped by a half inch of beige foam. Aromas of cookie, cocoa, toast, and a hint of coffee. The flavor is very similar to the smell but isnt as "punchy" or not quite as crisp. There is a good deal of roasted character in the finish. Quite interesting and would make a nice jumping off point for a bigger beer. As it is though it comes across a little weak and watery.
22oz.  Pours very dark.  Not much aroma, but has a nice nutty and almost creamy taste.  Laces the glass nicely and finishes clean.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2009 Bottle, compliments of Lewis at Rabun Gap family reunion.  Poured a beautiful mahagony with thin khaki more like crema than head.  Toasty malts and semi-sweet  Like 2% dark-chocolate milk.  Good times.

Bottle pour.....wow, this is an impressive looking beer. Very dark, syrupy color, with a thin, tan head. Not as strong in the aroma as I expected, but with strong hints of dark caramel, and roasted heavy malts, some nutty roast also. Tastes are prominent in the front end....sort of a chocolatey, cooked coffee, smokey (almost tobacco like, kinda tastes like the smell of an old, smokey bar) flavors, again, very  strong, roasted malt flavors. The tastes quickly dissipate and leave a slight reminder on the palate, prompting you to drink again, just to make sure you got the full effect. I like the effort made to produce this beer, its certainly filling and flavorful. I think I will open another.

Bottle. Very dark amber, near black, tan frothy head, strong lacing. Rich malt aroma, notes of chocolate. Wow this beer is malty - but in a good way - and is well balanced. Long dry finish, fairly bitter.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle.
Appearance: A clear black if you will, with garnet highlights and a foamy, light tan head.  Good head retention and great lacing left behind.
Aroma: A vegetal nose with roasted notes, smoke, and a wee bit of chocolate.
Flavor: Very roasty but smooth on the tongue.  A little nuttiness, a bit of mineral, and a light chocolate note.  It could use a little more body.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and a medium-short, slightly roasty finish.
Overall: A very sessionable ale that is reasonably tasty.  Still, there is nothing so great as to bring me back to this one.

12oz bottle at Shellfish in Port Lavaca, TX. Pours dark brown with a thin, short lasting tanned head. Aroma is light of brown sugar, dark fruits and some nuts. Medium body with dark fruit and espresso coffee fill the mouth. Finish is medium. Taste like a good porter to me.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a thin beige head. Grainy malt aroma with caramel and a hint of chocolate. Caramel malt flavor with a bit of hop in the finish.
great beer! my favorite from new belgium. dark appearance with a light to medium head that doesnt hang around long. Smokey flavor with chocolate notes. try it!
12 oz. bottle- Aroma is decent enough, but the flavor is where this beer excells. Flavor of chocolate and coffee, deeply multi layered in flavors, the best New Belgium beer ive ever had.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2011 1 pint 6 oz. Bottle. Pours Black. head is minimum and light-brown. Aroma is chocolaty and roasty. Flavor is fizzy to the palate, body is medium. Flavor misses the mark slightly. overall taste is better than average...finish long and full of body. Nice.
12 oz botttle.  Smells of chocolate, coffee, dark malt.  Black in appearance (no surprise), small head, moderate lacing.  Tastes of black coffee.  Creamy mouthfeel.  One of New Belgiums best.

I like this the best of the New Belgium Brewing selections.  Hints of chocolate/coffee. Dark roasted malts. Actually a bit lighter than you would expect, so you can throw a few down in a sitting.  Im facinated by the 1554 story.

Pours black w/ dull ruby hue; off-white creamy head.  Aroma of sweet malt, burnt sugar and hints of coffee & dark fruit.  Taste is coffee w/ cream, sweet malt w/ notes of chocolate & nuts.  Some bitterness on the back end.  Mouthfeel is thinner than expected and not as sweet as the aroma lets on.  This is good, kind of a cross between a nut brown ale and a porter.
Pours a flat coke color. Nose is slight roast, some cocoa and coffee. Flavor is a clean toasted malt, mild chocolate and sweet caramel. Above average mouthfeel. Good drinking beer.
Stout-like, flavor and mouth feel. Taste and aroma both dominated by chalk, chocolate, and caramel. Long enjoyable finish. Great beer.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark, cola-brown color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing. Loads of nougat and wet malts in the aroma; richness without being overtly sweet; hints of chocolate. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lively carbonation upfront, and a solidly drinkable presentation; lots of dark malts, nougat, and touches of cocoa at the core of things; light on the perimeter; in all honestly, the carbonation is a touch pushy here, but theres a citrus bitterness balancing this out thats quite nice. Solid beer. Lengthy finish of wet malts, chocolate, and a slight, though lasting mineral bitterness. Tasty finish.

Bottled at Monks Cafe, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a hazy dark brown colour with a small off-white head. Rather rich aroma of roasted malts, mild estery yeast, sweet licorice and mild banana. Medium-bodied with notes of toeasted malts, cocoa, mild spices, estery yeast, licorice and yeast. Balnced finish of yeast, licorice, rosated amlts and neutral yeast.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown/black, but holding it up to the light there is a red hue.  The aroma is caramelized malts and roasted malts.  Notes of spices, floral hops, and dark fruit comes out.  On the palate, it is a little dry.  The flavor really brings out a chocolate pressence.  It finishes a little sweet and dry.  Overall, pretty good, but nothing special,
Beer is good but not great. Aromma is malty, and pretty balanced. The finish is smooth, and the color dark. I would recommend this beer to the ale loves of the world!

When pouring out it looks like cola but is almost black but has red hues when held to a light in the glass.  Nice white head with some lasting power and some lacing.  Aroma is roasty.  Taste is malty, roasty and chocolaty.  Weird taste that effects the middle of my tongue, not bad, but never had a beer hit these taste buds.  Taste finishes sweet with just the mildest hop balance.
Dark roasted and flavorful.  Great malts without being at all heavy.  This is probably my favorite New Belgium beer.

A thick dark beer that I love. Tried it the first time on tap and now in bottles. This beer has a nice brown head and chocolate aroma. The taste is of raisins and malt. Very smooth and the reason I fell in love with New Belgium beers. One of my favorites.
22oz - Roasted malt aroma with a bit of raisin.  Flavor is a tad more complex and sweet with a touch of smoke.  Palate is sticky and dry.  Tasty but a bit lame.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2009 [bottle into dimpled mug] Very dark pour, brown foamy head. Nice touch of burned coffee in both smell and taste, but not overpowering on either. Very nice flavorful beer. Definite + in my book
UPDATED: NOV 3, 2009 This beer has very dark color.  The aroma is chocolatety.  The flavor is malty.  Very drinkable and a decent black ale.

ྫྷoz bottle) dark brown pour decent head. Nose of chocolate, alcohol, and some caramel. Taste is creamy, chocolaty, and quite nice. Some dark dried fruit on the front as well. Darker tasting than I expected but no off flav ors at all.

On tap at Pour 24 at NY NY in Vegas.  Pours a clear coppery brown with a thin beige head. Caramel, roast, light malt.  Medium body, good carb.  Nice malt and caramel notes.  Finishes a little quick, zesty from carbs, and with a subtle and balanced bitter.
Earthy and with tons of Licorice- this is deliscious. Grainy with touches of coffee. Smoky and sweet. I would buy plenty of these if they sold them down here. Bottle from a freind.
Bottle, Aroma of dark malts, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is chocolate, with a light sweetness, some coffee maybe a bit of smoke. Palate is a bit light, but tastes good. Not a bad one.

On Tap at the Cheeky Monk Belgian Beer Cafe, Denver 09/10/2008
Fruit and roast aromas. Small white head. Black smooth and a little rich on the palate. Crisp and slightly dry coffee roast finish.
Bomber into a pint glass.  Refreshing and very drinkable, but not reminiscent of the Belgian roots they describe on the bottle.
Comparable to Sprecher Black Bavarian lager, with a bit of tart fruit in the nose. Slick medium palate and easy, clean finish. Nice easy drinker with lots of flavor.
Pours deep brown.  Toasty yeasty smell.  nice burnt toast flavor and not too sweet.  I enjoyed it.
light roast aroma with sweet caramel.  Brown pour with a tan head.  Lots of malt in the flavor and light on the palate.
Pours a brown color with tan head.  Aroma is caramel, roast, chocolate, and honey. Flavor is roast, caramel, toast, chocolate, and a sweet malty finish.
Dark reddish beer with a medium brown head.  Nice aroma of sweet malts.  Flavor is sweet chocolate and roasted malts.  Dry in the finish.  Smooth and fun.
A deep red beer with a brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel as well as slightly smoked notes. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of berries and caramel.

Very tasty, light roated malt, sweet like a porter, roasted, but not too much.  Does not cling to the palate, clean, refreshing for a dark beer.  Just very good and drinkable, while roasted and sweet.

Slightly chilled into a New Belgium goblet.  Nice head, deep mahoganey color. Toasty malt and a touch of roast in the nose, with suggestion of fresh fig.  Malty, somewhat sweet upfront, the malt turns warm and the roast develops.  Mild but crisp hops clean the beer up.  Very nice, very drinkable.  Not amazingly complex, but a solid beer.  Try with a nice fontina.
pours a dark brown with offwhite sudsy lacing and small head.  Smell is subdued chocolate roasted malt, smoke, toffee.  Flavor is a one dimensional mild smoky chocolate malt.  Not a huge fan.
dark brown pour aroma and light taste of burnt coffee, slight smoke finish. like it

Poured dark, dark brown.  The head was off-white and short.  The aroma was smoke, roasted malts and thin chocolate.  The flavor was lots of smoked malts and some light sweetness that was followed by a slightly sour finish.  The mouthfeel is thin and very dry.
Classic burnt coffee nose and flavors with a similar nose. much like your classic stout. the only difference was that it was much light in mouthfeel being an ale.
