bottle. Pours a rich roasty dark brown, nice thick but small tan head. Nice nose of spice and malt and caramels. Flavor is a lot lighter than you expect for the colour. malty and sweet, hint of belgium spices in the background. finishes well.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 Opening the bottle delivers a fruity aroma akin to an Old or Scottish ale.  Pours very dark brown with a verrrrry frothy head.  Beer goes down very frothy in mouthfeel, akin to a nitro-ized stout, and with a roasty toasty grainy portery finish.  And manages after all that to retain a distinctly Belgian character.  Lovely.  Got a 6er for $7, thats good.
Pours dark reddish with nearly receding off-white wispy head. Aroma of aromatic malt, toffee, caramel. Taste is caramel, toffee, bready lager yeast. Medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation.

I drank 1554 last night and dont remember it being so sweet. This is a unique beer, very complex malt character. It has a very low hop profile, which seems to be appropriate for style. The sweetness was overpowering though and made it somewhat difficult to drink. I do enjoy the malty aroma however.

Pours a dark brown with red highlights.  A tan one finger head.  Aroma is roasted malt with a bit of hop.   This is a porter light.  It has everything a porter has but lighter.  Roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee.  Smooth and zesty feel.  A very nice beer.

Blankboys bottle, thanks Paul! App: Certainly looks like an ale! Deep red/brown, creamy head. Aroma, sour apple and chocolate, flavour: Smokey, nutty, roasty! Short-quick finish! Like I wasnt drinking at all!!! Lovely

Bottle (12oz).  Shared by blankboy with garthicus.  Very deep clear brown-red pour, average tan head.  Dry, sharply spicy/yeasty aroma (Belgian/Unibroue yeast-like), with dry cocoa and a hint of roasty fruity malt.  Taste - VERY nice - light in character, mild brown ale-like dry roast with ripe pear and light floral hop bitterness - but man what a quick finish.  Light body, only mildly carbonated, no aftertaste, but I think pints of this would hit the spot for me year-round.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 Probably my absolute favorite dark beer.  Chocolatey flavor with a hint of coffee that tastes divine.  Truly a unique beer with a great, foamy white head.  The only bad part about this beer is the empty bottle at the end.

Pours a dark brown with a small white head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted barley and malt. Flavor is chocolate, malts, hops and sweetness. The chocolate sticks around inside your mouth and is slick feeling. Not bad.
This was a refreshing ale I drank in Texas when I went to see Radiohead. Not too strong, it was smooth with a lucid, reddish dark appearance.

ReRate: Bottle, Kegs & Barrels, McKinney, TX.
Pours a translucent dark brown with ruby highlights, beige head, decient retention, slight lacing. Aroma is similar to a schwartz beer, slight dark roast. Flavor is slightly sweet dark roast, very slight dark fruit with light alcohol spice, slight dark grain bitter, very slight hop bitter. Palate is medium-high carbonation, medium body. Very good beer.....Reminded me of what I thought a good schwartz beer would taste like, just turns out what I wanted would be a black ale instead of a black lager......Good stuff! and yes, I said "Slight" alot in this rating.....
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 Black, roasted malts, sweet caramel, and nutty with a slight hop finish.  Sweet and crisp.

Initially, I was a little worried when I took a deep breath of 1554.  The scent was the only thing I was not sompletely sold on.  This beer has a great, deep color, and then I tasted it, and could not stop.  Flavor is fairly complex and goes down smooth, leaving that same feeling on the roof of your mouth.  Very good beer!

Pours dark carmel/brown with red huge.  Nice light head occurs from pour but dissipates quickly.  Aroma is very malty with some nuttiness and a slight sweet endnote. This beers mouth feel is on the heavier side with fine carbonation on tongue.  Flavor is complex mixture starting off with a malty/nutty bite which then moves into a very toasted, almost burnt grain flavor and ends with a slight sweet dry flavor that sticks around for a bit.  Overall a decent beer that I will get again.
Nice frothy white head.  Dark pour.. Some raisons.. Little acidity.  Long finish

Dark brown with a thin head, a slight and simple aroma with hints of malt, and alcohol, medium creamy roasted malt flavour fading to a warm smokey black cherry residue. An enjoyable palate for an everyday beer.

Dark brown but so clear that when you hold it to a strong light the whole glass goes carmel color.  Light coffee and malt aroma, with a nice, smooth yet bright flavor of sweet malt and coffee with hints of cocoa.  Not much finish, small bitter bite in the back over the throat.  Someone fun to serve with friends.

On tap @ NB Hub in DIA.  Pours a dark reddish, almost black color with a nice white head.  Roasted, caramel aroma.  Great roasted malt flavor, mildly sweet, but clean and not sticky.  Crisp, worth a try...
Not overly-complex, but works in terms of roasted and toasted maltiness.  Strong chocolate and coffee tones with a finish that moves into the slightly-hoppy realm.

22 oz. botle, pours a red-tinged dark brown body with light brown head.  Sweet malty aroma with hints of caramel and biscuit.  Flavor is more of the same with some hints of smoke, coffee, and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is light and a little watery.  Slightly bitter coffee finish.

Pours a clear dark brown body with off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is sweet caramel, malty with no real bitterness. Medium body, thin texture. Finishes someone medium and sweet.

Pours dark brown with medium beige head. Aroma of coffee, yeast, and chocolate. Pleasant mouth feel, creamy, but very light carbonation. Taste is sweet, caramel and chocolaty, seems to end too abruptly but is followed by a very nice long finish, of roast  malt, nuts, and burnt coffee with a slight bitter tang. Definitely calls for another.
a very dark red colour with a nice head strong aroma of coffee and chocolate which also shows in the flavour very enjoyable

Bomber from Lakeville Liqour:
Pours a dark ruby brown with a nice tan head. Aroma was dusty yeast and dark chocolate. Flavour carried through with the chocolate tones, and a light bitterness.
Tap at the Brewery.  Dark brown with beige head.  Smells a bit of chocolate with slight hop flavor.

12oz bottle.   This one has been intriguing for awhile: seemed like an interesting idea with the story of the super old recipe and all that... Well, dark brown body with a medium beige head and good lacing.   As soon as I open the bottle, there is a nice aroma of spicy and grassy hops that dissipates too quickly.  Followed by doughy, yeastiness and some cocoa.   The flavor is pretty sweet with a mild roast, some chocolate, cold coffee ground scent perceived as flavor, and some subtle hops.   Could use some more bitterness or more roast.   Reminds me of a dunkel, which I guess it is, but fermented at a higher temp?   The sweetness gets to me by the end, but no shame in putting one of these down and I would go for it again.

Ok stuff
ok roasted malt flavor a bit thin and watery in the mouth feel......almost seems like it was trying to be a swarczbeer...but not really
I think this is semi refreshing for a hot day....but I would much rather drink something else....
12 0z. bottle, very dark color, chocolate and roast flavors and nose, a little light on the finish but a good beer overall

Bomber. Poured an almost black with some brown highlights. Just a ring of a head that dissipated quickly. Not much in way of aroma besides some roasted malt. Flavors of predominately black tea and coffee, molasses and toffee. Fairly malty. Quite good.

[bottle] Poured a deep ruby color with a moderate tannish head. Aroma was subtle. Some dark fruits, a little bit of coffee, and some yeast. Flavor was a little roasty with some chocolate. Reminded me of a bittersweet porter. Pretty light mouthfeel, and overall a very drinkable, refreshing dark beer.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2010 Pours a deep black/brown color with a ruby glow and a lovely, fine off-white head.  Aroma of specialty grains, a little pit fruity. Has a sweet, almost roasted porter-like characteristics.  Its light-medium body is great and easy to drink, roasted in the throat, and very satisfying on the tongue.  Wonderfully tasty and a safe bet when you find it on tap (or someone picks up a NB 12-sampler). Next to Ranger IPA, probably my favorite NB in a 12-oz bottle.

Pours a deep copper brown (almost black ale?)  1 finger beige creamy head that sticks around.  Sharp sweet nose with a hint of raisin at the back end.  Semi-sweet malt with hints of roasted dark chocolate and slightly dry hop finish.  Medium body, mouth feel is spot on.  The best I have ad from this brewer.  A great 100th beer!

A clear deep mahogany color and a light tan foamy head.  Chocolate and roasted malt aroma, some coffee.  Full bodied and nice carbonation.  Flavors of dark chocolate and aromatic coffee.  Drier finish with a brisk bitter bite at the end.

from tap and bottle.  pour dark and black with a thick dark head.  Bready and sweet malty aromas.  All the color and flavor of dark malt without the roastiness of a stout.  A great beer that is unique
On tap...pours black.  Creamy head.  Great appearance.   Roasted flavor with coffee and chocolate most prevalent.  Wonderful thickness...food like quality.   A sipping beer.  Most enjoyable.

Eh, a very forgettable beer. Pours a beautiful black color with a very dense, thick head and a malty aroma. However, taste was incredibly thin. Very little of anything except watered down malts and something else I couldnt quite place. Decent, but definitely wouldnt buy again.

The bottle poured nearly black with caramel tones and tan foam. I get mild spicy notes, definitely toasted, chocolatey, and mild dark fruits arriving with a bit of warmth. Medium dry finish, flavor of burnt bread crust, palate a bit thin, but its nice.

Pours a dark ruby-black with a foamy tan head.  Nice aroma of chocolate and fruit, with some roasted malts.  Flavor is similar, with some caremel sweetness.  Sour fruit on the finish.  A little thin, but otherwise good brew.

Poured midnight black from a bottle, with a minute tan head.  Aroma of roasted coffee and sweet cocoa with flavor to match.  Nice rounded body without a heavy thickness.  An excellent and highly drinkable beer.

From a 22oz. bottle purchased locally. Aroma is a little roasted and a little sweet. Appearance is a dark ruby to brown color with a small tan head. Flavors are grainy, a little carmelly sweet, and a touch of roasted chocolate, but not overpowering. Bitterness balances the sweet evenly. Medium bodied and easy drinking. This is a nice drinking beer that pairs well with food. Almost like a schwartzbier, but as an ale.
Silky dark pour with a two finger thick tan head.  Roasted malt on the nose with some cocoa notes.  Smooth body with a hint of dark fruit and then the cocoa and roasted malt flavor.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2008 Pours the color of motor oil and has a very thick, long-lasting tan head.  Nice aroma of chocolate malt.  Strong roasted malt flavor with chocolate and coffee hints.  Just a bit of bitterness and a bit of a bite on the back of the tongue.  A very nice beer.

Poured into an Ommegang goblet. Dark brown with clear ruby highlights. Big, fluffy, tan, three finger head. Thick lacing on the glass.

A little bit of roasty malt on the aroma, as well as a sourish fruitiness.

Flavor is of peanut skins with a little bit of classic Belgian dark fruit. Some cocoa powder comes out but on the whole this beer is kind of watery and stale.

Mouthfeel is thin, finish isnt very dry for an unsweet beer. Carbonation is a touch heavy. Pretty decent drinkability.
Dark brown to black in color with a decent head.  Roasted in the aroma with some chocolate and malts.  Taste is smooth and like the aroma has malts, some roastiness, and chocolate.

22 oz from bevMo.  pours a very opague tar black with a musty colored slowly disipating head.  scents of toffee and toasted malts...very easy going heavy set taste to the palate that doesnt have any real surprises.  the malts carry the taste of choclate and roast... a well put together ale just not my type of brew on a regualar basis.  I personally like new belgium brewing company and this was another brew  epitomizing the style they are trying to present.

bottle - Pours dark brown with a one finger tan head.  The roast malt and yeast elements in the aroma immediately put me in mind of a Belgian stout.  Its a little lighter than most stouts, but the flavor continues with the roast malt, adds a hint of chocolate, and theres a little bit of a fruity ester in there.  Solid.
Bottle. Pours deep black with nice slight head. Chocolate malt to the nose, sweet chocolate roast on the tongue, a fine beer.
2008 Bottle - Smokey on the nose, malty chocolate, burnt bitterness on the end, this has a regular spot in my fridge...
smooth and chocolaty.  A smidge smokey.  I cant find anything wrong with this dark beer.  Will buy/drink again and again and again.
On tap.  Deep Brown, nearly black body.  Surprisingly easy to drink - not bitter.  My favorite New Belgium brew.

Dark dark brown with a quickly dissipating white head. Aroma of malt, figs, dates. Taste has a nice sweet maltiness, with hints of dark fruits and coffee. Slight lingering malt flavor. Not very complex, but very drinkable.

Coming from New Belgium Brewing Company  i knew this Ale wasnt going to be stellar, but I was slightly surprised. The color and appearance is beautiful, but very short lasting small head. Little carbonation, but delicious roasted flavor slightly dry at the end which i personally appreciate.  Overall a tasty beer.

Pour: A deep mahogany with red hues. Two finger tan head with Belgium lacing on the 
glass
Nose: Chocolate, roasted malt, hints of pine and hops
Taste: A complexed, chocolate, toasted malt, hints of wheat, wheat, citrus, the finish is a bit acidic and dry.
body Medium
Overall: a very good beer with a good balance and character.  Enjoyed
Chocolate, roasted malts, and a little bitter at the end.  One of New Belgiums better beers.  Not great, but not bad either.

Poured black with a light tan head. Smells of chocolate and caramel. Starts out with a dark fruit taste similar to an Abbey Ale that ends up tasting more chocolaty and dessert like with a hint of vanilla. Finishes with a very earthy taste similar to some wines. I do like that they are a little easier on the carbonation than some of their other beers. Overall good and would drink it again.

Poured from 22oz bottle a clear dark brown with a medium sized light brown head that slowly dwindled leaving nice lacing.  Aroma is of cereal (Cheerios), toasted bread and a light sourness.  The flavor comes across, with the slightess bitterness, as a light toasted bread, some malty sourness and a touch of mild roast coffee.  There is a dry finish that comes in chalky with a bit of unsweetened coco powder.  Overall the beer starts a bit watery but gets better, good but not great.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2008 Not a bad brew.  Pour was dark brown with nice white head.  Taste was of malt, light caramel, a few hops, and some roasted characters.  Ok but not super special.  Would drink again but would not go out of my way to buy.
Bottle.  Pours a brown color with a creamy white head. Aroma of malt, fruit, caramel, grain. Tastes of roasted malt, soy with a bit of chocolate. Has a dry earthy finish.

Dark brown to almost black.  Aroma is really nice, biscuity and yeasty.  I have had this beer for years, but this is my first rating.  I tend not to buy NB much anymore.  10-15 years ago Fat Tire was my cross over beer.  But it is nice to revisit and enjoy this beer.  Nice finish as well, again the aroma is one of a kind.
Im always a bit cautious with darker beer. However, 1554 is an absolutely delicious gem that has become one of my favorite beers.

This brew is a breath of fresh air. Pouring full and dark with a light, frothy head, the nose does not do it justice, with little more than an understated roasted oat scent. But the flavor--now, that my friend is outstanding. Caramel and butterscotch frolic with oats and barley against a backdrop of raisins adn the lightest hint of cherries, all with a smoothly creamy, poppingly crisp mouth feel,

12 oz six pack.  Another brew picked up on my midwest road trip, this black ale wasnt as black as the Summit porter I also picked up.  Hard to get a good whiff out of a plastic hotel cup.  The head was full and off-white, and the flavor was full and of a nut brown kinda taste.  Nice lightly roasted taste, easy to drink.  Very nice.
12 oz bottle pours a dark brown with a thin beige head.  Aroma of sweet and roasted malt.  Flavor is roasted coffee, chocolate, and a little hop bitterness.

3/8/08 - On draft at Ginger Man in Dallas.  Pours brown with amber hues.  Nose is not discernible.  Taste of chocolate and caramel, dry7 and a touch of hops.  Good and very drinkable. Very double-esque.

Dark, almost black ruby, clear, spongy white head, quickly falling.
Dry, somewhat papery aroma.
Sweet roasty flavor.
Thick creamy palate.

12 oz bottle.  Clear burgundy brown with a fluffy beige head.  Nose is light coffee, smoke and green grass.  Medium body with a carb tingle.  Starts watery but gets richer; finish a bit chalky.  Taste is an odd mix of bittersweet chocolate, raisin, flat cola and plum peel.

Pours dark brown/black, average head. Smells like chocolate. Taste like chocolate, fortunately with no over-roasting like most others do.  Good lacing. Good carbonation and bite A little coffee and hickory on the finish. Mostly good to drink.

A very dark brew.  Thin tan head. A slight licorice, coffee aroma.  The flavor is on the sweet side with just a bit of bitter/coffee in the finish, a slight metallic taste as well.  Body is a bit on the syrupy side to me.  This is an OK beer, but I wouldnt hunt it down.

Dark, rich, brown body and a tannish head. Pretty good lacing. The aroma reminds me of black licorice and dark chocolate. The flavor is of roasted malt, caramel, and coffee. Nice aftertaste, if you like that which you sometimes get from instant coffee, that is. Also, there are some roasted vegetable notes, and those appear after all the slight bitterness is gone. Good carbonation, and the finish is dry. Frankly, I didnt have high hopes for this before opening the bottle, but Ive been pleasantly surprised. I hope you will be, too.

Pours dark with a fairly frothy head. Aroma of yeast, slight hint of coffee. Tastes of bread/yeast with a strong chocolate-coffee dark roast finish. Not too heavy. Overall, excellent complex dark brew.

better from the tap than the bottle, imo.

Pours with a largish, off-white, rocky head with an extra-dark, although clear, brown body. Very nice lacing, decent retention. Some hops followed by a huge hit of chocolate malts on the aroma. There is some biscutiness. Taste is nearly that of a dry stout, tons of coffee malts in the after taste. Lively carbonation. Quite nice.

My favorite black ale.  Weyerbachers Black Hole aspires to this but misses the light touch and winds up too cough-syrupy.  1554 can be guzzled or sipped non-stop, in a word: drinkable.  Also, has a bit of alcohol sting on top so you dont notice the low content.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with creamy light brown head, with great retention and good lacing. Aroma is dark bread, toast, grain, nuttiness, dark chocolate, along with smokiness and raisin. Flavor sweet light bread, saltiness, light to moderate bitterness lingering into the finish. Body is moderately full, dry, slightly oily with a lively and soft mouthfeel.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Black Ale -- 3/4/2008 from 12 oz. bottle . . .
  Aroma: Sweet; Maltiness; Some caramel, chocolate and nuttiness.
  Appearance: Clear; Dark mahogany, reddish-brown color;  Medium light-tan head with good retention; Nice lacing.
  Taste: Medium sweet; Chocolate and caramel dominant; Very little hops.
  Palate: Medium body; Medium carbonation; Smooth; Sweet, malty finish.
  Overall: We really like this beer, but feel that a bit stronger hops presence would be an improvement.  Nevertheless, its a very enjoyable brew.

A nice clear brown with thick tan head. Aroma is hints of caramel and malts. Flavor is of caramel, roasted malts and undertones of chocolate. Body is medium light. I really enjoyed this beer. I think this is one of my favorites from them thus far.

Clear brown, nice creamy tan head. Flavor is light roast, caramel sugar, a bit of toffee and chocolate. Medium bodied. Smooth on the palate. Nice sweet lingering finish. This is a pretty solid beer, very drinkable.
Nice dark chocolate color with a smooth cream colored head and a rich nutty choclatey flavor. It has a strong after taste a little metallic but mostly bitter.
black pour with a ring of cream colored froth.  sweet malts and a hint of sugar as well.  chocolate and roasted malts on the palate and a good thickness.  this could easily be a daily drinker for me.
Pours a very dark red with a lot of off-tan head.  Odor of oats and malts.  Taste of bread, with chocolate and caramel that ends with a creamy aftertaste.  This is actually very enjoyable.

Nice dark pour with a little red around the edges.  Half inch of head and nice lacing as you go.  Aroma is malts and bread.  Flavor is definitely black bread with some chocolate and a little caramel.  Nice.  Id buy a 6er, no doubt.
22oz bomber from Bevmo Carmel Mountain. Pours clear dark brown with a nice beige head. light toffee, chocolate roasted malt, and coffee. A bit thin, a little overrated but not bad at all.

Poured a very dark brown with a one inch head, good amount of lacings. A sweet, slightly chocolate flavored beer with a mild hop presence. Overall a malt and chocolate exsperience. Very sessionable just a little underwhelming for my hop prefences. My first Belgium black ale, so I have no reference for this type. Seems to be a lot like Becks Dark  or Heineken Dark. Very drinkable but not outstanding in any other way.

pours a burnt brown with a one finger fluffy tan head. aroma is toasted chocolate and caramel malt and a touch of hops. has a medium body with good lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but stronger and the chocolate being more cocoa powder and dark chocolate. has a little dry aftertaste and overall not bad. better than fat tire and as it warms the aroma catches up to the flavor a little more rating wise.

This one poured with a long lasting tan plillowiy head, where the liquid had a dark ruby color.  The aroma was of slight licorice and chocolate.  The taste blended the two with a slight coffee and caramel taste in the middle and a clean finish at the end.  This was well made.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Nutty malty nose.  Dark brown, almost looks like a porter.  Rich malt, nutty raisin sweetness.  Full body.  Interesting beer...worth trying

Bottle, BB 1/25/08.  Poured clear, medium garnety-brown with a creamy cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up sweet, toasted nutty notes and dry semi-sweet chocolate backed by a dusty kolsch-type yeast.. pleasant.  The flavor began with tart, darker-fruit inspired notes on the tip of the tongue.. semi-sweet, lightly-toasted caramel and chocolate across the middle.. a little tartness returns on the finish.  Crisp and clean on the palate, leaving dried cocoa on the refreshing finish.. this was a very well put-together beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with brown head. Low retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel chews, toasted granola, plums and mild cherry. The taste isnt as intense as the aroma. Notes of red fruit, bitter chocolate and raisins. The body seems a bit low as if this beer was watered down.
New Belgiums best beer by far, theyre generally overrated, but this ones a winner

Aroma - cereal, roasty, earthy, 
Appearance - redish brown, clear, with a minimal head
Flavor - light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness
Palete - medium body with a hin feel, and average carbonation, with a slight bitter ending.

Decent all around dark ale, however, I have had a few bad bottles both on the west coast and mid-west. Flavor can be a bit to over powering for seafood or other mild foods...and at other times the flavor is weak.

12 oz bottle thanks to lb4lb. Pours a deep dark brown with a large slightly off whte head, sort of reminded me off an oreo considering how dark the body was compared to the whiteness of the head. Initial aroma if slightly musty but as the beer warms notes chocolate, some sort of atificial sweetner, slight coffee and dirt. Medium bodied with lively carbonation that is highly quaffable. Flavor really suprised me compared to the aroma with nice chocolate notes, vanilla that leaves a very nice roastiness on the back of my tongue. I went black but now I have to go back because I cant get this beer around me.

Looks like pepsi cola. Dark brown, very carbonated and fluffy head. Smells nothing like pepsi. More like coffee, light sugar/caramel and some toasted malts. Flavor is that of of rich toffee and dark fruit. Sweet up front with some nice robust finish. Bold flavor, nice full bodied palate. Velvet smooth. More please.
Very good beer. Looks like a stout, but its not . Very deceiving beer. Its almost like a coffee taste. Its also fantastic when mixed with Frambozen, another New Belgium beer.
Thanks to tayner for the bottle. Dark copper color with a medium head. Aroma of toasted malt, smoke and dark fruit (mostly prunes). Sweet taste with a lite to medium body.

I think something was wrong with this tap or something... the other descriptions are nothing like what I experienced. It was a bit sour and flat. Hmmm... if I see this again, Ill give it another shot and re-rate. On tap at Ginger Man.
UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 simplly one of the best beers i have ever tasted. smooth and clean no after taste they hit a homerun with this brew.  always in my fridge, a must check it out
bottle.  pours very dark brown.  very nice flavor. has a lot of the same flavors as a stout.

(Bottle) Pours a very dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of dark malts, cocoa, and sweet toffee. Taste is quite malty, with a creamy and smooth body. Coffee and spice notes give the beer a dry finish. Very drinkable as well. A good beer!

Blah...I am always skeptical with traditional ales. This was a weird one (which is kind of the point). Aroma was very weak. Iced tea and dust. Pour was, well, close to black with no head. Taste was vanilla, dark fruit and dust. LIttle carbonation but that was expected. As it warms it gets better and the malt and graininess emerge. Not too bad after all. This beer just jumped .3 as I was typing.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Labeled as 1554 "Enlightened" Black Ale.  Dark beer that glows mahagony when held agains the light.  Frothy brown head that left sticky lace on glass.  Chocolate and dusty grains in the nose.  Very sweet, malty beer; the kind of sweet the makes your lips stick together until you lick them clean.  Chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit, roasted grains and a faint smoke.  Very easy drinker.
Yummy, black, and delightfully refreshing.  This beer should be drank during football.
Taproom.  Pours black with whitish head.  Medium body-lighter than I was expecting.  Roasted coffee finish.

On tap at Flying Saucer. Has a very dark ruby color with a small light tan head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is very malty and sweet. Good lacing on the glass. The taste was roasted malts with a nice finish. Enjoyed this one.

12oz bottle served in a shaker pint. Poured a deep brown with a hint of red with about a finger of off white head with fine bubbles. Cocoa in the aroma. Light to medium body. Chocolate malt with a little sweetness. Dry malty finish with some lingering chocolate flavors. 

Not a very complex beer, but pretty drinkable.
If you like Mackeson XXX Stout, you will like this beer.  Smoooooth beginning, middle, and end.  You will love this beer!  Malt is what it is all about!!

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with off-white head.  Aroma is malty and coffee.  Flavor is malt, coffee, very roasted.  Slighly spicy and acidic.  This isnt a style Im very familiar with, but I like this one alright.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Smell is very malty with some roasty coffee character. Taste is good malts and sugar, it doesnt have the dreaded New Belgium nastyness. I enjoyed this brew.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs:  Dark brown color with ruby highlights held up to a flashlight and a light tan head. Aroma is rich and malty with a hint of smoke. Flavor is also sweet and malty with a hint of cherry followed by a light fruity  acidic bitterness. Medium body is creamy with moderate carbonation.

Pours a deep dark brown color with a moderate fluffy white head that leaves a bit of lace. Smells a bit smokey/toasty to me. Sweet malts and some earthy hops in the background. Tastes a bit watery up front, then the sweet toasty malt, brown sugar, flavors come in. Just a faint hint of earthy hops. Medium body, smooth, with subdued carbonation. Not a bad beer at an attractive price $2.99 at BevMo
Had on tap. Appeared a very dark brown. Sweet milk chocolate was in the aroma. A nice mellow and smooth chocolate taste, with a little spicyness in the finish.

Dark red furniture looking color. Syrupy sweet smell.  Taste is carmel type sweet.  A bit fruity. Smells of strong alcohol but alcohol is well hidden in taste.  However the 5.6% really seemed to hit me.

650 ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a translucent dark brown color with a big sudsy khaki head that leaves oodles of lacing in the glass as it slowly recedes. Aroma is light with plums, light spices and roasted malts. The flavor is weak and un-complex with roasted malts in the forefront and some earthy coffee filling in the sides. The mouthfeel is uneven with the drink starting thin and finishing malty-creamy. The finish is short, sweet and sticky-pasty.  Overall: this is a quite ordinary ale, nothing objectionable, just not enough complexity to push it into the top tier. Recommended with reservations.
Nutty, pecan like aroma.  Regardless of the style, its a pretty tasty beer.  Not a ton of acidity but enough to add interest.

Seems more like an Engligh ale to me than a Belgian style. Pours dark brown with a thick head. Aromas of chocolate and coffee. Thin mouthfeel. Tastes of coffee toasted malts, hints of chocolate, hop bitterness.
(Draught) Sampled at Taphouse in Seattle. Mahogany with a thin white head. Belgian-style black ale? Nose of coffee with a thin body. Not much here as it warms up. Below average.

Nice darker brown color with a medium beige head.  Aroma dominated by buckwheat, chocolate, and dark fruit.  Taste had some funky grainyness that really ruined it.  Its drinkable, but not all that tasty.  I like trying the ales of old, they just dont always taste that good.
The 1554 pours a dark brown with a nice thick head.  Its smooth and malty with a hint of chocolate flavor.  Very good beer.  A must try.

Pours with huge off-white head that settles to a thin lasting layer.  Nice lace.  Color is almost black with garnet highlights.  Aroma is of coffee and chocolate with a subtle cherry-like fruitiness.  Flavor is malty sweet with chocolate, coffee and almond toffee undertones. Seems only slightly hopped but has a nice balance. Finishes with a slightly sour but pleasing aftertaste. One of my favorites.
DraughtRed-amber color. The aroma shows also some malt fruitness. Tha taste is malty, again with a light fruitness, and the bitterness is quite high, but still balanced. Well brewed.

From a bottle poured a black clear body with brown-amber tones. Medium-sized white head with favorable lacing left in the glass.  Nose of caramel malts, fruits,  and chewy breadiness.  Light bodies mouth feel with a dry clean finish.  One of my favorite New Belgian standards (which doesnt really mean a lot).
Found this at Goody Goody in Highland Village, Texas. Very smooth with carmel and chocolate overtones. Not too much foam.

Huge head on this dark, dark ruddy brown beer.  Scent of tangerine skin & raspberry. Flavor quite sweet, with light roasted malts, candy sugar, caramel, & slight Belgian yeastiness combining.  Very smooth, with little prickliness. Are there any hops? Like a slightly weakened, but strong flavored, dopplebock sans hops or possibly a very experimental attempt at an Abbey duppel  which proved worth replicating for its own sake.  Will buy more at the price.
Clear dark reddish brown, moderate head with decent lacing and retention. Aroma is light chocolate, darker fruits, caramel. Medium to light body, dry finish. Nothing Belgian about it though.

Bottle best before 1/25/08. Very dark deep red, with mostly disappearing one-finger head. Aroma: Very earthy tones; maltiness of a scotch ale combined with some darker stout/porter malts. Hops are faint. A little bit fruity (strawberry & cherry). Taste: More evidence of scottish & stout combination. Some fruitiness towards the end. Some dark chocolate in the finish & a hint of coffee. Finish is surprisingly dry, with a fair amount of dark malt bitterness. Mouthfeel is too stingingly carbonated, but not horribly so.
Huge frothy head and strong smell of malt. Very sweet chocolate and molasses flavor with no after taste.

From bottle, courtesy valpoaj, Thanks!  : Pours a dark, black color with a small quick diminishing light brown head.  Nose is heavy malts with some slight hints of fruit.  Flavor is roasted, cocoa beans, and some fruit toward the end.  Medium bodied, clean and crisp palate.  Not to bad, i really like these traditional ales.

Red brown body with a creamy beige head; Quite big strangely composed biscuit like nose; Soft texture on fruity sweet body, slightly cloying; Medium long earthy chocolate thick finish, cocoa bean aroma, to sweet and a little to cloying. VERY strange!
Almost like an American brown. I dont get the "zesty" adjective in the commercial description. A bit flat in taste. Pours dark, but has none of the Belgian brown taste. Not great.

Not sure why it took me so long to try this...but Im sad I didnt try it earlier. Great reddish black with nice tan head. Love that roasty chocolate nose and the malty, chocolately taste. I will have more from now on.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a garnet hue with a fleeting tan head. Roasted nut and chocolate malt smell. Light to medium bodied. Has a semi sweet chocolate flavor with roasted malts. Finishes with a wheat toast taste on the tongue. A pretty tasty brew whatever the style. sept 2004
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle; poured a brown color with a medium off white head.  Aroma of chocolate, nuts and yeast.  Palate was a little watery.  Flavor was slightly sweet.  Main flavors of chocolate, caramel ant nuts; possibly some dark fruit.  Pretty tasty, but nothing to get overly excited about.

A beer thats close to my heart, but the more I drink the less I understand why.  Not watery, but not super-focussed; and certainly not that Belgian.  However, if youre looking for an easy-drinking porter that isnt sweet, I would really give this a second glance -- even though it isnt a porter.

Pours cola brown with a rocky off-white head.  Aroma is slightly toasted malts and dark berries.  Flavor starts off with a nice mix of roasted and toasted malts with some hints of chocolate and plums.  Some mild sweetness through-out with a dry finish.

Draught.  Pour was clear dark brown in color with a medium sized beige head that is mostly lasting.  The aroma is clean, light sweet malt and bitter chocolate.  The flavor is roasted malt, subtle hop bitterness, bakers chocolate, and perhaps just a touch of dark fruits. Medium/light body.   A very solid offering from New Belgium.
1554 pours a dark brown.  This is an excellent brew with smooth maltiness with a hint of chocolate bite at the end.  A dry and smooth beer.  Very good.

12oz bottle.  Interesting body - seemingly opaque buy strangely transparent.  Aroma of berries and malt.  Good sweet flavor, not overrun by either the dark malt or blackberry tones.  Whereas some of NBs beers are starting to taste similar and blandish, the 1554 stands out as a good selection.
One of the three offerings from NB that actually make it to Minnesota.  I like this beer better than Fat Tire.  It has a nice savory smooth flavor of malt with some hops.

Sample from bottle at West Lakeview Liquors, Chicago with rep.  Dark brown with ruby color, medium brown head.  Fruity dark malt, some hop spice.  Grainy fruity malt, red apple, not bad, subtle hop bitterness.  Medium to full body, good carb.  Okay.  Once again, I rated this higher than I actually liked it.

Excellent beer. Very smooth and chocolaty, a little nutty in the aftertaste. Mild and pleasant taste, not very 
complex.

(Bottle (best before 2/22/08) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=9 target=blank>BeerandBlues2, thanks Brad!) Not too complex but quite tasty...Pours very dark brown with some garnet highlights. One and a half fingers of soft khaki head. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and perhaps licorice. Mouthfeel a bit thin, soft, fairly smooth, very lightly prickly. Heavy sheets of lacing inside of glass. Flavor is like a dark bakers chocolate, very little sweetness, with perhaps a note of licorice or a slight dark spice element. Slightly nutty. Nice flavor and texture. As others have said this is similar to a schwarzbier. Have been wanting to try this for some time and wasnt disappointed.

Thanks to beerandblues for this one.  Surprisingly enjoyable.  Big wafting aromas I can smell from a foot away of smoky maltiness.  Flavor is slightly fruity with some chocolate.  Creamy texture.  Im also getting some roasted malt in the flavor as well.  Very reminiscent of a light quad type beer which would make sense considering the old begian heritage of the recipe supposedly.
Dark brown in color with a beige head. Malty flavor with hints of caramel and molasses.

Draught: Poured a deep black that of which could be related to the melting rubber on a highway, the smoke of the head was beige. The ice droplets of beer forming on the cold glass definetly help its appearance. The aroma was dark and somewhat roasted malt with sweet sugary overtone. The taste was complex as first it starts bitter waking the senses of your tongue, from there it finished a caramel or molasses dry flavor. This beer was a nice way to chase away the frustration of having my flight home delayed!

Really enjoyed this one.  Pours a nutty dark brown with a very small tan head.  Malty and roasted aroma with a roasted chocolate malt flavor.  Chocolate/coffee aftertaste.  Smooth but dark... reminds me a bit of a Schwarzbier.

12 oz. bottle.

Bottle from BlackForestCO.  Medium brown color with small head. Aroma of chocolate, biscut, malt, coco, and nuts. The taste was the same with good mild sweetness throughout. Smooth on the palate. Side note, this brew has the same nutty taste that fat tire and the trippel do. Hmmm?? Still, one damn fine brew. I wish I could get a case.

I had this on-tap at the Gingerman in Austin.  I swore it was a Schwartzbier, as it is true to that style, which is to say really, really boring.  I didnt get much of anything out of this beer...it is just sort of generic.

This beer pours black but is sort of on the runny side (not viscous like many stouts are).  Aroma is very faint...virtually odorless.  Flavor was a slight bit of roastiness, but also was exceedingly faint to me.

I was not impressed with this beer.  Not recommended.

deep brown with a quickly dissipating head. roasted earthy aroma with dry chocolate notes. thin slick mouth feel. has a roasted acidity taste with chocolate and a light plummy toffee flavor. good, drinks like a black lager
Light roast and clean smell.  Dark brown to amber color with a thin head. Taste lots of chocolate with a good roast balance.  Mouthfeel is too thin...needs to match the heartier nature of the beer.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2007 Pours dark brown,  decent head but goes away fast.  Hints of chocolate but nothing overpowering.  I thought of sam adams black from the first drink,  but just a tad better.  Nothing to write home about but great to grab a six pack for the night and have fun.

(bottle BB 22Feb08): Pours a dark brown color. Reddish fringes. .Dull-white head, diminishing. Chocolately roasted aroma. Malts. Dry taste, dusty chocolately taste. Watery, with a dull taste. Some malts.
Bottle.  Very dark malty aroma with a dark, dark brown color.  It is better to enjoy this at a warmer temp, otherwise the flavor is not that great.  There is not any beer I know of that is similar.
Bottled. Pours darky dark.   Caramel and coffee. Thin tasting so drinkable.

Pours with good deep tan head, dark brown color.  Aroma of cocoa and a bit of orange zest.  Taste - bread and chocolate with a touch of coffee and caramel. Aftertaste is sweet, but not too sticky.  Body a little thin.  This one is an easy pick, time and again.

mine was called enlightened back ale?? anyways kinda liked this alot nice beer unique taste kinda sweet but burnt maybe hard to explain but nice deep blackis color and smooth to drink kinda watery though

To me all of New Belgium beer tastes like Mac and Jacks. 2  Below, Fat Tire, And now this 1554. There is a little more roasted malt flavor and a nice dark color but when you taste it you think "This tastes like Fat Tire.

Rich dark malts on the nose.  Pours black with a tan head.  Smooth flavors, dark and rich malts, with an earthy hop flavor.  I havent had this in a few years it seems thicker than i remember?  Not bad, but the flavor is a little lacking.
Tap, No real head. Light raisin, some plum and thin chocolate in the nose. Nearly nothing in the mouth. Faint flavor. Expected more from this beer, could be better.

Dark brown with red hue and small tan head. Simple light roasty aroma with traces of dark fruits. Flavor is sweet and roasty with some nice earthy notes and some light fruit too. Finishes with a mix of crisp and roasty. Way better than Fat Tire.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 Being used to Flat Tire, I avoided this for some years, but recently tried it and was very impressed.  It is dark, deep red brown with a thick, long-lasting light tan head leaving good, lasting lacing.  The aroma is sweet earth, like rich, damp soil and leaves, with a fruity element.  The taste is also primarily a sweet, full earthiness with a toasty hint of chocolate that fades soon to leave a pleasant, mild earthy aftertaste.  The palate is thick and full.  The result is tasty, rich and smoothly balanced.

Pours a very thin dark brown with a thin off white almost beige head.   Nose of dark malts, dark chocolate but not very potent.  Flavor is mostly dark roasted malt with some nice chocolate hints quite sweet with a good bitterness.

Had this beer on 3/10/1999.  Color is a deep dark rich brown with light carbonation and a light head.  Aroma is light but there is a sweet darkly roasted malt scent there.  Taste is light, smooth and almost creamy.  Starting with a medium body that goes down very smooth and easy with a light malt flavor.  Finish has a creamy feel to it with a nice sweet roasted flavor and the lightest bitterness.  Its a nice dark ale.

Pours dark brown (but not black, I can still see through it) with a red glow. Thin head and mild carbonation. Some burnt grain flavors, but also lots of toasted on the second sniff. Rich burnt flavors with a very quaffable body. Nice beer! Burnt flavors linger on the tongue for quite some time (this is a good thing).
Hints of raisin in the nose and mouth.  Slightly flat in both flavor intensity and effervescence.  Very smooth and drinkable, but I was left looking for more oomph... no complaints though.
Very nice- rich and tasty, but with its own flavor.  Strikes a nice balance of chocolate/coffee/nutty flavors.

22 oz bottle labeled "Enlightened Black Ale" pours dark, with red hue through back lighting and a non-sustaining head with lingering lace.  Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, sweetness.  The flavor is solidly malty, with a roasted character, slightly lactic, very slightly sour, and actually quite nice.  Palate is smooth and carbonated, quite refreshing.  Overall this is nice.  Im glad I tried it.

Roasted/Black Malt Aroma, Poured with a small tan head. Low head retention. Roasted malt flavor with a fair amount of chocolate. Perceived hop bitterness is low as most seems to come from the dark roasted grains. Balance is to very much to the malt. Body is Medium to Medium low. Overall its a enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2007 Let me start off by saying that I am not the biggest fan of Fat Tire. This is my second offering from this brewery and it surprised the hell out of me. 

Very dark brown in color, bordering on black with a thick and creamy white head. Perfectly roasted malt, rich milk chocolate, and dark dried fruit in the nose. Creamy texture yet well carbonated. A extremely well balanced brew with a nice clean, bittersweet finish. Great from start to finish.
Dark brown with creamy head.  Roasted barley and slight chocolate aroma.  Sweet milk chocolate with a mild roastiness to the taste and a fruity finish.
33cl bottle.  Poured a very dark chocolate brown colour with a tan head.  Some roasted malt and nut flavors.  Nice and rather light body for a black ale.

Autumn Brew Review 07 
Aromas are of dark chocolate, caramel, and butterscotch.  This has a creamy mouthfeel.  Good starter beer for the event.

Poured dark, not quite opaque with a dense light tan head that stayed nicely on the walls of the glass.  Roasted malt aroma with sweeter caramel and nutty notes.  Round roasted character in the flavor with subtle bitterness.  Finishes clean.  Poured with big head but carbonation seems okay out of bottle.
Very dark beer. Poured a thick light tan head. Full bodied flavor with a hint of bitterness.

Roasted malty aroma, sweet caramel notes.  Foamy tan head and black body.  Flavor is roasted malt, cooked vegetables, bitter sharpness with light sweet balance.  Light on the palate, well carbonated with a moderate woody duration.  Easy drinking.  Not bad.
This is a magnificent beer.  Its a lot more carbonated than most black ales/porters that Ive had.  Smooth malt through and through

On tap at Bouchon in The Venetian Hotel & Casino. Dark brown with a deep red hue. Terrific chocolate aroma, faintly fruity. Robust chocolate is the dominant flavour, again with a faint fruity note, almost like cherry tobacco. Clean dry finish.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 22 oz. bottle, pours almost opaque, black but hints of red when held to the light. Aroma and flavor are both nicely rounded with good roastiness. Theres a substantial undercurrent of sweetness and fruitiness as well, perhaps plums. Finish is fairly dry. I think Ill pick up a case of this to keep around.
Dark red/brown ale.  Aroma is sweet with hints of caramel.  Sweet malts, but not much flavor.  Decent beer, but seems rather flat.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2008 Thanks BossHossBikes! Bottle best before October 5, 2007. Pours a very dark brown with a small whispy head. The nose is very malty with strong hints of nuts, toast, a bit of caramel. Actually, this smells like a high quality brown ale. Thats how I feel about the flavor as well. Lots of toasted nuts, appropriate malty flavor. . .the finish brings out more notes like tobacco and wood. Theres a thin leathery flavor that I associate with similar ales present, but its not very strong. The beer is relatively light on the palate, considering the style. Its okay, but probably not something Ill get again.

[August 3, 2008]

Bomber. I was initially excited to see this at the local grocery store. I remember it being enjoyable enough and a departure from anything else in the pitiful selection there. Give this a pour to reveal a brown beer with a small head. The aroma is musty and slightly gummy with hints at chocolate, nuts, and leather. Perhaps too sweet. I was kind of let down after tasting it. I mean, it’s not bad, but the leathery notes I remember are quite faint. I definitely picked up qualities I associate with generic lagers. This suggests bread, caramel, and creamed corn.  Really nothing special.
freebie from the nfamous Beachbum! Thanks. Black , but not pitch black. Heavy roasted nose borderline nutty. malty flavor with a clean finish

At Grumpys in NE Minneapolis.  Of the three New Beligium beers Ive had, this was one of two disappointing ones.  It poured a nice black with a thin fluffy head.  However, the flavor was very weak.  It had a fair aroma that was sweet and malty but tasted as though someone watered Guinness down with equal parts water.  Not a very complex taste and a rather flat palate.  I doubt Id buy this again.

355 ml bottle.  Pours a rich opaque mahogany with touches of amber at the edges.  Copious beige head with excellent lacing.  Heavy roasted nose with an earthy touch.  Smooth medium body.  Balanced roasted malt profile with an subtle earthy nuttiness.  Semi-dry lingering finish.
very dark brown almost black, slight burnt aroma not in a bad way, flavor was much like a good black lager but slighter harsher mouthfeel. aftertaste fades quickly.  I love this one, I buy it often

Draft.  Poured a deep brown/black color with ruby highlights and a supple tan head.  Faint aroma of roasted malt.  Flavor of roasted malt with hints of chocolate and toffee with some nuttiness in the aftertaste.  A nice beer that is easy to enjoy.

Good soft aroma of roasted malt, bitter chocolate, and some burnt caramel.  Nice pale head.  A light mouth feel with strong hints of chocolate, earthy espresso, and light nuttiness.  Reminds me more of a black lager, than a Brussels brown.

New Belgium 1554 (bottle), a deep, dark brown with a substantial off-white head, remains one of the best widely distributed beers in America. It smells of dark fruit, coffee and roasted nuts, tastes sweetly of chocolate and caramel, and maintains a few of the characteristics of a true Belgian brown ale. 1554 is one of the first beers outside of the BMC mold that I truly enjoyed years ago, and I still love the stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2009 
Name: 1554 Brussels Style Black Ale
Date: March 19, 2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Roadtrip
Appearance: black, fine beige head, lots of lace
Aroma: light roasted malt aroma
Body: creamy body
Flavor: rich chocolate malt flavor with a touch of roasted, nice dark caramel sweetness, enough hops to add balance and interest without being hoppy

Name: 1554 Brussels Style Black Ale
Date: April 07, 2007
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting
Appearance: clear dark brown, wispy beige head
Aroma: chocolate malt aroma with light roasted
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, light bitterness, the roasted and hops are not as apparent

Name: 1554 Brussels Style Black Ale
Date: November 10, 2009
Mode: draft
Words: right wing tavern
Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, fruity esters
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, sweet caramel, fruity esters

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **+ /4
[Tap, Bottle] not going to say much, but it is amazing.  much better but someone less popular than fat tire.  didnt taste a real difference between the draft and the bottle.

12 oz bottle.  Pours deep dark brown with a nice thick head.  Complex aroma, I could smell tobacco, roasted malts, nuttiness, and faint hints of chocolate.  Flavor is similiar with a bit of smokeyness to it.  Lively carbonation, medium mouthfeel, and a dry finish.

For a really dark beer, I wouldnt say black, this was a very good experience for me.  I definately felt the black licorice on the first drink, and with the aroma still fresh in my nose I  got it a little on the second dink. After that I lost the licorice and I could only taste the nutty dark almost coffee like taste. Very good beer. there are light notes of a sweet fruit deep in the beer, but you really have to take it in to get to them. The after math is a lingering smooth breath, very balanced.

Very dark, almost black. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor very similar, not too sweet. Incredible. I found it much more to my liking than most other darks like stouts or porters. Very unique.

Very dark brown/ruby with a medium sized gray/tan head. Nose chocolate roast, tobacco, subtle generic herbal notes, and a light sweetness. Same flavor. Medium body, smooth. Somewhere between a schwarzbier and a porter. Good stuff.
very dark brown,tan head,chocolate roast smell.light carbonation,roasty malt,chocolate notes,very drinkable beer,I like this.

label looked different than pictured but appears to be their only 1554 black ale.  poured fairly black, can see throw the glass in light.  decent head, some lacing as well.  aroma is malty, nutty, chocolate and coffee.  taste is smooth, chocolate powder , some roast, with a slight bitter finish.

Pours a nice dark, not black, color with little head that dissipates quickly. Nice aroma of chocolate/coffee/malt and (?) red grapes. Smooth taste with hint of orange. Nice finish that left me wanting another. A very good beer with exceptional taste.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2009 old rating:
5/3/6/3/12 - 2.9.
6/4/7/3/13 - 3.3.
6/4/7/4/15 - 3.6.

pours a dark brown with a  ruby tint, medium foamy khaki head, very good lacing.

smell is cocoa, weak coffee, slight smoke, dark fruit, caramel, some sour, earthy, and some malt.

taste is thick, sour malt, some chocolate, roasted nuts, some fruit, some spice, touch of caramel, end is slightly bitter and dry.

Twelve ounce bottle pours a clear, dark, dark brown (or red?) with a thick pale off white head that eventually leaves blotchy curtains of lacing. The aroma and flavor are mainly roasty dark chocolate / coffee malts with a hint of hops. Body is comparatively thin but not at all watery, and has lively carbonation. Finish is slightly bittersweet. Not as spicy or heavy as a porter, but excellent with a subdued meal and light enough to not bog me down even on a hot day.

Pours chocolate brown and somewhat thin.  Nose of sanitizer, clean laundry/dryer sheets and coffee malts at first.  With time and warmth come suggestions of maraschino cherry, prunes, and dry anise.  Tastes of oatmeal cookies with dark chocolate powder.  Hints of soap and wet, ground black malt.  Mildly astringent.  Burnt butterscotch in a sweet latte kind of way.  Very dry.  Texture is robust and leans slightly heavy.  Never quite arrives.  Smacks of a familiar, chalky espresso intimation.  Tired and thin in general, but pretty reasonable.

22oz bombers are back in Minnesota. Commemorative return bottle. Pours a nice deep black color and allows just a little bit of light to penetrate in some areas. Nice couple fingers of light brown head sit on the top of the brew slowly settles and leaves lots of sticky lace on the walls of the glass as it settles. Lots of burnt malt in the nose. Nice bitterness. Little bit of dry sweetness and a touch of chocolate at the very end. Nice aroma for a black ale. Very smooth black brew. Lots of burnt malt and some nice malty sweetness. Bit of subtle bitterness from the burnt malt comes through and then just a touch of coffee comes through. Dark in color but fairly medium in body and easy to drink. Smooth with a nice medium level of carbonation to it. Not much in the aftertaste. A nice mellow brew.

Usually, I hate New Belgium beers, probably because my dad has bought some in Lebanon, MO, and they have more than likely sat around on the shelf.  But I tried this one in a sampler at the Flying Saucer in Houston.

Yes, I felt it still had the "pinch of dirt" taste I always get from NB beers, but this one had some nice chocolate overtones.  While Michelob Dark is not necessarily a GOOD dark beer, it was always a nice alternative to the usual swill I drank at parties in school.  This reminds me a little bit of Mick Dark, only better.
Robe brune foncée claire surmontée dune mousse beige qui persiste. Arômes de malt torréfié. Saveurs de caramel et de malt torréfié.

I could sit and smell this ale all day.  The aroma was wonderful with chocolate, malt, plums, and roasted grain.  The aroma was so enjoyable I felt a little let down by the flavor, which was rather acidic and sour.  The chocolate flavor helped dull the sharpness.  The finish was acidic and left little lingering flavor.  The alcohol content was much too low given the aroma and flavor.  A higher alcohol content would have better helped deliver the flavors.

Black with a slight whitish head.  Aroma of fruits and malt.  Various dried/candied fruits in the flavor with a nicely balanced roasted maltyness; hops only slightly present.  Pleasant slightly bitter chocolatey aftertaste.
I drank it out of the bottle.  Chocolate and plum flavor with crispy hops.  Fairly complex, good.

Bottle. Black, thinning to red at the edges, with offwhite head. Nose of roasted malt, dark chocolate, sour dark fruit, and some faint harsh burnt notes. Flavor follows, with sweet and sour smoky notes in front, followed by a drying sweet roasted grain in the finish. This is pretty tasty stuff, and what a cool story.

12oz bottle stolen from holdenn, sorry. pours dark brown with hint of red and off white head. nose is very bready, yeasty, almost sour note, and b.o. flavor is musty, dry, bland, slighty nutty with dried dark fruits. mouth feel is watery. this nose and flavor are pretty boring. i dont get the point of this beer.

Bottle, Aroma of dark malts, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is chocolate, with a light sweetness, some coffee maybe a bit of smoked tobacco. Palate is a bit light, but tastes good, I really like this one. A nice easy drinker, but with enough taste to keep it interesting.

Rated 7/25/07.  Bottle in Las Vegas, NV.  Dark brown color with a medium tan head.  Aroma was of bittersweet chocolate malts and some smoke.  Flavor was very malty, with minimal hops present.  Chocolate and molasses dominated, with a pronounced smokey backgground.  Medium bodied with a very smooth, creamy finish.  Nice, easy drinking beer.  I would definitely try it again.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 Draft at Denver airport NB brewpub. Dark brown, nearly opaque with a medium and lasting head. Aroma is faint, mostly dry yeast with maybe a hint of cocoa and molasses. Flavor is molasses, dry yeast, cocoa and slight metallic grassy herb. Medium-heavy bodied, slightly syrupy with a dry finish.

Impressive brew.  Pours nearly black with a tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is light but with hints of chocolate, caramel, and milk.  Medium palate with light carbonation.  Taste is outstanding.  Chocolate, coffee, and malt.  Finishes sweet and dry.  A great beer from a great brewer.

Best before Oct.05, 2007. 12 oz. brown bottle. Poured out a light chocolate / deep amber color, depending on the light. Minimal head. Left a decent lacing down the sides of the glass. Aromas are of roasted malts, some burnt sugars, some chocolate. Flavors are about the same as the aromas. Decent body, medium mouthfeel. Dry, chalky finish.
Pours dark dark brown with a good sized light tan head. Aroma of chocolate and some roastiness. Dry with light bitterness at the end. Seems like a brown ale to me, but what do I know. Good stuff.
Black with moderate, fast dissapating head / Roast coffee & chocolate nose / Light-med body with forward flavors of roast coffee and lingering bittersweet chocolate finish.  Real good.

A very dark pour at Flying Saucer with minimal head.  some carmel, biscuit malt, amaretto, half and half, some chocolate, and some dark crystal malt.  very smooth mouthfeel with light carbonation.  tasty.

22 oz. bottle, called New Belgium 1554 Enlightened Black Ale. Roasted malts dominate the aroma, which features chocolate, mocha, and caramel scents and a touch of coffee sharpness. The aroma is not very complex, but its nice. Pours an amber-tinted dark brown color with a copper hue at the bottom of the glass. Produces a large amount of tan head and good, spider-web-like lacing. Pleasant, milky, creamy taste. Milk chocolate, coffee-flavored ice cream, cream soda, and shortbread cookie flavors. Light to medium body. Soft, smooth, and, especially, creamy in the palate. Produces a liveliness on the tongue nonetheless. Essentially an American version of a Continental European version of an English sweet stout / brown ale cross that tastes like a beer-flavored milkshake. It would make a fine dessert beer, despite its relatively low alcohol content. 1554 is a different kind of ale but a good one, and it stands as a pleasant surprise.

Pours a deep garnet/red with a creamy beige head. The nose is of dark roasted malts, burnt molasses and light cocoa. Medium-bodied and creamy with a roasted bitter finish. I tend to get a bit of metal in the finish on this one as well, even at temperature. The flavor is molasses, dark coffee and a dry, roasted, bitter finish that lingers a bit. A lot of my friends and fellow RateBeerians hold this beer in relatively high regard. While I am a fan of NB, Im just not feeling it with this one. Thanks for letting me steal this one from your fridge, Don.

Black pour with a cream colored medium head that fades very quickly for a dark beer.  Smells of coffee, dark roasted malt, a touch of licorice, and some alcohol.  A fairly unique nose out of a blend of seemingly common scents.  Taste is very smooth, creamy, rich, dark, and roasty.  Very nice taste overall.  There is just a touch of bitterness, and I actually wouldnt mind a bit more, which is something Ive never said about a dark beer before.  A really nice , very easy to drink darker beer and one I would recommend and buy again.  I really like everything Ive had from this brewery so far.

12 oz bottle from West LakeView Liquors.  It looks like were finally getting this New Belgium stuff weve been promised.  Enough of the Fat Tire, lets see this offering.  Pours a brown black with a beige head.  Nose is malty with chocolate and slightly sour.  Creamy medium light body.  Lightl flavors malty carmel, chocolate, belgian spice from the yeast and a light sourness.  Finishes with bakers chocolate and lemon citrus.  Ok.
Had a dark brown color. Aroma and flavor were dominated by burnt malt with a mild smokey undertone.

i really enjoyed this beer. i was not expecting it to be this good. pours a dark mahogany, you can still see through it quite a bit if you hold it up to the light. very smooth mouthfeel. no bite at all. hints of chocolate and dates. i dont know if id call it a stout though.
Fizzy dark amber body almost black.  Malty nose with faint dark roasted malt flavor.  Watery.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2008 22 ounce bottle. Shaker glass. Dark with a thin tan head. Aroma was of roast malt. Taste was roast malt, coffee and a touch of chocolate. It is similiar to a stout, but its a little thin. Only slightly above average at best.

Giving this one a second try. I was a bit harsh on this one before. While it is a bit thin is seems tonight like a more satisfying blend of the flavors listed above. I’m going to bump this one up a few points.

served cold in bottle. could not determine color from bottle, but there was definitely a large frothy head, light in color. notes of chocolate and malts in the aroma. very creamy and easy to drink, with a fraction of bitterness at the finish. an excellent choice.
22oz bomber.  Pours clear dark brown with a nice beige head.  light toffee, chocolate roasted malt, and coffee.  A bit thin, but not bad at all.

(Note: This bottle was labeled "1554 Enlightened Black Ale")
I poured this ale into a standard pint glass, producing a larg frothy head, which required me to complete the pour in a few stages.  The head was beige, with good lacing and lasted throughout the experience.  The body of the ale was clear with a dark brown color, with red highlights.

1554 had a light dark chocolate aroma that intensified as the ale warmed to room temperature.  The dark chocolate aroma is currently lingering in my moustache and is very plesant (yet another reason for facial hair!)

This ale was an easy drinking mixture, with very light acidity in its initial tasting and a short bitter finish.  The ale was full bodied, with a creamy texture and soft carbonation, with a slight metallic aftertaste on the sides of the tongue.

This was a fine ale with at great lingering aroma.  If you like hints of chocolate in your beers, this is an ale worth checking out.
Pours a very dark brown cola with a thick and creamy beige head.  Aroma of banana and bready malts.  Taste is malty with hints of banana, bread, and faint roasted chocolate.  Decent.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with rich amber highlights. Decent off-white head with some nice lacing. Roasted malt and a hint of milk chocolate on the nose. Creamy with medium carbonation. Decent flavor: lightly roasted malt. Hints of chocolate and a lighter style coffee (Breakfast Blend). Gets a tad watery at the end. Decent "light" dark beer.
Beautiful Black Ale with a light body with a thin texture and a sweet taste. Good but not near the best.

Poured a dark black color with a sticky thin tan head.  Aroma was very malty, slightly sweet, woody, smoky, slightly salty, and with a hint of tobacco.  Flavors were mostly malty and sweet, but with a distinct salty (soy sauce-like) element and some bitterness.  Fairly full-bodied but not too heavy.  Not bad overall.
Another placemarker for a beer Ive had many times but never fully rated.  Black, burnt, and blah.

Very dark purple-brown; light tan, slightly frothy head.  Aroma of bready malt and roast and ash; nutty; a hint of plum.  Flavor is malty, roasty, nutty, and a tiny bit smoky.  Medium body; medium sticky.  A decent beer, but I would rate it higher if I liked the style more.
Spicy beer. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a bubbly tan thin head. Pretty good has a bit of bite to it which makes it more difficult to drink. Overall pretty good and very yeasty.

Poured a black mahogany with ruby highlights beneath an average head of creamy tan foam. The nose was of roasted chocolate and coffee-beans. The taste started biscuity with some darker, roasted notes next. Toffee brings up the end along with a spicy/acidic snap from the dark malts. These combine with the roated bitterness to balance it out nicely. It finishes with a lingering note of roasty, dark-chocolate accented caramel. The feel was rich with a light/ medium-body.The flavor is not aggressive or strong. Its a well balanced ale that is definately worth a try or two. Quite nice!

12 ounce bottle dated best before 10AUG07.  Poured into a shaker.  Pours dark brown with a dense tan head.  Fairly clean aroma with some spice and black malt character.  The flavor is similar to a chocolate cover caramel candy.  Clean finish.  With all that said, Ive never been too excited by this beer.

Bottle.  Darkish pour, black with some red highlights.  Nice toasted malt aroma and tasted.  A touch of sweetness, cane sugar almost.  I would like a bit more body to this one, other than that, quite nice.
Dark with a white head.  Bready smells with a hint of banana.  Taste is light and thin with a sweet caramel finish.

12 oz bottle from mreusch - thanks! Best by 29DEC06 - Im a bit late. Clear, deep, dark brown with a thick tan head. Sweet, lightly smoky malt nose, bitter nut scents, some dark fruit notes. Beautiful sheet of tan lace. Burnt caramel flavors, roasty malt, lightly nutty. Finish of over toasted bread and dark molasses, a tad acidic. Interesting brew.

Roasty coffee aroma. Thick tan head. Black even when held to the light. can taste coffee and chocolate flavors. Very dry roastyness. Velvety smooth moutfeel. Its yummy.there is alot of chocolate in that finish.

Dry, roasty, slight spice aroma. Pours with a fizzy cola head that quickly subsides. Taste is moderately sweet, ginger and birch, light caramel chocolate and cilantro. A little bit over fizzy, but very well balanced. Very schwarzbier like. I like this a lot.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 on tap @ papago. aroma and flavor=  very wet woody and roasted grainy with lots of dark molasses and dried fruits. chocolate and coffee on the finish linger in the aftertaste.  nice and malty, not too hoppy... pretty tasty brew.

This is the perfect dark ale,I have finally found a great ale,with mild hops.It is not too bitter,the sweet malts are perfect.This is the best dark ale I have ever had and I will make my primary daily drinker.I liked everything about it. Perfect! I like this brew better than fat tire.Its the best tasting beer in the world ,I love it.

Highly carbonated pour from a bottle with a BB Date of 10 Aug 07.  Watching this thing I couldnt help think it was continuing to ferment in my mug, but the bubbly head quickly dissipated.  Nutty flavor is actually very very smooth compared to what I expected following the pour.  Aroma is very weak, but not offensive.  Some hints of coffee with a mild, yet sweet malt flavor.  I cant help think I note a very mild tobacco flavor either...interesting to say the least  A very enjoyable beer.

Bottle courtesy of Dubbercody, thanks again! Dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, light smoke and brown sugar. FLavors held some more sweet malt with light smoke elements and a bit of coffee. Medium body...sweet throughout witha dry/sweet finish.

Bottle: Poured a dark brown color with a thin off white head. Dark fruit and dark malts aroma. Flavor is pretty much the same. Malty sweet and fruity esters. No real roasty or bitter qualities. Too one note for me. Try the Midnight Sun Conspiracy for an awesome belgian Black Beer.

One of the best Black beers I have had.  The body was that of an ale, but flavored rich like a sweet stout.  High coffee/chocolate notes.  Very smooth and enjoyable to drink.  MUCH better than Sam Adams Black Lager.  And not as carbonated.
Sampled with stegosaurus. Pours black in color with a small off white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, toffee, and a hint of chocolate. A smooth medium body beer. Good brew
Rich malt nose with a hint of carmel and molases.  Low bitterness and very smooth.  Thin but robust head and moderate lacing.  All in all perhaps one of the best New Belgians I have had.

Bottle, at tria Fermentation School New Belgium event 4/11/07. Ruby brown, with a thin light brown head. Malty aroma with some banana and anise. Deep malt flavor with some chocolate and pepper. Long chocolate finish.
A warm, nutty flavor is accompanied by a slightly astringent aftertaste.  This tastes like a higher-ABV beer.
Poured a clear dark brown color with a hint of ruby on the edge.  Fruity and roasty aroma and flavor.  Light coffee notes on the flavor.  Medium bodied.

This beer smelled heavily of coffee and chocolate.  From the tap it looked black, almost like tar.  It was quite opaque.  The malty roasted flavor was accented well with chocolate highlights.  With a medium to full body, this beer had a surprisingly clean and crisp finish.  It was pretty good for the style, but it is not my prefered style.

12 Oz Bottle. Unique charred hickory and seared chicken aroma. Leafy herbs blow through. Dark mahogany with orange fringe, rimmed in silky off-white. Flavor a smooth, toothy roast grain, with wisping cocoa nib and caramel toffees. A candied perfume of lemongrass and licorice run through the background, inspiring balance and complexity. Malt character morphs into woody toast and light pecan smoke. Dry and drinkable, with woodruff? A nip of licorice herbal sense in the middle gives a unique cast of circus to this beer. Finishes in some standard caramel and light goldings lemon leaf. A well-balanced, clean dark bier with unique edges for something out of the ordinary. Appreciable.

Nottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark with with a small white head. Aroma of chocolate, roast, sweetness, and caramel. The flavor is sweet, caramel, chocolate, roast, mild hoppy traces. Good brew.
A bit chalky, but overall a good brew.  It has some nice smoked coffee tones and a rich malty texture.

Bottle shared by nolankowal: Light black, not quite a dark brown, off white head. Aroma, roasted notes, some toffee, coffee, and some fruits. Flavor, fruity, roasted malts, caramel, and coffee. Not bad.
12oz bottle-A dark brown almost black black with an off white head. Aroma of coffee and dark roasted malt. Taste of roasted malt and coffee. Nice beer.

Pours black with a small off-white head.  Malty and hoppy with caramel and maybe some chocolate, and a slightly bitter aftertase.  It has a pretty watery feel to it.
Overall a good beer, but nothing special.  This is typically what I drink when I want a beer, but dont feel like a high-dollar one.

Dark brown to black with ruby and rusty highlights. Thick tan head slowly fades. Chocolate aromas, dark caramel and light rubber. Soft carbonated mouthfeel releases charred malts and toffee and dark cherry to appley hops. Finish is lightly cocoa. Moutfeel is medium -light with playful carbonation.

Hard to define this style of beer.  Reminds me of the old ale style (Old Peculier).  I decided to try this because Im such a big fan of Fat Tire.  I wasnt disappointed.  This brewery seems to know what theyre doing.  Black (not pitch), thin, stout-like pour with dissipating light tan head.  Aroma gives away the hop character along with the bready malt notes.  Some chocalate or caramel in there as well.  Overall impression is (as other raters put it) a zestiness that really comes out at you.  Not as drinkable as Fat Tire, but good.
Pours like a stout. Has the strong hoppy taste that New Belgian is famous for. Goes down very smooth and has a lasting aftertaste of roasted spices. Highly recommended.

Thinner than expected. First thing that hit me was scent of yeast. Beer tastes of faint caramel or toffee malts, light hoppines. wasnt unimpressed but this beer is nothing more than drinkable. Decent ale.

12 oz bottle; Nose of caramel malt with some chocolate notes and a little breadiness; very dark cherry brownwitha big glass-lacing tan head, nice lookin ale; flavor has some coffee and caramel malts with a little faint chocolate. Very good ale.
Dark reddish brown; near black, body with very light aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Initial zesty acidic flavor with surprisingly clean, refreshing finish.  My all-time personal favorite.

Very smooth for a dark beer it pours a nice light black with a light tan head.  The aroma is so mild its hard to define.  Taste is only somewhat bitter with hints of and vanilla roasted malts.  Aftertaste is short and dry.
Another very good beer from New Belgium.  Crisp nutbrown flavor with a great malty ton.  The alcohol is well hidden and the palate is smooth and warm.
Really refreshing - and refreshingly light, despite appearance. Nice roasted, heavy malt character. Light coffee bean and some very subtle nuttiness.

12 oz. bottle - Pours a clear deep mohogany color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Light lacing.  Flavor and aroma is lightly smoked, dark roasted malt with a touch of dark esters.  Has enough bitterness to balance the beer.  A smooth, medium body beer.  Another decent NB offering.

Bottle.  Black color, brownish around the edges, brown head.  Typical roasted malt/coffee aroma with some belgian yeast/wheat.  Pretty thin and smooth mouthfeel, taste is similar to aroma with some licorice and black cherry.  Improved a lot as it warmed.

Black.  Aroma of roasted malt and coffee.  Tastes of the same with an underlying sweetness.  The flavor and malt profiles are less pronounced than in other stouts.  This results in a subtle refreshing stout.
Poured black with big fluffy head.  I couldnt really catch the aroma but thats typical for me.  Taste was slightly acidic and finished dry and somewhat metallic.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 (Bottle, thanks Beachbum25) Pours deep dark red with a nougat coloured head. Caramelly aroma with spicy soap and a slight smokey touch. Roasted undertones and some liquorice. Smooth mouthfeel. Roasted and almost light burned flavour with a salty sting. Tiny notes of nuts,chocolate, coffee, liquorice and a light spicyness. Thin aftertaste with a dryish touch and a light to medium body.

On tap at The Graduate.  Hint of light shinning through.  Rich white head, very fine bubbles.  Couldnt detect exact scents initially, but after sampling I could pick out some odors.  I thought this beer to have some unique flavors.  When it first hits your tongue, it is somewhat ordinary and tame possessing a bit of a weak mouthfeel.  However, right before swallowing you are hit with a sweet honey-like wash of flavor.  Once the honey subsides, chocolate and other toasty flavors emerge.  If you think you may like honey beers or brown ales mixed with malt, this might be your beer.
Pours deep brown, with a tan head. aroma is of roasted malts. The taste is of coffee, chocolate, molassess and the roasted malt makes it farily smoky. The body is pretty watery.

Bottle courtesy of ford9719. Watery medium brown, minimal off-white head. Aroma has soem burnt grain and coffee and not much else. Flavor much the same with some caramel, smoke and raisin. Mouthfeel really thins in finish. Not bad, just something doesnt mesh well.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 Re-rate. Bottle. Sweet malt, wood, and spice aroma with some very mild fruit notes. Dark mahogany with a thing beige head, bubbly and patchy. Flavor is dominated by a light smokiness without too much depth or body. Some spice in the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2010 Reminds me of a sweeter brown ale with a small hints of chocolate. Simple flavor with chocolate and licorice.  mouthfeel is a tiny bit flat and is my biggest complaint, maybe a little more zest or fullness would really help.  flavor seems a little wimpy until it warms up and lets more flavors out, then its pretty acceptable.  nice enough and a little unique, especially nice when a bar has it available and youre not stuck with BL
Poured dark brown with a thick head.  Aroma of malt and alcohol.  Flavour of malt, espresso and malt.  Lekker finish with malty notes, lingering.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle, 12 oz., Pours a  molasses dark brown with a thin short-lived head, a slight and simple aroma with hints of malt,  and alcohol, medium creamy roasted malt flavor fading to a warm smokey black cherry residue.  An enjoyable palate for an everyday beer with a lively initial carbondation and a lazy oily finish.

Black, revealing translucent deep burgundy when held up to the light. Creamy extremely fine mocha head settles to a complete cap.

Roasty bitter chocolate leads the nose, supported by a delicate fruitness and some fresh brown bready malt. Lovely and very appetizing.

Thin side of medium in the mouth. The bitter chocolate leads the way with some browned cookie maltiness. Richer malt kicks in on the mid-palate, and gently fades to leave the crisp, roasty goodness to end things on the long finish.

Modest carbonation suits the style well and gives a lovely mouthfeel. Extremely drinkable in quantity and an excellent and flexible companion at the table (another is doing very well with a wild mushroom lasagna as I type). A staple in my DBF.
